Recent studies suggested that human/mammalian genomes are divided into large, discrete domains that are units of chromosome organization.	BACKGROUND
CTCF, a CCCTC binding factor, has a diverse role in genome regulation including transcriptional regulation, chromosome-boundary insulation, DNA replication, and chromatin packaging.	BACKGROUND
It remains unclear whether a subset of CTCF binding sites plays a functional role in establishing/maintaining chromatin topological domains.	BACKGROUND
We systematically analysed the genomic, transcriptomic and epigenetic profiles of the CTCF binding sites in 56 human cell lines from ENCODE.	RESULTS
We identified ~24,000 CTCF sites (referred to as constitutive sites) that were bound in more than 90% of the cell lines.	RESULTS
Our analysis revealed: 1) constitutive CTCF loci were located in constitutive open chromatin and often co-localized with constitutive cohesin loci; 2) most constitutive CTCF loci were distant from transcription start sites and lacked CpG islands but were enriched with the full-spectrum CTCF motifs: a recently reported 33/34-mer and two other potentially novel (22/26-mer); 3) more importantly, most constitutive CTCF loci were present in CTCF-mediated chromatin interactions detected by ChIA-PET and these pair-wise interactions occurred predominantly within, but not between, topological domains identified by Hi-C.   CONCLUSIONS Our results suggest that the constitutive CTCF sites may play a role in organizing/maintaining the recently identified topological domains that are common across most human cells.	RESULTS

Patients with signs and symptoms of heart failure and a normal left ventricular ejection fraction are said to have diastolic heart failure.	BACKGROUND
It has traditionally been thought that the pathophysiological cause of heart failure in these patients is an abnormality in the diastolic properties of the left ventricle; however, this hypothesis remains largely unproven.	BACKGROUND
We prospectively identified 47 patients who met the diagnostic criteria for definite diastolic heart failure; all the patients had signs and symptoms of heart failure, a normal ejection fraction, and an increased left ventricular end-diastolic pressure.	METHODS
Ten patients who had no evidence of cardiovascular disease served as controls.	METHODS
Left ventricular diastolic function was assessed by means of cardiac catheterization and echocardiography.	METHODS
The patients with diastolic heart failure had abnormal left ventricular relaxation and increased left ventricular chamber stiffness.	RESULTS
The mean (+/-SD) time constant for the isovolumic-pressure decline (tau) was longer in the group with diastolic heart failure than in the control group (59+/-14 msec vs. 35+/-10 msec, P=0.01).	RESULTS
The diastolic pressure-volume relation was shifted up and to the left in the patients with diastolic heart failure as compared with the controls.	RESULTS
The corrected left ventricular passive-stiffness constant was significantly higher in the group with diastolic heart failure than in the control group (0.03+/-0.01 vs. 0.01+/-0.01, P<0.001).	RESULTS
Patients with heart failure and a normal ejection fraction have significant abnormalities in active relaxation and passive stiffness.	CONCLUSIONS
In these patients, the pathophysiological cause of elevated diastolic pressures and heart failure is abnormal diastolic function.	CONCLUSIONS

We explored the subjective effects associated with olanzapine, risperidone and older antipsychotics.	OBJECTIVE
We conducted a content analysis of an Internet database of comments about prescribed medications.	METHODS
We analysed 223 comments on risperidone, 170 on olanzapine and 46 relating to three older antipsychotics.	RESULTS
The predominant subjective effects produced by all drugs consisted of sedation, cognitive impairment and emotional flattening or indifference.	RESULTS
Connections appeared between these effects and Parkinsonian-like symptoms with the older drugs, sexual impairment with risperidone and metabolic effects with olanzapine.	RESULTS
The experience of akathisia was frequently linked to suicidal thoughts.	RESULTS
Some respondents described how the drugs' subjective effects helped to reduce symptoms of mania, psychosis and anxiety.	RESULTS
The generalisability of Internet data is uncertain.	CONCLUSIONS
However, the data suggest that adverse subjective effects play a central role in the experience of taking antipsychotic drugs and may be related to the drugs' desired benefits.	CONCLUSIONS

White matter hyperintensities (WMHs) are areas of increased signal on T2-weighted magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scans that most commonly reflect small vessel cerebrovascular disease.	OBJECTIVE
Increased WMH volume is associated with risk and progression of Alzheimer's disease (AD).	OBJECTIVE
These observations are typically interpreted as evidence that vascular abnormalities play an additive, independent role contributing to symptom presentation, but not core features of AD.	OBJECTIVE
We examined the severity and distribution of WMH in presymptomatic PSEN1, PSEN2, and APP mutation carriers to determine the extent to which WMH manifest in individuals genetically determined to develop AD.	OBJECTIVE
The study comprised participants (n = 299; age = 39.03 ± 10.13) from the Dominantly Inherited Alzheimer Network, including 184 (61.5%) with a mutation that results in AD and 115 (38.5%) first-degree relatives who were noncarrier controls.	METHODS
We calculated the estimated years from expected symptom onset (EYO) by subtracting the affected parent's symptom onset age from the participant's age.	METHODS
Baseline MRI data were analyzed for total and regional WMH.	METHODS
Mixed-effects piece-wise linear regression was used to examine WMH differences between carriers and noncarriers with respect to EYO.	METHODS
Mutation carriers had greater total WMH volumes, which appeared to increase approximately 6 years before expected symptom onset.	RESULTS
Effects were most prominent for the parietal and occipital lobe, which showed divergent effects as early as 22 years before estimated onset.	RESULTS
Autosomal-dominant AD is associated with increased WMH well before expected symptom onset.	CONCLUSIONS
The findings suggest the possibility that WMHs are a core feature of AD, a potential therapeutic target, and a factor that should be integrated into pathogenic models of the disease.	CONCLUSIONS
Ann Neurol 2016;79:929-939.	CONCLUSIONS

Previous in vitro and in vivo studies have revealed an association between Helicobacter pylori infection and apoptosis in gastric epithelial cells.	BACKGROUND
Although involvement of the Bcl-2 family of proteins as well as cytochrome c release has been demonstrated in H pylori induced cell death, the exact role of the mitochondria during this type of programmed cell death has not been fully elucidated.	BACKGROUND
Therefore, we sought to determine whether or not Bax translocation and mitochondrial fragmentation occur on exposure of gastric epithelial cells to H pylori, resulting in cell death.	BACKGROUND
Experiments were performed with human gastric adenocarcinoma (AGS) cells, AGS cells transfected with the HPV-E6 gene (which inactivates p53 function), AGS-neo cells (transfected with the backbone construct), mouse embryonic fibroblasts (MEFs), and p19(ARF) null (ARF(-/-)) MEFs.	METHODS
Cells were incubated with a cag positive H pylori strain for up to 24 hours, lysed, and cytoplasmic and mitochondrial membrane fractions were analysed by western blot for Bax translocation.	METHODS
Bax translocation was detected in AGS, AGS-neo, and normal MEF cells after exposure to H pylori for three hours, but not in ARF(-/-) MEFs cells.	RESULTS
Translocation of Bax after H pylori incubation was also detected in AGS-E6 cells (inactive p53 gene) but to a lesser degree than in AGS-neo cells.	RESULTS
In parallel studies, the mitochondrial morphology of living cells infected with H pylori was assessed by confocal microscopy.	RESULTS
Mitochondrial fragmentation was detectable after 10 hours of H pylori incubation with AGS cells and after seven hours with MEF cells.	RESULTS
In wild-type MEFs, mitochondrial fragmentation was significantly increased in comparison with ARF null MEFs (43% v 10.4%, respectively).	RESULTS
Furthermore, mitochondrial depolarisation and caspase-3 activity were initiated within four hours in cells incubated with H pylori, and these events were inhibited by forced expression of Bcl-2.	RESULTS
These data suggest that during H pylori induced apoptosis, Bax translocates to the mitochondria which subsequently undergo depolarisation and profound fragmentation.	CONCLUSIONS
Functional ARF and p53 proteins may play an important role in H pylori induced mitochondrial modification.	CONCLUSIONS

Interleukin-24 (IL-24) is a cytokine that belongs to the IL-10 family.	BACKGROUND
It can selectively induce cancer cell apoptosis which has been utilized as a cancer gene therapy strategy.	BACKGROUND
A recombinant type five adenovirus containing IL-24 gene (designated CNHK600-IL24) was constructed, whose replication is activated only in tumor cells.	METHODS
The replication of CNHK600-IL24 in breast tumor cells and fibroblasts were assessed by TCID50 and MTT assay; the secretion of IL-24 was measured by ELISA and western blotting.	METHODS
The in vivo anti-tumor effect of CNHK600-IL24 was investigated in nude mice carrying orthotopic or metastatic breast tumor.	METHODS
We observed that CNHK600-IL24 could replicate efficiently and resulted in high level IL-24 expression and massive cell death in human breast cancer cell MDA-MB-231 but not in normal fibroblast cell MRC-5.	RESULTS
In addition, orthotopic breast tumor growth in the nude mice model was significantly suppressed when CNHK600-IL24 was administered.	RESULTS
In the metastatic model generated by tail vein injection, CNHK600-IL24 virotherapy significantly improved survival compared with the same virus expressing EGFP (median survival CNHK600-IL24, 55 days vs. CNHK600-EGFP, 41 day, p < 0.05 Mantal-Cox test).	RESULTS
A similar phenomenon was observed in the metastatic model achieved by left ventricular injection as suggested by in vivo luminescence imaging of tumor growth.	RESULTS
The oncolytic adenovirus armed with IL-24, which exhibited enhanced anti-tumor activity and improved survival, is a promising candidate for virotherapy of breast cancer.	CONCLUSIONS

Migraineurs are at increased risk of cerebellar infarcts and supratentorial white matter lesions.	BACKGROUND
The prevalence, frequency, and distribution of infratentorial hyperintense lesions in migraine are unknown.	BACKGROUND
Migraineurs with aura (n=161), without aura (n=134), and controls (n=140) from a population-based sample of adults (30 to 60 years of age) were evaluated with MRI.	METHODS
Infratentorial hyperintensities were identified in 13 of 295 (4.4%) migraineurs and in 1 of 140 (0.7%) controls (P=0.04).	RESULTS
Twelve cases had hyperintensities, mostly bilaterally, in the dorsal basis pontis.	RESULTS
Those with infratentorial hyperintensities also had supratentorial white matter lesions more often.	RESULTS
We found an increased prevalence of infratentorial (mostly pontine) hyperintensities in migraineurs from the general population.	CONCLUSIONS
This extends the knowledge about vulnerable brain regions and type of lesions in migraine brains.	CONCLUSIONS
A hemodynamic ischemic pathogenesis is likely, but further research is needed.	CONCLUSIONS

Although the Polypill concept (proposed in 2003) is promising in terms of benefits for cardiovascular risk management, the potential costs and adverse effects are its main pitfalls.	OBJECTIVE
The objective of this study was to identify a tastier and safer alternative to the Polypill: the Polymeal.	OBJECTIVE
Data on the ingredients of the Polymeal were taken from the literature.	METHODS
The evidence based recipe included wine, fish, dark chocolate, fruits, vegetables, garlic, and almonds.	METHODS
Data from the Framingham heart study and the Framingham offspring study were used to build life tables to model the benefits of the Polymeal in the general population from age 50, assuming multiplicative correlations.	METHODS
Combining the ingredients of the Polymeal would reduce cardiovascular disease events by 76%.	RESULTS
For men, taking the Polymeal daily represented an increase in total life expectancy of 6.6 years, an increase in life expectancy free from cardiovascular disease of 9.0 years, and a decrease in life expectancy with cardiovascular disease of 2.4 years.	RESULTS
The corresponding differences for women were 4.8, 8.1, and 3.3 years.	RESULTS
The Polymeal promises to be an effective, non-pharmacological, safe, cheap, and tasty alternative to reduce cardiovascular morbidity and increase life expectancy in the general population.	CONCLUSIONS

To compare contemporary pregnancy outcomes in women with and without type 1 diabetes, and to examine the effects of obesity and glycaemic control on these outcomes.	OBJECTIVE
Historical cohort study in a specialist diabetes and maternity network in Victoria.	METHODS
All singleton births (at least 20 weeks' gestation), 2010-2013, were analysed: 107 pregnancies to women with type 1 diabetes and 27 075 pregnancies to women without diabetes.	METHODS
Women with type 2 diabetes or gestational diabetes were excluded.	METHODS
Data were extracted from the Birthing Outcomes System database; associations between type 1 diabetes and pregnancy outcomes were analysed by multivariable regression.	METHODS
Mode of birth; maternal and neonatal outcomes.	METHODS
The mean body mass index was higher for women with type 1 diabetes than for women without diabetes (mean, 27.3 kg/m(2) [SD, 5.0] v 25.7 kg/m(2) [SD, 5.9]; P = 0.01); the median gestation period for their babies was shorter (median, 37.3 weeks [IQR, 34.6-38.1] v 39.4 weeks [IQR, 38.4-40.4]; P < 0.001) and they were more likely to be large for gestational age (LGA) (adjusted odds ratio [aOR], 7.9; 95% CI, 5.3-11.8).	RESULTS
Women with type 1 diabetes were more likely to have had labour induced (aOR, 3.0; 95% CI, 2.0-4.5), a caesarean delivery (aOR, 4.6; 95% CI, 3.1-7.0), or a pre-term birth (aOR, 6.7; 95% CI, 4.5-10.0); their babies were more likely to have shoulder dystocia (aOR, 8.2; 95% CI, 3.6-18.7), hypoglycaemia (aOR, 10.3; 95% CI, 6.8-15.6), jaundice (aOR, 5.1; 95% CI, 3.3-7.7), respiratory distress (aOR, 2.5; 95% CI, 1.4-4.4) or to suffer perinatal death (aOR, 4.3; 95% CI, 1.9-9.9).	RESULTS
In women with type 1 diabetes, greater obesity was associated with increased odds for an LGA baby or congenital malformation, and increased HbA1c levels were associated with pre-term birth and perinatal death.	RESULTS
Women with type 1 diabetes, even when managed in a specialist setting, still experience adverse obstetric and neonatal outcomes.	CONCLUSIONS
Poor glycaemic control is not wholly responsible for adverse outcomes, reinforcing the importance of other risk factors, such as obesity and weight gain.	CONCLUSIONS

Cali, Colombia, has a high incidence of interpersonal violence deaths.	BACKGROUND
Various alcohol control policies have been implemented to reduce alcohol-related problems.	BACKGROUND
The objective of this study was to determine whether different alcohol control policies were associated with changes in the incidence rate of homicides.	BACKGROUND
Ecologic study conducted during 2004-08 using a time-series design.	METHODS
Policies were implemented with variations in hours of restriction of sales and consumption of alcohol.	METHODS
Most restrictive policies prohibited alcohol between 2 a.m. and 10 a.m. for 446 non-consecutive days.	METHODS
Moderately restrictive policies prohibited alcohol between 3 a.m. and 10 a.m. for 1277 non-consecutive days.	METHODS
Lax policies prohibited alcohol between 4 a.m. and 10 a.m. for 104 non-consecutive days.	METHODS
In conditional autoregressive negative binomial regressions, rates of homicides and unintentional injury deaths (excluding traffic events) were compared between different periods of days when different policies were in effect.	METHODS
There was an increased risk of homicides in periods when the moderately restrictive policies were in effect compared with periods when the most restrictive policies were in effect [incidence rate ratio (IRR) 1.15, 90% confidence interval (CI) 1.05-1.26, P = 0.012], and there was an even higher risk of homicides in periods when the lax policies were in effect compared with periods when the most restrictive policies were in effect (IRR 1.42, 90% CI 1.26-1.61, P < 0.001).	RESULTS
Less restrictive policies were not associated with increased risk of unintentional injury deaths.	RESULTS
Extended hours of sales and consumption of alcohol were associated with increased risk of homicides.	CONCLUSIONS
Strong restrictions on alcohol availability could reduce the incidence of interpersonal violence events in communities where homicides are high.	CONCLUSIONS

In patients with Ovarian Cancer (OvCa) exosomes released by tumor cells are present in the plasma and could be involved in tumor progression.	BACKGROUND
This study examines the association between the exosome presence/protein content in plasma of OvCa patients and disease outcome, response to standard therapy and/or tumorresistance to therapies in patients studied at diagnosis and also serially during and after therapy.	BACKGROUND
Exosomes were purified from OvCa patients' plasma (n=22), patients with benign tumors (n=10) or (n=10) healthy controls (NC) using ultracentrifugation.	METHODS
Exosomes were visualized by scanning electron microscopy.	METHODS
Their protein content was measured.	METHODS
The presence of MAGE 3/6 and TGF-β1 in exosomes was evaluated in Western blots.	METHODS
The OvCa patients' plasma contained higher levels of exosomal proteins (p<0.05) compared to those isolated from plasma of patients with benign tumors or NC.	RESULTS
Exosomes isolated from OvCa patients's plasma carried TGF-β1 and MAGE3/6, which distinguished OvCa patients from those with benign tumors and NC.	RESULTS
High protein levels of exosomes were seen in newly diagnosed patients; however in advanced stages of OvCa patients the protein content of isolated exosomes was significantly higher than that of early stages.	RESULTS
The exosome levels variably changed during/after chemotherapy, and correlations between the changes in exosomal protein levels and clinical data suggested that the protein content of exosomes might be useful in predicting responses to therapy and prognosis in OvCa patients.	RESULTS
Analysis of plasma exosomes levels offers a novel approach to diagnosis and monitoring response to therapies in OvCa patients.	CONCLUSIONS

To measure the impact on transmission of leishmaniasis of curtains impregnated with insecticide.	OBJECTIVE
Cluster randomised controlled trial: household interview survey, observational study of people's behaviour, entomological study with light trap captures of sandflies inside houses.	METHODS
14 urban sectors in Trujillo, Venezuela.	METHODS
2913 inhabitants of 569 houses.	METHODS
Sectors were paired according to their 12 month cumulative incidence of cutaneous leishmaniasis, one sector in each pair was randomly allocated to receive polyester curtains impregnated with lambdacyhalothrin (intervention group) while the other sector received curtains without insecticide or no curtains (control groups).	METHODS
After 12 months a follow up household survey was conducted.	METHODS
Reduction in abundance of sandflies indoors and 12 month incidence of clinical cases of cutaneous leishmaniasis.	METHODS
Transmission of cutaneous leishmaniasis occurred mainly in the domestic setting, with the incidence over 12 months of 4%.	RESULTS
The mean number of sandflies per trap per night was 16.	RESULTS
After follow up the 12 month incidence of cutaneous leishmaniasis was 0% in the intervention group and 8% in the six pairs in the control group that received unimpregnated curtains (mean difference 8, 95% confidence interval 4.22 to 11.78; P=0.001).	RESULTS
There were significantly fewer sandflies in the intervention group (2 v 15, mean difference 13 sandflies per trap; 9 to 17; P<0.001).	RESULTS
Curtains impregnated with insecticide provide a high degree of protection against indoor transmission of cutaneous leishmaniasis.	CONCLUSIONS

Dystrophins, utrophins, and their associated proteins are involved in structural and signaling roles in nonmuscle tissues; however, description of these proteins in neutrophils remained unexplored.	OBJECTIVE
Therefore we characterize the pattern expression, and the cellular distribution of dystrophin and utrophin gene products and dystrophin-associated proteins (i.e., beta-dystroglycan, alpha-syntrophin, and alpha-dystrobrevins) in relation to actin filaments in resting and activated with formyl-methionyl-leucyl-phenylalanine human neutrophils.	OBJECTIVE
Resting and fMLP-activated human neutrophils were analyzed by immunoblot and by confocal microscopy analysis.	METHODS
Immunoprecipitation assays were performed to corroborate the presence of protein complexes.	METHODS
Immunoprecipitation assays and confocal analysis demonstrated the presence of two dystrophin-associated protein complexes in resting and activated neutrophils: the former formed by Dp71d/Dp71Delta(110)(m) and dystrophin-associated proteins (beta-dystroglycan, alpha-syntrophin, alpha-dystrobrevin-1, and -2), while the latter contains Up400, instead of Dp71d/Dp71Delta(110)(m), as a central component of the dystrophin-associated protein complexes (DAPC).	RESULTS
Confocal analysis also showed the subcellular redistribution of Dp71d/Dp71Delta(110)(m) approximately DAPC and Up400 approximately DAPC in F-actin-based structures displayed during activation process with fMLP.	RESULTS
Our study showed the existence of two protein complexes formed by Dp71d/Dp71Delta(110)(m) or Up400 associated with DAPs in resting and fMLP-treated human polymorphonuclears.	CONCLUSIONS
The interaction of these complexes with the actin cytoskeleton is indicative of their dynamic participation in the chemotaxis process.	CONCLUSIONS

Variability of gene expression in human may link gene sequence variability and phenotypes; however, non-genetic variations, alone or in combination with genetics, may also influence expression traits and have a critical role in physiological and disease processes.	BACKGROUND
METHODOLOGY/PRINCIPAL FINDINGS To get better insight into the overall variability of gene expression, we assessed the transcriptome of circulating monocytes, a key cell involved in immunity-related diseases and atherosclerosis, in 1,490 unrelated individuals and investigated its association with >675,000 SNPs and 10 common cardiovascular risk factors.	BACKGROUND
Out of 12,808 expressed genes, 2,745 expression quantitative trait loci were detected (P<5.78x10(-12)), most of them (90%) being cis-modulated.	BACKGROUND
Extensive analyses showed that associations identified by genome-wide association studies of lipids, body mass index or blood pressure were rarely compatible with a mediation by monocyte expression level at the locus.	BACKGROUND
At a study-wide level (P<3.9x10(-7)), 1,662 expression traits (13.0%) were significantly associated with at least one risk factor.	BACKGROUND
Genome-wide interaction analyses suggested that genetic variability and risk factors mostly acted additively on gene expression.	BACKGROUND
Because of the structure of correlation among expression traits, the variability of risk factors could be characterized by a limited set of independent gene expressions which may have biological and clinical relevance.	BACKGROUND
For example expression traits associated with cigarette smoking were more strongly associated with carotid atherosclerosis than smoking itself.	BACKGROUND
CONCLUSIONS/SIGNIFICANCE This study demonstrates that the monocyte transcriptome is a potent integrator of genetic and non-genetic influences of relevance for disease pathophysiology and risk assessment.	BACKGROUND

Ovarian clear-cell and endometrioid carcinomas may arise from endometriosis, but the molecular events involved in this transformation have not been described.	BACKGROUND
We sequenced the whole transcriptomes of 18 ovarian clear-cell carcinomas and 1 ovarian clear-cell carcinoma cell line and found somatic mutations in ARID1A (the AT-rich interactive domain 1A [SWI-like] gene) in 6 of the samples.	METHODS
ARID1A encodes BAF250a, a key component of the SWI–SNF chromatin remodeling complex.	METHODS
We sequenced ARID1A in an additional 210 ovarian carcinomas and a second ovarian clear-cell carcinoma cell line and measured BAF250a expression by means of immunohistochemical analysis in an additional 455 ovarian carcinomas.	METHODS
ARID1A mutations were seen in 55 of 119 ovarian clear-cell carcinomas (46%), 10 of 33 endometrioid carcinomas (30%), and none of the 76 high-grade serous ovarian carcinomas.	RESULTS
Seventeen carcinomas had two somatic mutations each.	RESULTS
Loss of the BAF250a protein correlated strongly with the ovarian clear-cell carcinoma and endometrioid carcinoma subtypes and the presence of ARID1A mutations.	RESULTS
In two patients, ARID1A mutations and loss of BAF250a expression were evident in the tumor and contiguous atypical endometriosis but not in distant endometriotic lesions.	RESULTS
These data implicate ARID1A as a tumor-suppressor gene frequently disrupted in ovarian clear-cell and endometrioid carcinomas.	CONCLUSIONS
Since ARID1A mutation and loss of BAF250a can be seen in the preneoplastic lesions, we speculate that this is an early event in the transformation of endometriosis into cancer.	CONCLUSIONS
(Funded by the British Columbia Cancer Foundation and the Vancouver General Hospital–University of British Columbia Hospital Foundation.).	CONCLUSIONS

& OBJECTIVES Anaemia is commonly observed in children with malaria, but reports on leucocyte and platelet count abnormalities associated with malaria are inconsistent.	BACKGROUND
This study examined the effect of age, gender, parasite density and temperature on haematological parameters in children with acute uncomplicated malaria.	BACKGROUND
Haematological parameters were determined in children with acute uncomplicated malaria, and these were correlated with age, sex, temperature and parasite density.	METHODS
Statistical analysis was done using SAS 9.1.	METHODS
Six hundred and ninety five children with acute uncomplicated malaria participated in the study.	RESULTS
The mean age was 51.7 months +/-	RESULTS
33.8.	RESULTS
At presentation, anaemia occurred in 43.8% of the patients and children <5 yr had a significantly lower haematocrit (28.4% +/- 4.8) than that of older children (32.8% +/-	RESULTS
4.8) (p <0.001), but the haematocrit was not significantly different by days 14 and 28.	RESULTS
There was no difference between both sexes.	RESULTS
Leucocytosis was more frequently seen than leucopenia (9.5% vs 3%).	RESULTS
Thrombocytopenia was found in 59.3% of enrolled patients.	RESULTS
More than half of the patients with thrombocytopenia had recovered by Day 28.	RESULTS
Baseline platelet count was related to Day 14 (r = 0.6, p < 0.0001) and Day 28 (r = 0.2, p = 0.0015) and the haematocrit on Day 28 (r = 0.12, p = 0.00197).	RESULTS
Platelet count showed no correlation with temperature, parasite density and leucocyte count.	RESULTS
Haematocrit correlated with age (r = 0.4, p < 0.0001); but not with parasite density or temperature.	RESULTS
Leucocyte count showed no correlation with age or parasite density.	RESULTS
While thrombocytopenia was the most common haematological finding and may be of diagnostic importance, anaemia and leucocytosis were more common in the under fives.	CONCLUSIONS

To compare expectations for cancer survivorship care between patients and their physicians and between primary care providers (PCPs) and oncologists.	OBJECTIVE
Survivors and their physicians were surveyed to evaluate for expectations regarding physician participation in primary cancer follow-up, screening for other cancers, general preventive health, and management of comorbidities.	METHODS
Of 992 eligible survivors and 607 physicians surveyed, 535 (54%) and 378 (62%) were assessable, respectively.	RESULTS
Among physician respondents, 255 (67%) were PCPs and 123 (33%) were oncologists.	RESULTS
Comparing patients with their oncologists, expectations were highly discrepant for screening for cancers other than the index one (agreement rate, 29%), with patients anticipating significantly more oncologist involvement.	RESULTS
Between patients and their PCPs, expectations were most incongruent for primary cancer follow-up (agreement rate, 35%), with PCPs indicating they should contribute a much greater part to this aspect of care.	RESULTS
Expectations between patients and their PCPs were generally more concordant than between patients and their oncologists.	RESULTS
PCPs and oncologists showed high discordances in perceptions of their own roles for primary cancer follow-up, cancer screening, and general preventive health (agreement rates of 3%, 44%, and 51%, respectively).	RESULTS
In the case of primary cancer follow-up, both PCPs and oncologists indicated they should carry substantial responsibility for this task.	RESULTS
Patients and physicians have discordant expectations with respect to the roles of PCPs and oncologists in cancer survivorship care.	CONCLUSIONS
Uncertainties around physician roles and responsibilities can lead to deficiencies in care, supporting the need to make survivorship care planning a standard component in cancer management.	CONCLUSIONS

Although the red cell distribution width (RDW) has been reported as a reliable predictor of prognosis in several types of cancer, to our knowledge the prognostic value of RDW in gastric carcinoma has not been studied, so far.	BACKGROUND
We aimed to investigate the role of red cell distribution width (RDW) in predicting prognosis in gastric cancer patients.	OBJECTIVE
All gastric cancer patients who underwent curative surgery (n= 172, 110M/62F) over a five-year study period were evaluated.	METHODS
Data on demographics, preoperative RDW levels, tumor characteristics (early stage: I and II, advanced stage: IIIA-B-C), disease-free (DFS) and overall survival (OS) were retrospectively reviewed.	METHODS
Patients were classified as high RDW group (RDW ≥ 16, n= 62) or low RDW group (RDW < 16, n= 110).	METHODS
Overall mortality and postoperative 60-day mortality in both groups were 55% and 14%, respectively.	RESULTS
A borderline significant association between RDW (0.063) and mortality was noted.	RESULTS
Preoperative RDW levels were significantly higher in patients with short-term mortality (17.9 ± 4.3 vs. 16 ± 3.2, p= 0.015).	RESULTS
In high RDW group, the incidence of advanced gastric cancer was significantly higher (75 vs. 51%, p= 0.002), whereas DFS (0.035) and OS (p= 0.04) were lower.	RESULTS
The frequency of advanced cancer was high in patients with high RDWvalues.	CONCLUSIONS
High RDW values were strongly associated with short-term mortality although only a borderline relationship with overall survival was observed.	CONCLUSIONS

Analysis of fetal DNA in maternal plasma has recently been introduced as a new method for noninvasive prenatal diagnosis, particularly for the analysis of fetal genetic traits, which are absent from the maternal genome, e.g., RHD or Y-chromosome-specific sequences.	BACKGROUND
To date, the analysis of other fetal genetic traits has been more problematic because of the overwhelming presence of maternal DNA sequences in the circulation.	BACKGROUND
We examined whether different biochemical properties can be discerned between fetal and maternal circulatory DNA.	BACKGROUND
Plasma DNA was examined by agarose gel electrophoresis.	METHODS
The fractions of fetal and maternal DNA in size-fractionated fragments were assayed by real-time PCR.	METHODS
The determination of paternally and maternally inherited fetal genetic traits was examined by use of highly polymorphic chromosome-21-specific microsatellite markers.	METHODS
Size fractionation of circulatory DNA indicated that the major portion of cell-free fetal DNA had an approximate molecular size of <0.3 kb, whereas maternally derived sequences were, on average, considerably larger than 1 kb.	RESULTS
Analysis of size-fractionated DNA (</=0.3 kb) from maternal plasma samples facilitated the ready detection of paternally and maternally inherited microsatellite markers.	RESULTS
Circulatory fetal DNA can be enriched by size selection of fragment sizes less than approximately 0.3 kb.	CONCLUSIONS
Such selection permits easier analysis of both paternally and maternally inherited DNA polymorphisms.	CONCLUSIONS

Isotonic crystalloids play a central role in perioperative fluid management.	BACKGROUND
Isooncotic preparations of colloids (for example, human albumin or hydroxyethyl starch) remain nearly completely intravascular when infused to compensate for acute blood losses.	BACKGROUND
Recent data were interpreted to indicate a comparable intravascular volume effect for crystalloids, challenging the occasionally suggested advantage of using colloids to treat hypovolemia.	BACKGROUND
General physiological knowledge and clinical experience, however, suggest otherwise.	BACKGROUND
In a prospective study, double-tracer blood volume measurements were performed before and after intended normovolemic hemodilution in ten female adults, simultaneously substituting the three-fold amount of withdrawn blood with Ringer's lactate.	METHODS
Any originated deficits were substituted with half the volume of 20% human albumin, followed by a further assessment of blood volume.	METHODS
To assess significance between the measurements, repeated measures analysis of variance (ANOVA) according to Fisher were performed.	METHODS
If significant results were shown, paired t tests (according to Student) for the singular measurements were taken.	METHODS
P < 0.05 was considered to be significant.	METHODS
A total of 1,097 ± 285 ml of whole blood were withdrawn (641 ± 155 ml/m(2) body surface area) and simultaneously replaced by 3,430 ± 806 ml of Ringer's lactate.	RESULTS
All patients showed a significant decrease in blood volume after hemodilution (-459 ± 185 ml; P < 0.05) that did not involve relevant hemodynamical changes, and a significant increase in interstitial water content (+2,157 ± 606 ml; P < 0.05).	RESULTS
The volume effect of Ringer's lactate was 17 ± 10%.	RESULTS
The infusion of 245 ± 64 ml of 20% human albumin in this situation restored blood volume back to baseline values, the volume effect being 184 ± 63%.	RESULTS
Substitution of isolated intravascular deficits in cardiopulmonary healthy adults with the three-fold amount of Ringer's lactate impedes maintenance of intravascular normovolemia.	CONCLUSIONS
The main side effect was an impressive interstitial fluid accumulation, which was partly restored by the intravenous infusion of 20% human albumin.	CONCLUSIONS
We recommend to substitute the five-fold amount of crystalloids or to use an isooncotic preparation in the face of acute bleeding in patients where edema prevention might be advantageous.	CONCLUSIONS

The major sites of obstruction in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) are small airways (<2 mm in diameter).	BACKGROUND
We wanted to determine whether there was a relationship between small-airway obstruction and emphysematous destruction in COPD.	BACKGROUND
We used multidetector computed tomography (CT) to compare the number of airways measuring 2.0 to 2.5 mm in 78 patients who had various stages of COPD, as judged by scoring on the Global Initiative for Chronic Obstructive Lung Disease (GOLD) scale, in isolated lungs removed from patients with COPD who underwent lung transplantation, and in donor (control) lungs.	METHODS
MicroCT was used to measure the extent of emphysema (mean linear intercept), the number of terminal bronchioles per milliliter of lung volume, and the minimum diameters and cross-sectional areas of terminal bronchioles.	METHODS
On multidetector CT, in samples from patients with COPD, as compared with control samples, the number of airways measuring 2.0 to 2.5 mm in diameter was reduced in patients with GOLD stage 1 disease (P=0.001), GOLD stage 2 disease (P=0.02), and GOLD stage 3 or 4 disease (P<0.001).	RESULTS
MicroCT of isolated samples of lungs removed from patients with GOLD stage 4 disease showed a reduction of 81 to 99.7% in the total cross-sectional area of terminal bronchioles and a reduction of 72 to 89% in the number of terminal bronchioles (P<0.001).	RESULTS
A comparison of the number of terminal bronchioles and dimensions at different levels of emphysematous destruction (i.e., an increasing value for the mean linear intercept) showed that the narrowing and loss of terminal bronchioles preceded emphysematous destruction in COPD (P<0.001).	RESULTS
These results show that narrowing and disappearance of small conducting airways before the onset of emphysematous destruction can explain the increased peripheral airway resistance reported in COPD.	CONCLUSIONS
(Funded by the National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute and others.).	CONCLUSIONS

Glioblastomas are notorious for resistance to therapy, which has been attributed to DNA-repair proficiency, a multitude of deregulated molecular pathways, and, more recently, to the particular biologic behavior of tumor stem-like cells.	OBJECTIVE
Here, we aimed to identify molecular profiles specific for treatment resistance to the current standard of care of concomitant chemoradiotherapy with the alkylating agent temozolomide.	OBJECTIVE
Gene expression profiles of 80 glioblastomas were interrogated for associations with resistance to therapy.	METHODS
Patients were treated within clinical trials testing the addition of concomitant and adjuvant temozolomide to radiotherapy.	METHODS
An expression signature dominated by HOX genes, which comprises Prominin-1 (CD133), emerged as a predictor for poor survival in patients treated with concomitant chemoradiotherapy (n = 42; hazard ratio = 2.69; 95% CI, 1.38 to 5.26; P = .004).	RESULTS
This association could be validated in an independent data set.	RESULTS
Provocatively, the HOX cluster was reminiscent of a "self-renewal" signature (P = .008; Gene Set Enrichment Analysis) recently characterized in a mouse leukemia model.	RESULTS
The HOX signature and EGFR expression were independent prognostic factors in multivariate analysis, adjusted for the O-6-methylguanine-DNA methyltransferase (MGMT) methylation status, a known predictive factor for benefit from temozolomide, and age.	RESULTS
Better outcome was associated with gene clusters characterizing features of tumor-host interaction including tumor vascularization and cell adhesion, and innate immune response.	RESULTS
This study provides first clinical evidence for the implication of a "glioma stem cell" or "self-renewal" phenotype in treatment resistance of glioblastoma.	CONCLUSIONS
Biologic mechanisms identified here to be relevant for resistance will guide future targeted therapies and respective marker development for individualized treatment and patient selection.	CONCLUSIONS

To evaluate long-term prognostic effect of serum noncholesterol sterols, including plant sterols, in middle-aged men with high cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk, without statins at baseline.	OBJECTIVE
This was a prospective study of 232 men (mean age 60 years) at high risk of CVD in 1985-1986.	METHODS
Most were hypercholesterolemic, 29 (12%) had a history of CVD or cancer, 6 (3%) had diabetes, and 46 (20%) had metabolic syndrome (MS).	METHODS
Measured noncholesterol sterols (expressed as absolute concentrations or ratios to serum cholesterol to standardize for cholesterol concentrations) included lathosterol and desmosterol (reflect cholesterol synthesis), and plant sterols (campesterol and sitosterol) and cholestanol (reflect cholesterol absorption).	METHODS
Main outcome measure was total mortality.	METHODS
At baseline, markers of cholesterol synthesis and absorption showed expected inverse associations.	RESULTS
During the 22-year follow-up 101 men (43%) died.	RESULTS
At baseline, nonsurvivors smoked more, exercised less and had more components of MS (although not filling strict criteria), whereas traditional risk factors of CVD were not significantly different.	RESULTS
Of the noncholesterol sterols (either absolute or ratio), only sitosterol was significantly higher in survivors than in nonsurvivors (P=0.02).	RESULTS
In multivariable analyses, highest sitosterol-to-cholesterol tertile was associated with significantly lower mortality risk (HR 0.51, 95% CI 0.30-0.87) as compared to lowest tertile.	RESULTS
Other associations were nonsignificant, although a "global" index of cholesterol metabolism (desmosterol-to-sitosterol ratio) suggested higher cholesterol synthesis and lower absorption to be associated with higher total and CVD mortality.	RESULTS
Higher serum plant sterol levels in middle-aged men predicted lower long-term mortality risk, possibly reflecting an association between higher synthesis/lower absorption of cholesterol and mortality.	CONCLUSIONS

Long non-coding RNAs (lncRNAs) are a sub-class within non-coding RNA repertoire that have emerged as crucial regulators of the gene expression in various pathophysiological conditions.	BACKGROUND
lncRNAs display remarkable versatility and wield their functions through interactions with RNA, DNA, or proteins.	BACKGROUND
Accumulating body of evidence based on multitude studies has highlighted the role of lncRNAs in many autoimmune and inflammatory diseases, including type 1 diabetes (T1D).	BACKGROUND
This review highlights emerging roles of lncRNAs in immune and islet β cell function as well as some of the challenges and opportunities in understanding the pathogenesis of T1D and its complications.	BACKGROUND
We accentuate that the lncRNAs within T1D-loci regions in consort with regulatory variants and enhancer clusters orchestrate the chromatin remodeling in β cells and thereby act as cis/trans-regulatory determinants of islet cell transcriptional programs.	CONCLUSIONS

Radio Frequency Identification (RFID) devices are becoming more and more essential for patient safety in hospitals.	BACKGROUND
The purpose of this study was to determine patient safety, data reliability and signal loss wearing on skin RFID devices during magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and computed tomography (CT) scanning.	BACKGROUND
Sixty RFID tags of the type I-Code SLI, 13.56 MHz, ISO 18000-3.1 were tested: Thirty type 1, an RFID tag with a 76 x 45 mm aluminum-etched antenna and 30 type 2, a tag with a 31 x 14 mm copper-etched antenna.	METHODS
The signal loss, material movement and heat tests were performed in a 1.5 T and a 3 T MR system.	METHODS
For data integrity, the tags were tested additionally during CT scanning.	METHODS
Standardized function tests were performed with all transponders before and after all imaging studies.	METHODS
There was no memory loss or data alteration in the RFID tags after MRI and CT scanning.	RESULTS
Concerning heating (a maximum of 3.6 degrees C) and device movement (below 1 N/kg) no relevant influence was found.	RESULTS
Concerning signal loss (artifacts 2 - 4 mm), interpretability of MR images was impaired when superficial structures such as skin, subcutaneous tissues or tendons were assessed.	RESULTS
Patients wearing RFID wristbands are safe in 1.5 T and 3 T MR scanners using normal operation mode for RF-field.	CONCLUSIONS
The findings are specific to the RFID tags that underwent testing.	CONCLUSIONS

The effects of Plasmodium falciparum on B-cell homeostasis have not been well characterized.	BACKGROUND
This study investigated whether an episode of acute malaria in young children results in changes in the peripheral B cell phenotype.	BACKGROUND
Using flow-cytofluorimetric analysis, the B cell phenotypes found in the peripheral blood of children aged 2-5 years were characterized during an episode of acute uncomplicated clinical malaria and four weeks post-recovery and in healthy age-matched controls.	METHODS
There was a significant decrease in CD19+ B lymphocytes during acute malaria.	RESULTS
Characterization of the CD19+ B cell subsets in the peripheral blood based on expression of IgD and CD38 revealed a significant decrease in the numbers of naive 1 CD38-IgD+ B cells while there was an increase in CD38+IgD- memory 3 B cells during acute malaria.	RESULTS
Further analysis of the peripheral B cell phenotype also identified an expansion of transitional CD10+CD19+ B cells in children following an episode of acute malaria with up to 25% of total CD19+ B cell pool residing in this subset.	RESULTS
Children experiencing an episode of acute uncomplicated clinical malaria experienced profound disturbances in B cell homeostasis.	CONCLUSIONS

Sugar-sweetened beverages like soft drinks and fruit punches contain large amounts of readily absorbable sugars and may contribute to weight gain and an increased risk of type 2 diabetes, but these relationships have been minimally addressed in adults.	BACKGROUND
To examine the association between consumption of sugar-sweetened beverages and weight change and risk of type 2 diabetes in women.	OBJECTIVE
DESIGN, SETTING, AND PARTICIPANTS Prospective cohort analyses conducted from 1991 to 1999 among women in the Nurses' Health Study II.	OBJECTIVE
The diabetes analysis included 91,249 women free of diabetes and other major chronic diseases at baseline in 1991.	OBJECTIVE
The weight change analysis included 51,603 women for whom complete dietary information and body weight were ascertained in 1991, 1995, and 1999.	OBJECTIVE
We identified 741 incident cases of confirmed type 2 diabetes during 716,300 person-years of follow-up.	OBJECTIVE
Weight gain and incidence of type 2 diabetes.	METHODS
Those with stable consumption patterns had no difference in weight gain, but weight gain over a 4-year period was highest among women who increased their sugar-sweetened soft drink consumption from 1 or fewer drinks per week to 1 or more drinks per day (multivariate-adjusted means, 4.69 kg for 1991 to 1995 and 4.20 kg for 1995 to 1999) and was smallest among women who decreased their intake (1.34 and 0.15 kg for the 2 periods, respectively) after adjusting for lifestyle and dietary confounders.	RESULTS
Increased consumption of fruit punch was also associated with greater weight gain compared with decreased consumption.	RESULTS
After adjustment for potential confounders, women consuming 1 or more sugar-sweetened soft drinks per day had a relative risk [RR] of type 2 diabetes of 1.83 (95% confidence interval [CI], 1.42-2.36; P<.001 for trend) compared with those who consumed less than 1 of these beverages per month.	RESULTS
Similarly, consumption of fruit punch was associated with increased diabetes risk (RR for > or =1 drink per day compared with <1 drink per month, 2.00; 95% CI, 1.33-3.03; P =.001).	RESULTS
Higher consumption of sugar-sweetened beverages is associated with a greater magnitude of weight gain and an increased risk for development of type 2 diabetes in women, possibly by providing excessive calories and large amounts of rapidly absorbable sugars.	CONCLUSIONS

To determine if preoperative statin treatment is associated with a reduction in systemic inflammatory response (SIR) and myocardial damage markers following cardiac surgery with cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB).	OBJECTIVE
We study a prospective cohort of 138 patients who underwent coronary and valvular surgery with CPB.	METHODS
We differentiate two study groups: patients with (group A, n=72) or without (group B, n=66) statins.	METHODS
Plasma levels of pro-inflammatory interleukins (tumour necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-alpha), interleukin (IL)-6, IL-8 and IL-2R), creatine phosphokinase (CPK), CPK-MB and troponin I were measured before and 1, 6, 24 and >72 h after surgery.	METHODS
The baseline, operative and postoperative morbidity and mortality characteristics were similar for both the groups.	RESULTS
Group A had significantly lower postoperative levels of IL-6 than group B at 6h (68.8+/-5 pg ml(-1) vs 108.9+/-108 pg ml(-1), p=0.01), 24h (71.7+/-7 pg ml(-1) vs 110.4+/-106 pg ml(-1), p=0.01) and before hospital discharge (21.6+/-12 pg ml(-1) vs 32.8+/-27 pg ml(-1), p=0.005), as well as significantly lower average IL-6 levels in the first 24h following surgery (71.8+/-5 pgml(-1) vs 112.8+/-82 pg ml(-1), p=0.002).	RESULTS
The postoperative CPK-MB at 24h (19.7+/-23 ng ml(-1) vs 33.1+/-32 ng ml(-1), p=0.02) and troponin I levels at the end of the intervention (2.2+/-2.2 ng ml(-1) vs 3.3+/-3.1 ng ml(-1), p=0.03) and at 24h (4.1+/-3.5 ng ml(-1) vs 6.6+/-8 ng ml(-1), p=0.04) were also significantly lower in the group treated with statins prior to surgery.	RESULTS
Preoperative treatment with statins is associated with a lower biochemical parameters of SIR and myocardial damage following cardiac surgery with CPB, regardless of it being coronary bypass grafting (CABG) or valvular surgery.	CONCLUSIONS

& AIMS Treatment of chronic hepatitis B with interferon alfa is not approved in children.	BACKGROUND
The aim of this study was to evaluate the safety and efficacy of interferon alfa (IFN-alpha) in children with chronic hepatitis B and increased transaminase levels.	BACKGROUND
Children were given either IFN-alpha2b (6 megaunits/m2 thrice weekly for 24 weeks) or no treatment.	METHODS
Clearance of markers of viral replication was evaluated 24 weeks after therapy and after 48 weeks of observation in controls.	METHODS
Of 149 children enrolled, 144 were evaluable (70 treated and 74 controls).	RESULTS
Serum hepatitis B e antigen and viral DNA became negative in 26% of treated children and 11% of controls (P < 0.05).	RESULTS
Serum aminotransferase levels normalized and liver histology improved among responders.	RESULTS
Hepatitis B surface antigen became undetectable in 10% of treated patients and 1% of controls.	RESULTS
Female gender and interferon treatment were the only significant predictors of response.	RESULTS
Ethnic origin, baseline aminotransferase level, initial DNA levels, and histology did not correlate with response.	RESULTS
Most adverse reactions were mild or moderate, and dose was reduced in 24% of children.	RESULTS
In children with chronic hepatitis B, INF-alpha promotes loss of viral replication markers and surface antigen and improves aminotransferases and histology.	CONCLUSIONS

Advances made in the past ten years highlight the notion that peroxisome proliferator-activated receptors gamma (PPARγ) has protective properties in the pathophysiology of osteoarthritis (OA).	OBJECTIVE
The aim of this study was to define the roles of PPARγ in AGEs-induced inflammatory response in human chondrocytes.	OBJECTIVE
Primary human chondrocytes were stimulated with AGEs in the presence or absence of neutralizing antibody against RAGE (anti-RAGE), MAPK specific inhibitors and PPARγ agonist pioglitazone.	METHODS
The expression of IL-1, MMP-13, TNF-α, PPARγ, nuclear NF-κB p65 and cytosol IκBα was determined by western blotting and real-time PCR.	METHODS
AGEs could enhance the expression of IL-1, TNF-α, and MMP-13, but the level of PPARγ was decreased in a time- and dose-dependent manner, which was inhibited by anti-RAGE, SB203580 (P38 MAPK specific inhibitor) and SP600125 (a selective inhibitor of JNK).	RESULTS
PPARγ agonist pioglitazone could inhibit the effects of AGEs-induced inflammatory response and PPARγ down-regulation.	RESULTS
In human chondrocytes, AGEs could induce cytosol IκBα degradation and increase the level of nuclear NF-κB p65, which was inhibited by PPARγ agonist pioglitazone.	RESULTS
In primary human chondrocytes, AGEs could down-regulate PPARγ expression and increase the inflammatory mediators, which could be reversed by PPARγ agonist pioglitazone.	CONCLUSIONS
Activation of RAGE by AGEs triggers a cascade of downstream signaling, including MAPK JNK/ p38, PPARγ and NF-κB. Taken together, PPARγ could be a potential target for pharmacologic intervention in the treatment of OA.	CONCLUSIONS

Taxing sugar-sweetened beverages (SSBs) has been proposed in high-income countries to reduce obesity and type 2 diabetes.	BACKGROUND
We sought to estimate the potential health effects of such a fiscal strategy in the middle-income country of India, where there is heterogeneity in SSB consumption, patterns of substitution between SSBs and other beverages after tax increases, and vast differences in chronic disease risk within the population.	BACKGROUND
Using consumption and price variations data from a nationally representative survey of 100,855 Indian households, we first calculated how changes in SSB price alter per capita consumption of SSBs and substitution with other beverages.	METHODS
We then incorporated SSB sales trends, body mass index (BMI), and diabetes incidence data stratified by age, sex, income, and urban/rural residence into a validated microsimulation of caloric consumption, glycemic load, overweight/obesity prevalence, and type 2 diabetes incidence among Indian subpopulations facing a 20% SSB excise tax.	METHODS
The 20% SSB tax was anticipated to reduce overweight and obesity prevalence by 3.0% (95% CI 1.6%-5.9%) and type 2 diabetes incidence by 1.6% (95% CI 1.2%-1.9%) among various Indian subpopulations over the period 2014-2023, if SSB consumption continued to increase linearly in accordance with secular trends.	RESULTS
However, acceleration in SSB consumption trends consistent with industry marketing models would be expected to increase the impact efficacy of taxation, averting 4.2% of prevalent overweight/obesity (95% CI 2.5-10.0%) and 2.5% (95% CI 1.0-2.8%) of incident type 2 diabetes from 2014-2023.	RESULTS
Given current consumption and BMI distributions, our results suggest the largest relative effect would be expected among young rural men, refuting our a priori hypothesis that urban populations would be isolated beneficiaries of SSB taxation.	RESULTS
Key limitations of this estimation approach include the assumption that consumer expenditure behavior from prior years, captured in price elasticities, will reflect future behavior among consumers, and potential underreporting of consumption in dietary recall data used to inform our calculations.	RESULTS
Sustained SSB taxation at a high tax rate could mitigate rising obesity and type 2 diabetes in India among both urban and rural subpopulations.	CONCLUSIONS

The CpG island methylator phenotype (CIMP) may be associated with development of malignancy through coordinated inactivation of tumor suppressor and tumor-related genes (TRG) and methylation of multiple noncoding, methylated-in-tumor (MINT) loci.	OBJECTIVE
These epigenetic changes create a distinct CIMP pattern that has been linked to recurrence and survival in gastrointestinal cancers.	OBJECTIVE
Because epigenetic inactivation of TRGs also has been shown in malignant melanoma, we hypothesized the existence of a clinically significant CIMP in cutaneous melanoma progression.	OBJECTIVE
The methylation status of the CpG island promoter region of TRGs related to melanoma pathophysiology (WIF1, TFPI2, RASSF1A, RARbeta2, SOCS1, and GATA4) and a panel of MINT loci (MINT1, MINT2, MINT3, MINT12, MINT17, MINT25, and MINT31) in primary and metastatic tumors of different clinical stages (n=122) was assessed.	METHODS
Here, we show an increase in hypermethylation of the TRGs WIF1, TFPI2, RASSF1A, and SOCS1 with advancing clinical tumor stage.	RESULTS
Furthermore, we find a significant positive association between the methylation status of MINT17, MINT31, and TRGs.	RESULTS
The methylation status of MINT31 is associated with disease outcome in stage III melanoma.	RESULTS
These findings show the significance of a CIMP pattern that is associated with advancing clinical stage of malignant melanoma.	CONCLUSIONS
Future prospective large-scale studies may determine if CIMP-positive primary melanomas are at high risk of metastasis or recurrence.	CONCLUSIONS

We have previously identified solute-linked carrier family A1 member 5 (SLC1A5) as an overexpressed protein in a shotgun proteomic analysis of stage I non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) when compared with matched controls.	OBJECTIVE
We hypothesized that overexpression of SLC1A5 occurs to meet the metabolic demand for lung cancer cell growth and survival.	OBJECTIVE
To test our hypothesis, we first analyzed the protein expression of SLC1A5 in archival lung cancer tissues by immunohistochemistry and immunoblotting (N = 98) and in cell lines (N = 36).	METHODS
To examine SLC1A5 involvement in amino acid transportation, we conducted kinetic analysis of l-glutamine (Gln) uptake in lung cancer cell lines in the presence and absence of a pharmacologic inhibitor of SLC1A5, gamma-l-Glutamyl-p-Nitroanilide (GPNA).	METHODS
Finally, we examined the effect of Gln deprivation and uptake inhibition on cell growth, cell-cycle progression, and growth signaling pathways of five lung cancer cell lines.	METHODS
Our results show that (i) SLC1A5 protein is expressed in 95% of squamous cell carcinomas (SCC), 74% of adenocarcinomas (ADC), and 50% of neuroendocrine tumors; (ii) SLC1A5 is located at the cytoplasmic membrane and is significantly associated with SCC histology and male gender; (iii) 68% of Gln is transported in a Na(+)-dependent manner, 50% of which is attributed to SLC1A5 activity; and (iv) pharmacologic and genetic targeting of SLC1A5 decreased cell growth and viability in lung cancer cells, an effect mediated in part by mTOR signaling.	RESULTS
These results suggest that SLC1A5 plays a key role in Gln transport controlling lung cancer cells' metabolism, growth, and survival.	CONCLUSIONS

Tuberculosis (TB) has been reported to be associated with poverty, especially in developing countries.	BACKGROUND
Hong Kong is one of the few industrialised areas with a high incidence of TB where previous reports on the effect of poverty at neighbourhood level have been conflicting.	BACKGROUND
To examine the spatial distribution of TB and its association with neighbourhood risk factors.	OBJECTIVE
A total of 17 294 TB cases notified from 2005 to 2007 were mapped down to the District Council Constituency Area (DCCA) level, and were indirectly standardised by age and sex using 2006 census population data.	METHODS
The standardised TB ratio was correlated with neighbourhood risk factors classified by family, ethnicity, economic and environmental domains.	METHODS
The indirect age- and sex-standardised ratio demonstrated a spatially varied pattern, and was significantly associated with all neighbourhood factors on univariate analysis.	RESULTS
Only marital status, place of birth and low household income were independently associated with the standardised TB ratio on multivariate analysis.	RESULTS
Despite the virtual elimination of absolute poverty by a well-developed social assistance scheme, low household income in the neighbourhood was significantly associated with TB, independently of place of birth, marital status and other risk factors.	CONCLUSIONS

Emergency postcoital contraception prevents pregnancy, but it must be prescribed by a doctor and taken within 72 hours of intercourse.	BACKGROUND
It has been proposed that emergency contraception be made available without a prescription.	BACKGROUND
We undertook a study to learn how women might behave if given a supply of emergency contraceptive pills to keep at home.	BACKGROUND
We assigned 553 women to be given a replaceable supply of hormonal emergency contraceptive pills to take home (the treatment group) and 530 women to use emergency contraception obtained by visiting a doctor (the control group).	METHODS
The frequency of use of emergency contraception, the use of other contraceptives, and the incidence of unwanted pregnancy were determined in both groups of women one year later.	METHODS
The results for 549 women in the treatment group and 522 women in the control group were available for analysis.	RESULTS
Three hundred seventy-nine of the women in the treatment group (69 percent) and 326 of the women in the control group (62 percent) contributed detailed information at follow-up.	RESULTS
One hundred eighty of the women in the treatment group (47 percent) used emergency contraception at least once.	RESULTS
Among those who returned the study questionnaire, 98 percent used emergency contraception correctly.	RESULTS
There were no serious adverse effects.	RESULTS
Eighty-seven women in the control group (27 percent) used emergency contraception at least once (P<0.001 for the comparison with the treatment group).	RESULTS
The women in the treatment group were not more likely to use emergency contraception repeatedly.	RESULTS
Their use of other methods of contraception was no different from that of the women in the control group.	RESULTS
There were 18 unintended pregnancies in the treatment group and 25 in the control group (relative risk, 0.7; 95 percent confidence interval, 0.4 to 1.2).	RESULTS
Making emergency contraception more easily obtainable does no harm and may reduce the rate of unwanted pregnancies.	CONCLUSIONS

BACKGROUND/AIMS The small GTPase of Ras and Rho families are widely involved in human tumorgenesis and metastasis.	TRIAL REGISTRATION
It has recently been reported that pamidronate inhibits the mevalonate pathway, which is required for the prenylation of the small GTPase.	TRIAL REGISTRATION
We demonstrated a possible beneficial use of pamidronate in the treatment of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC).	TRIAL REGISTRATION
The effect of pamidronate on cell proliferation was analyzed with five hepatoma cell lines using MTT assay.	METHODS
Apoptosis was evaluated by staining with DAPI and a histon ELISA assay.	METHODS
A cell migration assay was performed using the Modified Boyden Chamber.	METHODS
To analyze anti-proliferation effect of pamidronate in vivo, tumor volumes were monitored with the intraperitoneal injection of pamidronate after subcutaneous inoculation of PLC/PRF/5 cells into nude mice.	METHODS
Pamidronate inhibited cell growth for all hepatoma cell lines.	RESULTS
The amount of membrane associated Ras and phosphorylated extracellular signal-regulated kinase 2 (ERK 2) were reduced after pamidronate treatment.	RESULTS
Pamidronate increased apoptosis and cleavage of Caspase-3, and -9.	RESULTS
Pamidronate suppressed membrane associated RhoA and cell motility.	RESULTS
In vivo, tumor volumes were significantly suppressed by pamidronate at three weeks (P<0.03).	RESULTS
We conclude that pamidronate has therapeutic potential in inducing anti-proliferative, apoptotic, and anti-migratory effects in HCC.	CONCLUSIONS

Raised concentrations of nitrate and nitrite have been found in exhaled breath condensate (EBC) in airway disease, and it has been postulated that this reflects increased nitric oxide (NO) metabolism.	BACKGROUND
However, the chemical and anatomical origin of nitrate and nitrite in the airways has not yet been sufficiently studied.	BACKGROUND
The fraction of exhaled NO at an exhalation flow rate of 50 ml/s (FE(NO)) and nitrite and nitrate in EBC, nasal condensate, and saliva were measured in 17 tracheostomised and 15 non-tracheostomised subjects, all of whom were non-smokers without respiratory disease.	METHODS
Tracheal and oral samples were taken from the tracheostomised subjects and nasal (during velum closure) and oral samples from the non-tracheostomised subjects.	METHODS
Measurements were performed before and after sodium nitrate ingestion (10 mg/kg) and use of antibacterial mouthwash (chlorhexidine 0.2%).	METHODS
In tracheostomised subjects oral FE(NO) increased by 90% (p<0.01) while tracheal FE(NO) was not affected 60 minutes after nitrate ingestion.	RESULTS
Oral EBC nitrite levels were increased 23-fold at 60 minutes (p<0.001) whereas the nitrite levels in tracheal EBC showed only a minor increase (fourfold, p<0.05).	RESULTS
Nitrate was increased the same amount in oral and tracheal EBC at 60 minutes (2.5-fold, p<0.05).	RESULTS
In non-tracheostomised subjects oral FE(NO) and EBC nitrite increased after nitrate ingestion and after chlorhexidine mouthwash they approached baseline levels again (p<0.001).	RESULTS
Nasal NO, nitrate, and nitrite were not affected by nitrate intake or mouthwash.	RESULTS
At baseline, mouthwash with deionised water did not affect nitrite in oral EBC or saliva, whereas significant reductions were seen after antibacterial mouthwash (p<0.05 and p<0.001, respectively).	RESULTS
Besides the salivary glands, plasma nitrate is taken up by the lower airways but not the nasal airways.	CONCLUSIONS
Nitrate levels in EBC are thus influenced by dietary intake.	CONCLUSIONS
Nitrate is reduced to nitrite by bacterial activity which takes place primarily in the oropharyngeal tract of healthy subjects.	CONCLUSIONS
Only oropharyngeal nitrite seems to contribute to exhaled NO in non-inflamed airways, and there is also a substantial contribution of nitrite from the oropharyngeal tract during standard collection of EBC.	CONCLUSIONS

In the year 2000, the organizational structure of the ICU in the Zaandam Medical Centre (ZMC) changed from an open to a closed format ICU.	BACKGROUND
The objective of this study was to evaluate the effect of this organizational change on outcome in high risk surgical patients.	BACKGROUND
The medical records of all consecutive high risk surgical patients admitted to the ICU from 1996 to 1998 (open format) and from 2003 to 2005 (closed format), were reviewed.	METHODS
High-risk patients were defined according to the Identification of Risk in Surgical patients (IRIS) score.	METHODS
Parameters studied were: mortality, morbidity, ICU length of stay (LOS) and hospital LOS.	METHODS
Mortality of ICU patients was 25.7% in the open format group and 15.8% in the closed format group (p = 0.01).	RESULTS
Morbidity decreased from 48.6% to 46.1% (p = 0.6).	RESULTS
The average length of hospital stay was 17 days in the open format group, and 21 days in the closed format group (p = 0.03).	RESULTS
High risk surgical patients in the ICU are patients that have undergone complex and often extensive surgery.	CONCLUSIONS
These patients are in need of specialized treatment and careful monitoring for maximum safety and optimal care.	CONCLUSIONS
Our results suggest that closed format is a more favourable setting than open format to minimize the effects of high risk surgery, and to warrant safe outcome in this patient group.	CONCLUSIONS

Kulldorff's spatial scan statistic and its software implementation - SaTScan - are widely used for detecting and evaluating geographic clusters.	BACKGROUND
However, two issues make using the method and interpreting its results non-trivial: (1) the method lacks cartographic support for understanding the clusters in geographic context and (2) results from the method are sensitive to parameter choices related to cluster scaling (abbreviated as scaling parameters), but the system provides no direct support for making these choices.	BACKGROUND
We employ both established and novel geovisual analytics methods to address these issues and to enhance the interpretation of SaTScan results.	BACKGROUND
We demonstrate our geovisual analytics approach in a case study analysis of cervical cancer mortality in the U.S.   RESULTS We address the first issue by providing an interactive visual interface to support the interpretation of SaTScan results.	BACKGROUND
Our research to address the second issue prompted a broader discussion about the sensitivity of SaTScan results to parameter choices.	BACKGROUND
Sensitivity has two components: (1) the method can identify clusters that, while being statistically significant, have heterogeneous contents comprised of both high-risk and low-risk locations and (2) the method can identify clusters that are unstable in location and size as the spatial scan scaling parameter is varied.	BACKGROUND
To investigate cluster result stability, we conducted multiple SaTScan runs with systematically selected parameters.	BACKGROUND
The results, when scanning a large spatial dataset (e.g., U.S. data aggregated by county), demonstrate that no single spatial scan scaling value is known to be optimal to identify clusters that exist at different scales; instead, multiple scans that vary the parameters are necessary.	BACKGROUND
We introduce a novel method of measuring and visualizing reliability that facilitates identification of homogeneous clusters that are stable across analysis scales.	BACKGROUND
Finally, we propose a logical approach to proceed through the analysis of SaTScan results.	BACKGROUND
The geovisual analytics approach described in this manuscript facilitates the interpretation of spatial cluster detection methods by providing cartographic representation of SaTScan results and by providing visualization methods and tools that support selection of SaTScan parameters.	CONCLUSIONS
Our methods distinguish between heterogeneous and homogeneous clusters and assess the stability of clusters across analytic scales.	CONCLUSIONS
We analyzed the cervical cancer mortality data for the United States aggregated by county between 2000 and 2004.	METHODS
We ran SaTScan on the dataset fifty times with different parameter choices.	METHODS
Our geovisual analytics approach couples SaTScan with our visual analytic platform, allowing users to interactively explore and compare SaTScan results produced by different parameter choices.	METHODS
The Standardized Mortality Ratio and reliability scores are visualized for all the counties to identify stable, homogeneous clusters.	METHODS
We evaluated our analysis result by comparing it to that produced by other independent techniques including the Empirical Bayes Smoothing and Kafadar spatial smoother methods.	METHODS
The geovisual analytics approach introduced here is developed and implemented in our Java-based Visual Inquiry Toolkit.	METHODS

Early childhood introduction of nutritional habits aimed at atherosclerosis prevention is compatible with normal growth, but its effect on neurological development is unknown.	BACKGROUND
To analyze how parental counseling aimed at keeping children's diets low in saturated fat and cholesterol influences neurodevelopment during the first 5 years of life.	OBJECTIVE
Randomized controlled trial conducted between February 1990 and November 1996.	METHODS
Outpatient clinic of a university department in Turku, Finland.	METHODS
A total of 1062 seven-month-old infants and their parents, recruited at well-baby clinics between 1990 and 1992.	METHODS
At age 5 years, 496 children still living in the city of Turku were available to participate in neurodevelopmental testing.	METHODS
Participants were randomly assigned to receive individualized counseling aimed at limiting the child's fat intake to 30% to 35% of daily energy, with a saturated:monounsaturated:polyunsaturated fatty acid ratio of 1:1:1 and a cholesterol intake of less than 200 mg/d (n = 540) or usual health education (control group, n = 522).	METHODS
Nutrient intake, serum lipid concentrations, and neurological development at 5 years, among children in the intervention vs control groups.	METHODS
Absolute and relative intakes of fat, saturated fatty acids, and cholesterol among children in the intervention group were markedly less than the respective values of control children.	RESULTS
Mean (SD) percentages of daily energy at age 5 years for the intervention vs control groups were as follows: for total fat, 30.6% (4.5%) vs 33.4% (4.4%) (P<. 001); and for saturated fat, 11.7% (2.3%) vs 14.5% (2.4%) (P<.001).	RESULTS
Mean intakes of cholesterol were 164.2 mg (60.1 mg) and 192.5 mg (71. 9 mg) (P<.001) for the intervention and control groups, respectively.	RESULTS
Serum cholesterol concentrations were continuously 3% to 5% lower in children in the intervention group than in children in the control group.	RESULTS
At age 5 years, mean (SD) serum cholesterol concentration of the intervention group was 4.27 (0.63) mmol/L (165 [24] mg/dL) and of the control group, 4.41 (0.74) mmol/L (170 [29] mg/dL) (P =.04).	RESULTS
Neurological development of children in the intervention group was at least as good as that of children in the control group.	RESULTS
Relative risks for children in the intervention group to fail tests of speech and language skills, gross motor functioning plus perception, and visual motor skills were 0.95 (90% confidence interval [CI], 0.60-1.49), 0.95 (90% CI, 0.58-1.55), and 0.65 (90% CI, 0.39-1.08), respectively (P =.85,.86, and.16, respectively, vs control children).	RESULTS
Our data indicate that repeated child-targeted dietary counseling of parents during the first 5 years of a child's life lessens age-associated increases in children's serum cholesterol and is compatible with normal neurological development.	CONCLUSIONS
JAMA.	CONCLUSIONS
2000;284:993-1000	CONCLUSIONS

Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a disease of the central nervous system with marked heterogeneity in several aspects including pathological processes.	OBJECTIVE
Based on infiltrating immune cells, deposition of humoral factors and loss of oligodendrocytes and/or myelin proteins, four lesion patterns have been described.	OBJECTIVE
Pattern II is characterized by antibody and complement deposition in addition to T-cell infiltration.	OBJECTIVE
MS is considered a T-cell-mediated disease, but until now the study of pathogenic T cells has encountered major challenges, most importantly the limited access of brain-infiltrating T cells.	OBJECTIVE
Our objective was to identify, isolate, and characterize brain-infiltrating clonally expanded T cells in pattern II MS lesions.	OBJECTIVE
We used next-generation sequencing to identify clonally expanded T cells in demyelinating pattern II brain autopsy lesions, subsequently isolated these as T-cell clones from autologous cerebrospinal fluid and functionally characterized them.	METHODS
We identified clonally expanded CD8(+) but also CD4(+) T cells in demyelinating pattern II lesions and for the first time were able to isolate these as live T-cell clones.	RESULTS
The functional characterization shows that T cells releasing Th2 cytokines and able to provide B cell help dominate the T-cell infiltrate in pattern II brain lesions.	RESULTS
Our data provide the first functional evidence for a putative role of Th2/Tc2 cells in pattern II MS supporting the existence of this pathogenic phenotype and questioning the protective role that is generally ascribed to Th2 cells.	CONCLUSIONS
Our observations are important to consider for future treatments of pattern II MS patients.	CONCLUSIONS

A primary cause of high maternal mortality in Bangladesh is lack of access to professional delivery care.	BACKGROUND
Examining the role of the family, particularly the husband, during pregnancy and childbirth is important to understanding women's access to and utilization of professional maternal health services that can prevent maternal mortality.	BACKGROUND
This qualitative study examines husbands' involvement during childbirth and professional delivery care utilization in a rural sub-district of Netrokona district, Bangladesh.	BACKGROUND
Using purposive sampling, ten households utilizing a skilled attendant during the birth of the youngest child were selected and matched with ten households utilizing an untrained traditional birth attendant, or dhatri.	METHODS
Households were selected based on a set of inclusion criteria, such as approximate household income, ethnicity, and distance to the nearest hospital.	METHODS
Twenty semi-structured interviews were conducted in Bangla with husbands in these households in June 2010.	METHODS
Interviews were transcribed, translated into English, and analyzed using NVivo 9.0.	METHODS
By purposefully selecting households that differed on the type of provider utilized during delivery, common themes--high costs, poor transportation, and long distances to health facilities--were eliminated as sufficient barriers to the utilization of professional delivery care.	RESULTS
Divergent themes, namely husbands' social support and perceived social norms, were identified as underlying factors associated with delivery care utilization.	RESULTS
We found that husbands whose wives utilized professional delivery care provided emotional, instrumental and informational support to their wives during delivery and believed that medical intervention was necessary.	RESULTS
By contrast, husbands whose wives utilized an untrained dhatri at home were uninvolved during delivery and believed childbirth should take place at home according to local traditions.	RESULTS
This study provides novel evidence about male involvement during childbirth in rural Bangladesh.	CONCLUSIONS
These findings have important implications for program planners, who should pursue culturally sensitive ways to involve husbands in maternal health interventions and assess the effectiveness of education strategies targeted at husbands.	CONCLUSIONS

Frail and dependent older people in resource-poor settings are poorly served by health systems that lack outreach capacity.	BACKGROUND
The COPE (Caring for Older PEople) multidimensional assessment tool is designed to help community health workers (CHWs) identify clinically significant impairments and deliver evidence-based interventions   METHODS Older people (n = 150) identified by CHWs as frail or dependent, were assessed at home by the CHW using the structured COPE assessment tool, generating information on impairments in nutrition, mobility, vision, hearing, continence, cognition, mood and behaviour.	BACKGROUND
The older people were reassessed by local physicians who reached a clinical judgment regarding the presence or absence of the same impairments based upon clinical examination guided by the EASY-Care assessment tool.	BACKGROUND
The COPE tool was considered easy to administer, and gave CHWs a sense of empowerment to understand and act upon the needs of older people.	RESULTS
Agreement between COPE assessment by CHW and clinician assessors was modest (ranged from 45.8 to 91.3 %) for most impairments.	RESULTS
However, the prevalence of impairments was generally higher according to clinicians, particularly for visual impairment (98.7 vs 45.8 %), cognitive impairment (78.4 vs. 38.2 %) and depression (82.0 vs. 59.9 %).	RESULTS
Most cases identified by WHO-COPE were clinician confirmed (positive predictive values - 72.2 to 98.5 %), and levels of disability and needs for care among those identified by COPE were higher than those additionally identified by the clinician alone.	RESULTS
The COPE is a feasible tool for the identification of specific impairments in frail dependent older people in the community.	CONCLUSIONS
Those identified are likely to be confirmed as having clinically relevant problems by clinicians working in the same service, and the COPE may be particularly effective at targeting attention upon those with the most substantial unmet needs.	CONCLUSIONS

More than 1.5 million US adults use stimulants and other medications labeled for treatment of attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD).	BACKGROUND
These agents can increase heart rate and blood pressure, raising concerns about their cardiovascular safety.	BACKGROUND
To examine whether current use of medications prescribed primarily to treat ADHD is associated with increased risk of serious cardiovascular events in young and middle-aged adults.	OBJECTIVE
