Prospective case series.	METHODS
Antenatal clinic of a large inner city maternity hospital.	METHODS
All women attending for their first antenatal clinic.	OBJECTIVE
Patients taking antibiotics for any reason and those with urinary tract symptoms were excluded.	OBJECTIVE
A midstream urine specimen was divided; half was sent for microscopy and formal bacteriological culture and the other half was tested with a commercial reagent strip test for the presence of blood, protein, nitrite, and leucocyte esterase.	METHODS
Sensitivity, specificity, and positive and negative predictive values of the reagent strips in diagnosing asymptomatic bacteriuria (defined as 10(5) colony forming units/ml urine).	METHODS
Sensitivity was low, with a maximum of 33% when all four tests were used in combination.	RESULTS
Specificity was high, with typical values of 99% or more.	RESULTS
Positive predictive value reached a maximum of 69% and negative predictive value was typically 95% or more.	RESULTS
Urine reagent strips are not sufficiently sensitive to be of use in the screening for asymptomatic bacteriuria and therefore many patients would be missed.	CONCLUSIONS
In view of the potentially serious sequelae of this condition in pregnant women we recommend that formal bacteriological investigation remain the investigation of choice in this group of patients.	CONCLUSIONS

MicroRNAs (miRNAs) are produced by the sequential processing of a long hairpin RNA transcript by Drosha and Dicer, an RNase III enzymes, and form transitory small RNA duplexes.	BACKGROUND
One strand of the duplex, which incorporates into RNA-induced silencing complex (RISC) and silences the gene expression is called guide strand, or miRNA; while the other strand of duplex is degraded and called the passenger strand, or miRNA*. Predicting the guide strand of miRNA is important for better understanding the RNA interference pathways.	BACKGROUND
This paper describes support vector machine (SVM) models developed for predicting the guide strands of miRNAs.	RESULTS
All models were trained and tested on a dataset consisting of 329 miRNA and 329 miRNA* pairs using five fold cross validation technique.	RESULTS
Firstly, models were developed using mono-, di-, and tri-nucleotide composition of miRNA strands and achieved the highest accuracies of 0.588, 0.638 and 0.596 respectively.	RESULTS
Secondly, models were developed using split nucleotide composition and achieved maximum accuracies of 0.553, 0.641 and 0.602 for mono-, di-, and tri-nucleotide respectively.	RESULTS
Thirdly, models were developed using binary pattern and achieved the highest accuracy of 0.708.	RESULTS
Furthermore, when integrating the secondary structure features with binary pattern, an accuracy of 0.719 was seen.	RESULTS
Finally, hybrid models were developed by combining various features and achieved maximum accuracy of 0.799 with sensitivity 0.781 and specificity 0.818.	RESULTS
Moreover, the performance of this model was tested on an independent dataset that achieved an accuracy of 0.80.	RESULTS
In addition, we also compared the performance of our method with various siRNA-designing methods on miRNA and siRNA datasets.	RESULTS
In this study, first time a method has been developed to predict guide miRNA strands, of miRNA duplex.	CONCLUSIONS
This study demonstrates that guide and passenger strand of miRNA precursors can be distinguished using their nucleotide sequence and secondary structure.	CONCLUSIONS
This method will be useful in understanding microRNA processing and can be implemented in RNA silencing technology to improve the biological and clinical research.	CONCLUSIONS
A web server has been developed based on SVM models described in this study (http://crdd.osdd.net:8081/RISCbinder/).	CONCLUSIONS

Transmission of dengue viruses (DENV), the leading cause of arboviral disease worldwide, is known to vary through time and space, likely owing to a combination of factors related to the human host, virus, mosquito vector, and environment.	BACKGROUND
An improved understanding of variation in transmission patterns is fundamental to conducting surveillance and implementing disease prevention strategies.	BACKGROUND
To test the hypothesis that DENV transmission is spatially and temporally focal, we compared geographic and temporal characteristics within Thai villages where DENV are and are not being actively transmitted.	BACKGROUND
Cluster investigations were conducted within 100 m of homes where febrile index children with (positive clusters) and without (negative clusters) acute dengue lived during two seasons of peak DENV transmission.	METHODS
Data on human infection and mosquito infection/density were examined to precisely (1) define the spatial and temporal dimensions of DENV transmission, (2) correlate these factors with variation in DENV transmission, and (3) determine the burden of inapparent and symptomatic infections.	METHODS
Among 556 village children enrolled as neighbors of 12 dengue-positive and 22 dengue-negative index cases, all 27 DENV infections (4.9% of enrollees) occurred in positive clusters (p < 0.01; attributable risk [AR] = 10.4 per 100; 95% confidence interval 1-19.8 per 100].	RESULTS
In positive clusters, 12.4% of enrollees became infected in a 15-d period and DENV infections were aggregated centrally near homes of index cases.	RESULTS
As only 1 of 217 pairs of serologic specimens tested in positive clusters revealed a recent DENV infection that occurred prior to cluster initiation, we attribute the observed DENV transmission subsequent to cluster investigation to recent DENV transmission activity.	RESULTS
Of the 1,022 female adult Ae.	RESULTS
aegypti collected, all eight (0.8%) dengue-infected mosquitoes came from houses in positive clusters; none from control clusters or schools.	RESULTS
Distinguishing features between positive and negative clusters were greater availability of piped water in negative clusters (p < 0.01) and greater number of Ae.	RESULTS
aegypti pupae per person in positive clusters (p = 0.04).	RESULTS
During primarily DENV-4 transmission seasons, the ratio of inapparent to symptomatic infections was nearly 1:1 among child enrollees.	RESULTS
Study limitations included inability to sample all children and mosquitoes within each cluster and our reliance on serologic rather than virologic evidence of interval infections in enrollees given restrictions on the frequency of blood collections in children.	RESULTS
Our data reveal the remarkably focal nature of DENV transmission within a hyperendemic rural area of Thailand.	CONCLUSIONS
These data suggest that active school-based dengue case detection prompting local spraying could contain recent virus introductions and reduce the longitudinal risk of virus spread within rural areas.	CONCLUSIONS
Our results should prompt future cluster studies to explore how host immune and behavioral aspects may impact DENV transmission and prevention strategies.	CONCLUSIONS
Cluster methodology could serve as a useful research tool for investigation of other temporally and spatially clustered infectious diseases.	CONCLUSIONS

Although we know that exacerbations are key events in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), our understanding of their frequency, determinants, and effects is incomplete.	BACKGROUND
In a large observational cohort, we tested the hypothesis that there is a frequent-exacerbation phenotype of COPD that is independent of disease severity.	BACKGROUND
We analyzed the frequency and associations of exacerbation in 2138 patients enrolled in the Evaluation of COPD Longitudinally to Identify Predictive Surrogate Endpoints (ECLIPSE) study.	METHODS
Exacerbations were defined as events that led a care provider to prescribe antibiotics or corticosteroids (or both) or that led to hospitalization (severe exacerbations).	METHODS
Exacerbation frequency was observed over a period of 3 years.	METHODS
Exacerbations became more frequent (and more severe) as the severity of COPD increased; exacerbation rates in the first year of follow-up were 0.85 per person for patients with stage 2 COPD (with stage defined in accordance with Global Initiative for Chronic Obstructive Lung Disease [GOLD] stages), 1.34 for patients with stage 3, and 2.00 for patients with stage 4.	RESULTS
Overall, 22% of patients with stage 2 disease, 33% with stage 3, and 47% with stage 4 had frequent exacerbations (two or more in the first year of follow-up).	RESULTS
The single best predictor of exacerbations, across all GOLD stages, was a history of exacerbations.	RESULTS
The frequent-exacerbation phenotype appeared to be relatively stable over a period of 3 years and could be predicted on the basis of the patient's recall of previous treated events.	RESULTS
In addition to its association with more severe disease and prior exacerbations, the phenotype was independently associated with a history of gastroesophageal reflux or heartburn, poorer quality of life, and elevated white-cell count.	RESULTS
Although exacerbations become more frequent and more severe as COPD progresses, the rate at which they occur appears to reflect an independent susceptibility phenotype.	CONCLUSIONS
This has implications for the targeting of exacerbation-prevention strategies across the spectrum of disease severity.	CONCLUSIONS
(Funded by GlaxoSmithKline; ClinicalTrials.gov number, NCT00292552.)	CONCLUSIONS

To quantify effect on mortality of administering human albumin or plasma protein fraction during management of critically ill patients.	OBJECTIVE
Systematic review of randomised controlled trials comparing administration of albumin or plasma protein fraction with no administration or with administration of crystalloid solution in critically ill patients with hypovolaemia, burns, or hypoalbuminaemia.	METHODS
30 randomised controlled trials including 1419 randomised patients.	OBJECTIVE
Mortality from all causes at end of follow up for each trial.	METHODS
For each patient category the risk of death in the albumin treated group was higher than in the comparison group.	RESULTS
For hypovolaemia the relative risk of death after albumin administration was 1.46 (95% confidence interval 0.97 to 2.22), for burns the relative risk was 2.40 (1.11 to 5.19), and for hypoalbuminaemia	RESULTS
it was 1.69 (1.07 to 2.67).	RESULTS
Pooled relative risk of death with albumin administration was 1.68 (1.26 to 2.23).	RESULTS
Pooled difference in the risk of death with albumin was 6% (95% confidence interval 3% to 9%) with a fixed effects model.	RESULTS
These data suggest that for every 17 critically ill patients treated with albumin there is one additional death.	RESULTS
There is no evidence that albumin administration reduces mortality in critically ill patients with hypovolaemia, burns, or hypoalbuminaemia and a strong suggestion that it may increase mortality.	CONCLUSIONS
These data suggest that use of human albumin in critically ill patients should be urgently reviewed and that it should not be used outside the context of rigorously conducted, randomised controlled trials.	CONCLUSIONS

Human papillomavirus (HPV) DNA testing of women having Papanicolaou (Pap) smears showing atypical squamous cells of undetermined significance (ASCUS) has clinical usefulness.	BACKGROUND
Whether HPV DNA testing alone is useful in primary screening remains to be determined.	BACKGROUND
To determine the accuracy of HPV DNA testing for detecting cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) grade 3 or cancer (the criterion standard).	OBJECTIVE
DESIGN, SETTING, AND PARTICIPANTS Between December 1997 and October 2000, 4075 women who attended Planned Parenthood clinics in Washington State were screened simultaneously using thin-layer Pap and HPV DNA testing by a polymerase chain reaction (PCR)-based method and by a liquid-based RNA-DNA hybridization capture with signal amplification assay (signal amplification).	OBJECTIVE
Women who were positive for high-risk HPV types, or had Pap results of ASCUS or higher, were considered to have positive screening test results and were referred for colposcopy and biopsy.	OBJECTIVE
Additionally, a random sample of women with negative screening test results was referred for colposcopy.	OBJECTIVE
Based on individual and combined thin-layer Pap, HPV PCR, and HPV signal amplification test results from the screening and the colposcopy visits, 7 colposcopy triage strategies were defined and evaluated.	OBJECTIVE
Sensitivity and specificity for detecting cervical lesions graded CIN 3 or higher for each of the 7 triage strategies.	METHODS
The estimated prevalence of CIN 3 or higher was 3.2%.	RESULTS
The sensitivity (95% confidence interval) of thin-layer Pap (with a result of > or = ASCUS) for identifying women with CIN 3 or higher was only 61.3% (48.5%-70.9%) compared with 88.2% (78.9%-93.8%) for HPV testing by PCR and 90.8% (83.1%-95.8%) by signal amplification.	RESULTS
Differences in specificities were also observed: 82.4% (81.8%-83.1%) for thin-layer Pap (with a result of > or = ASCUS), 78.8% (77.9%-79.7%) for PCR, and 72.6% (69.4%-75.0%) for signal amplification.	RESULTS
Compared with referral for colposcopy of all women with ASCUS or higher, signal amplification testing of women with ASCUS and referral of those with a positive result was about as sensitive (61.3% vs 60.3%, respectively) and significantly more specific (82.4% vs 88.9%, respectively).	RESULTS
The strategy requiring repeat positive PCR tests on 2 visits had a sensitivity of 84.2% (75.3%-91.0%) and a specificity of 86.2% (85.1%-87.3%).	RESULTS
All tests were more specific and less sensitive in older (> or = 30 years) vs younger women.	RESULTS
Testing for HPV has higher sensitivity but lower specificity than thin-layer Pap screening.	CONCLUSIONS
In some settings, particularly where screening intervals are long or haphazard, screening for HPV DNA may be a reasonable alternative to cytology-based screening of reproductive-age women.	CONCLUSIONS

The aim of the study was to report the 2-year outcome after a displaced 3-part fracture of the proximal humerus in elderly patients randomized to treatment with a locking plate or nonoperative treatment.	BACKGROUND
We included 60 patients, mean age 74 years (range, 56-92), 81% being women.	METHODS
The main outcome measures were the Constant and Disabilities of the Arm, Shoulder and Hand (DASH) scores and the health-related quality of life (HRQoL) according to the EQ-5D.	METHODS
At the final 2-year follow-up, the results for range of motion (ROM), function and HRQoL were all in favor of the locking plate group.	RESULTS
The mean flexion in the locking plate group was 120° compared to 111° in the nonoperative group (P = .36) and the mean abduction was 114° compared to 106° (P = .28).	RESULTS
The corresponding values for the Constant score were 61 versus 58 (P = .64), for DASH 26 versus 35 (P = .19), and the mean EQ-5D (index) score was 0.70 compared to 0.59 (P = .26).	RESULTS
In spite of good primary reduction in 86% of the fractures in the locking plate group, 13% of the patients had a fracture complication requiring a major reoperation and 17% had a minor reoperation.	RESULTS
The results of our study indicate an advantage in functional outcome and HRQoL in favor of the locking plate compared to nonoperative treatment in elderly patients with a displaced 3-part fracture of the proximal humerus, but at the cost of additional surgery in 30% of the patients.	CONCLUSIONS

Antiresorptive agents are widely used to treat osteoporosis.	BACKGROUND
We report the results of a multinational randomized, double-blind study, in which postmenopausal women with osteoporosis were treated with alendronate for up to 10 years.	BACKGROUND
The initial three-year phase of the study compared three daily doses of alendronate with placebo.	METHODS
Women in the original placebo group received alendronate in years 4 and 5 and then were discharged.	METHODS
Women in the original active-treatment groups continued to receive alendronate during the initial extension (years 4 and 5).	METHODS
In two further extensions (years 6 and 7, and 8 through 10), women who had received 5 mg or 10 mg of alendronate daily continued on the same treatment.	METHODS
Women in the discontinuation group received 20 mg of alendronate daily for two years and 5 mg daily in years 3, 4, and 5, followed by five years of placebo.	METHODS
Randomized group assignments and blinding were maintained throughout the 10 years.	METHODS
We report results for the 247 women who participated in all four phases of the study.	METHODS
Treatment with 10 mg of alendronate daily for 10 years produced mean increases in bone mineral density of 13.7 percent at the lumbar spine (95 percent confidence interval, 12.0 to 15.5 percent), 10.3 percent at the trochanter (95 percent confidence interval, 8.1 to 12.4 percent), 5.4 percent at the femoral neck (95 percent confidence interval, 3.5 to 7.4 percent), and 6.7 percent at the total proximal femur (95 percent confidence interval, 4.4 to 9.1 percent) as compared with base-line values; smaller gains occurred in the group given 5 mg daily.	RESULTS
The discontinuation of alendronate resulted in a gradual loss of effect, as measured by bone density and biochemical markers of bone remodeling.	RESULTS
Safety data, including fractures and stature, did not suggest that prolonged treatment resulted in any loss of benefit.	RESULTS
The therapeutic effects of alendronate were sustained, and the drug was well tolerated over a 10-year period.	CONCLUSIONS
The discontinuation of alendronate resulted in the gradual loss of its effects.	CONCLUSIONS

P2Y12 inhibitor switching has appeared in clinical practice as a consequence of prasugrel and ticagrelor availability, apart from clopidogrel, for use in patients with acute coronary syndrome (ACS) undergoing percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI).	BACKGROUND
In the context of the GReek AntiPlatelet REgistry (GRAPE) we assessed the prevalence, predictive factors and short-term outcome of in-hospital P2Y12 inhibitor switching in 1794 ACS patients undergoing PCI.	METHODS
Switching occurred in 636 (35.5%) patients of which in the form of clopidogrel to a novel agent, novel agent to clopidogrel and between prasugrel and ticagrelor in 574 (90.4%), 34 (5.3%) and 27 (4.3%) patients, respectively.	RESULTS
Presentation to non PCI-capable hospital, bivalirudin use, age ≥75 years (inverse predictor), and regional trends emerged as predictive factors of switching to a novel agent.	RESULTS
At combined in-hospital and one-month follow-up, propensity matched pairs analysis showed no differences in major adverse cardiovascular (MACE) or bleeding events between switching from clopidogrel to a novel agent vs novel agent constant administration.	RESULTS
More Bleeding Academic Research Consortium type 1, type 2 and any type events and fewer MACE were seen when switching from clopidogrel to a novel agent vs only clopidogrel administration (23.7%, 3.8%, 30.6%, 1.2% vs 8.9%, 1.2%, 12.0%, 3.8% with P < .001, P = .03, P < .001 and P = .03 respectively).	RESULTS
In a real-life experience with contemporary antiplatelet treatment in ACS patients undergoing PCI, in-hospital switching represents common clinical practice.	CONCLUSIONS
Clinical factors and regional practice differences seem to affect this strategy's choice, while switching to a novel agent may be associated with higher risk of bleeding.	CONCLUSIONS

To test the validity of age at menarche self-reported in adulthood and examine whether socioeconomic position, education, experience of gynaecological events and psychological symptoms influence the accuracy of recall.	OBJECTIVE
Prospective birth cohort study.	METHODS
England, Scotland and Wales.	METHODS
1050 women from the Medical Research Council National Survey of Health and Development, with two measures of age at menarche, one recorded in adolescence and the other self-reported at age 48 years.	METHODS
By calculating the limits of agreement, kappa statistic and Pearson's correlation coefficients (r), we found that the validity of age at menarche self-reported in middle age compared with that recorded in adolescence was moderate (kappa = 0.35, r = 0.66, n = 1050).	RESULTS
Validity was improved by categorising age at menarche into three groups: early, normal and late (kappa = 0.43).	RESULTS
Agreement was influenced by educational level and having had a stillbirth or miscarriage.	RESULTS
The level of validity shown in this study throws some doubt on whether it is justifiable to use age at menarche self-reported in middle age.	CONCLUSIONS
It is likely to introduce error and bias, and researchers should be aware of these limitations and use such measures with caution.	CONCLUSIONS

There is controversy in published studies regarding the role of repeat whole brain radiation (WBRT) for previously irradiated brain metastases.	OBJECTIVE
The aim of our retrospective study was to document the practice at Princess Margaret Hospital with respect to the re-irradiation of patients with progressive or recurrent brain metastatic disease after initial WBRT.	OBJECTIVE
A comprehensive computerised database was used to identify patients treated for brain metastases with more than one course of WBRT between 1997 and 2003.	METHODS
Seventy-two patients were treated with WBRT for brain metastases and retreated with WBRT at a later date.	METHODS
The records of these patients were reviewed.	METHODS
The median age was 56.5 years.	RESULTS
The most common primary sites were lung (51 patients) and breast (17 patients).	RESULTS
The most frequent dose used for the initial radiotherapy was 20 Gy/5 fractions (62 patients).	RESULTS
The most common doses of re-irradiation were 25 Gy/10 fractions (22 patients), 20 Gy/10 fractions (12 patients), 15 Gy/5 fractions (11 patients) and 20 Gy/8 fractions (10 patients).	RESULTS
Thirty-one per cent of patients experienced a partial clinical response after re-irradiation, as judged by follow-up clinical notes; 27% remained stable; 32% deteriorated after re-irradiation.	RESULTS
Patients who had Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group performance status 0-1 at the time of retreatment lived longer.	RESULTS
In responders, the mean duration of response was 5.1 months.	RESULTS
The median survival after re-irradiation was 4.1 months.	RESULTS
One patient was reported as having memory impairment and pituitary insufficiency after 5 months of progression-free survival.	RESULTS
Repeat radiotherapy may be a useful treatment in carefully selected patients.	CONCLUSIONS
With increased survival and better systemic options for patients with metastatic disease, more patients may be candidates for consideration of repeat WBRT for recurrent brain metastases, but prospective studies are needed to more clearly document their outcomes.	CONCLUSIONS

The epidemic of heart failure has yet to be fully investigated, and data on incidence, survival, and sex-specific temporal trends in community-based populations are limited.	BACKGROUND
To test the hypothesis that the incidence of heart failure has declined and survival after heart failure diagnosis has improved over time but that secular trends have diverged by sex.	OBJECTIVE
DESIGN, SETTING, AND PARTICIPANTS Population-based cohort study using the resources of the Rochester Epidemiology Project conducted in Olmsted County, Minnesota.	OBJECTIVE
Patients were 4537 Olmsted County residents (57% women; mean [SD] age, 74 [14] years) with a diagnosis of heart failure between 1979 and 2000.	OBJECTIVE
Framingham criteria and clinical criteria were used to validate the diagnosis   MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Incidence of heart failure and survival after heart failure diagnosis.	OBJECTIVE
The incidence of heart failure was higher among men (378/100 000 persons; 95% confidence interval [CI], 361-395 for men; 289/100 000 persons; 95% CI, 277-300 for women) and did not change over time among men or women.	RESULTS
After a mean follow-up of 4.2 years (range, 0-23.8 years), 3347 deaths occurred, including 1930 among women and 1417 among men.	RESULTS
Survival after heart failure diagnosis was worse among men than women (relative risk, 1.33; 95% CI, 1.24-1.43) but overall improved over time (5-year age-adjusted survival, 43% in 1979-1984 vs 52% in 1996-2000, P<.001).	RESULTS
However, men and younger persons experienced larger survival gains, contrasting with less or no improvement for women and elderly persons.	RESULTS
In this community-based cohort, the incidence of heart failure has not declined during 2 decades, but survival after onset of heart failure has increased overall, with less improvement among women and elderly persons.	CONCLUSIONS

Tetracyclines such as doxycycline are reported to possess cytotoxic activity against mammalian tumor cells, but the mechanism of their effects on cell proliferation remains unclear.	BACKGROUND
The antitumor effect of doxycycline was investigated in human pancreatic cancer cell line, PANC-1.	METHODS
We also investigated the effect of doxycycline on expression of a potent proangiogenic factor, interleukin (IL)-8.	METHODS
In excess of 20 microg/ml, cytotoxic effects of doxycycline were accompanied by G(1)-S cell cycle arrest and DNA fragmentation in PANC-1 cells.	RESULTS
Doxycycline consistently activated transcription of p53, p21 and Fas/FasL-cascade-related genes, while reducing the expression of Bcl-xL and Mcl-1.	RESULTS
Doxycycline (5 microg/ml) below the cytotoxic level suppressed endogenous and paclitaxel-induced IL-8 expression.	RESULTS
In the mouse xenograft model, doxycycline treatment was shown to suppress tumor growth by 80%.	RESULTS
These data suggest that doxycycline exerts its antitumor effect by activating proapoptotic genes, inhibiting IL-8 expression, and suppressing antiapoptotic genes.	CONCLUSIONS

Deadenylation regulates RNA function and fate.	BACKGROUND
Poly(A)-specific ribonuclease (PARN) is a deadenylase that processes mRNAs and non-coding RNA.	BACKGROUND
Little is known about the biological significance of germline mutations in PARN.	BACKGROUND
We identified mutations in PARN in patients with haematological and neurological manifestations.	METHODS
Genomic, biochemical and knockdown experiments in human marrow cells and in zebrafish have been performed to clarify the role of PARN in the human disease.	METHODS
We identified large monoallelic deletions in PARN in four patients with developmental delay or mental illness.	RESULTS
One patient in particular had a severe neurological phenotype, central hypomyelination and bone marrow failure.	RESULTS
This patient had an additional missense mutation on the non-deleted allele and severely reduced PARN protein and deadenylation activity.	RESULTS
Cells from this patient had impaired oligoadenylation of specific H/ACA box small nucleolar RNAs.	RESULTS
Importantly, PARN-deficient patient cells manifested short telomeres and an aberrant ribosome profile similar to those described in some variants of dyskeratosis congenita.	RESULTS
Knocking down PARN in human marrow cells and zebrafish impaired haematopoiesis, providing further evidence for a causal link with the human disease.	RESULTS
Large monoallelic mutations of PARN can cause developmental/mental illness.	CONCLUSIONS
Biallelic PARN mutations cause severe bone marrow failure and central hypomyelination.	CONCLUSIONS

To characterize the relationship between aneurysm size and epidemiologic risk factors with growth and rupture by using computed tomographic (CT) angiography.	OBJECTIVE
In this HIPAA-compliant, institutional review board approved study, patients with known asymptomatic unruptured intracerebral aneurysms were followed up longitudinally with CT angiographic examinations.	METHODS
Growth was defined as an increase in one or more dimensions above the measurement error, and at least 5% volume by using the ABC/2 method.	METHODS
Associations of epidemiologic factors with aneurysm growth and rupture were analyzed by using logistic regression analysis.	METHODS
Intra- and interobserver agreement coefficients for dimension, volume, and growth were evaluated by using the Pearson correlation coefficient and difference of means with 95% confidence intervals, the agreement statistic, and the McNemar χ(2).	METHODS
Patients (n = 165) with aneurysms (n = 258) had a mean follow-up time of 2.24 years from time of diagnosis.	RESULTS
Forty-six of 258 (18%) aneurysms in 38 patients grew larger.	RESULTS
Spontaneous rupture occurred in four of 228 (1.8%) intradural aneurysms of average size (6.2 mm).	RESULTS
Risk of aneurysm rupture per patient-year was 2.4% (95% CI: 0.5%, 7.12%) with growth and 0.2% (95% CI: 0.006%, 1.22%) without growth (P = .034).	RESULTS
There was a 12-fold higher risk of rupture for growing aneurysms (P < .002), with high intra- and interobserver correlation coefficients for size, volume, and growth.	RESULTS
Tobacco smoking (3.806, one degree of freedom; P < .015,) and initial size (5.895, two degrees of freedom; P < .051) were independent covariates, predicting 78.4% of growing aneurysms.	RESULTS
These results support imaging follow-up of all patients with aneurysms, including those whose aneurysms are smaller than the current 7-mm treatment threshold.	CONCLUSIONS
Aneurysm growth, size, and smoking were associated with increased rupture risk.	CONCLUSIONS

Risedronate, a potent bisphosphonate, has been shown to be effective in the treatment of Paget disease of bone and other metabolic bone diseases but, to our knowledge, it has not been evaluated in the treatment of established postmenopausal osteoporosis.	BACKGROUND
To test the efficacy and safety of daily treatment with risedronate to reduce the risk of vertebral and other fractures in postmenopausal women with established osteoporosis.	OBJECTIVE
DESIGN, SETTING, AND PARTICIPANTS Randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial of 2458 ambulatory postmenopausal women younger than 85 years with at least 1 vertebral fracture at baseline who were enrolled at 1 of 110 centers in North America conducted between December 1993 and January 1998.	OBJECTIVE
Subjects were randomly assigned to receive oral treatment for 3 years with risedronate (2.5 or 5 mg/d) or placebo.	METHODS
All subjects received calcium, 1000 mg/d.	METHODS
Vitamin D (cholecalciferol, up to 500 IU/d) was provided if baseline levels of 25-hydroxyvitamin D were low.	METHODS
Incidence of new vertebral fractures as detected by quantitative and semiquantitative assessments of radiographs; incidence of radiographically confirmed nonvertebral fractures and change from baseline in bone mineral density as determined by dual x-ray absorptiometry.	METHODS
The 2.5 mg/d of risedronate arm was discontinued after 1 year; in the placebo and 5 mg/d of risedronate arms, 450 and 489 subjects, respectively, completed all 3 years of the trial.	RESULTS
Treatment with 5 mg/d of risedronate, compared with placebo, decreased the cumulative incidence of new vertebral fractures by 41 % (95% confidence interval [CI], 18%-58%) over 3 years (11.3 % vs 16.3%; P= .003).	RESULTS
A fracture reduction of 65% (95% CI, 38%-81 %) was observed after the first year (2.4% vs 6.4%; P<.001).	RESULTS
The cumulative incidence of nonvertebral fractures over 3 years was reduced by 39% (95% CI, 6%-61 %) (5.2 % vs 8.4%; P = .02).	RESULTS
Bone mineral density increased significantly compared with placebo at the lumbar spine (5.4% vs 1.1 %), femoral neck (1.6% vs -1.2%), femoral trochanter (3.3% vs -0.7%), and midshaft of the radius (0.2% vs -1.4%).	RESULTS
Bone formed during risedronate treatment was histologically normal.	RESULTS
The overall safety profile of risedronate, including gastrointestinal safety, was similar to that of placebo.	RESULTS
These data suggest that risedronate therapy is effective and well tolerated in the treatment of women with established postmenopausal osteoporosis.	CONCLUSIONS

To describe and explain the primary care experiences of people with multiple long-term conditions in England.	OBJECTIVE
Using questionnaire data from 906,578 responders to the English 2012 General Practice Patient Survey, we describe the primary care experiences of patients with long-term conditions, including 583,143 patients who reported one or more long-term conditions.	METHODS
We employed mixed effect logistic regressions to analyse data on six items covering three care domains (access, continuity and communication) and a single item on overall primary care experience.	METHODS
We controlled for sociodemographic characteristics, and for general practice using a random effect, and further, controlled for, and explored the importance of, health-related quality of life measured using the EuroQoL (EQ-5D) scale.	METHODS
Most patients with long-term conditions report a positive experience of care at their general practice (after adjusting for sociodemographic characteristics and general practice, range 74.0-93.1% reporting positive experience of care across seven questions) with only modest variation by type of condition.	RESULTS
For all three domains of patient experience, an increasing number of comorbid conditions is associated with a reducing percentage of patients reporting a positive experience of care.	RESULTS
For example, compared with respondents with no long-term condition, the OR for reporting a positive experience is 0.83 (95% CI 0.80 to 0.87) for respondents with four or more long-term conditions.	RESULTS
However, this relationship is no longer observed after adjusting for health-related quality of life (OR (95% CI) single condition=1.23 (1.21 to 1.26); four or more conditions=1.31 (1.25 to 1.37)), with pain making the greatest difference among five quality of life variables included in the analysis.	RESULTS
Patients with multiple long-term conditions more frequently report worse experiences in primary care.	CONCLUSIONS
However, patient-centred measures of health-related quality of life, especially pain, are more important than the number of conditions in explaining why patients with multiple long-term conditions report worse experiences of care.	CONCLUSIONS

To investigate comparative national trends in mortality from conditions amenable to timely, appropriate medical care and from those considered not to be amenable to such care.	OBJECTIVE
Analysis of trends in direct age standardised mortality from the 1950s to 1987.	METHODS
Four eastern European nations (Hungary, Czechoslovakia, Poland, the German Democratic Republic) and two western European (the Federal Republic of Germany and England and Wales) and two North American nations (United States and Canada).	METHODS
The total populations of the relevant countries during the period examined.	OBJECTIVE
Proportional changes over time in age standardised mortality.	METHODS
Mortality from amenable and non-amenable causes was restricted to the age group 0-64.	METHODS
A divergence in the trends for all cause mortality between eastern Europe and the western nations occurred in about 1970, when the rates in western countries steadily declined but those in eastern Europe remained fairly static.	RESULTS
In the age group 0-64 mortality from causes considered amenable to medical care fell less quickly in eastern Europe than in the West, particularly after 1970.	RESULTS
In the same age group, mortality from non-amenable causes rose in eastern European countries from the late 1960s compared with substantial declines in such mortality in the West.	RESULTS
Non-amenable causes of death seem to be the principal, but not exclusive, reason for lack of improvement in trends in all cause mortality in eastern Europe from 1970.	CONCLUSIONS
The agenda for action in eastern Europe should give priority to a healthier lifestyle and improvement of the environment though not neglect enhancements in the quality and efficiency of direct health services.	CONCLUSIONS

Five or more circulating tumor cells (CTCs) per 7.5 mL of blood predicts for poorer progression-free survival (PFS) in patients with metastatic breast cancer (MBC).	OBJECTIVE
We conducted a prospective study to demonstrate that CTC results correlate strongly with radiographic disease progression at the time of and in advance of imaging.	OBJECTIVE
Serial CTC levels were obtained in patients starting a new treatment regimen for progressive, radiographically measurable MBC.	METHODS
Peripheral blood was collected for CTC enumeration at baseline and at 3- to 4-week intervals.	METHODS
Clinical outcomes were based on radiographic studies performed in 9- to 12-week intervals.	METHODS
Sixty-eight patients were evaluable for the CTC-imaging correlations, and 74 patients were evaluable for the PFS analysis.	RESULTS
Median follow-up was 13.3 months.	RESULTS
A statistically significant correlation was demonstrated between CTC levels and radiographic disease progression in patients receiving chemotherapy or endocrine therapy.	RESULTS
This correlation applied to CTC results obtained at the time of imaging (odds ratio [OR], 6.3), 3 to 5 weeks before imaging (OR, 3.1), and 7 to 9 weeks before imaging (OR, 4.9).	RESULTS
Results from analyses stratified by type of therapy remained statistically significant.	RESULTS
Shorter PFS was observed for patients with five or more CTCs at 3 to 5 weeks and at 7 to 9 weeks after the start of treatment.	RESULTS
We provide, to our knowledge, the first evidence of a strong correlation between CTC results and radiographic disease progression in patients receiving chemotherapy or endocrine therapy for MBC.	CONCLUSIONS
These findings support the role of CTC enumeration as an adjunct to standard methods of monitoring disease status in MBC.	CONCLUSIONS

Gastric bypass patients with a range of disturbed eating patterns before surgery may be at risk of returning to old patterns postoperatively.	BACKGROUND
Recent research has shown that binge eating is common among the obese before surgery as well as in the postoperative maintenance phase and appears to be linked to poorer outcome.	BACKGROUND
Although "grazing" behavior has not been specifically studied, it is also a high-risk pattern.	BACKGROUND
This paper is a descriptive investigation summarizing postoperative eating patterns in a group of patients.	BACKGROUND
Patients completed self-report questionnaires before surgery and were seen for a preoperative mental health evaluation with particular focus on assessing eating patterns.	METHODS
Patients with high-risk eating patterns, both binge eating and "grazing", were identified, invited to attend a post-surgery therapy group, and were given additional follow-up questionnaires regarding postoperative eating patterns.	METHODS
Consistent with recent studies, many high-risk patients reported recurrent loss of control over eating and, in some cases, subsequent weight gain.	RESULTS
Although no longer able to eat large amounts, "grazing" became a more common pattern, appearing >or=6 months following surgery.	RESULTS
Different forms of overeating need to be assessed in this population, focusing on the subjective loss of control rather than on the quantity consumed.	CONCLUSIONS
Although many patients do not meet strict criteria for binge eating disorder before surgery, these "grazers" are also high-risk.	CONCLUSIONS
Former binge eaters often turn into "grazers" following surgery.	CONCLUSIONS
Interventions are needed for at-risk patients.	CONCLUSIONS

Real-time adherence monitoring is now possible through medication storage devices equipped with cellular technology.	BACKGROUND
We assessed the effect of triggered cell phone reminders and counseling using objective adherence data on antiretroviral therapy (ART) adherence among Chinese HIV-infected patients.	BACKGROUND
We provided ART patients in Nanning, China, with a medication device (Wisepill) to monitor their ART adherence electronically.	METHODS
After 3 months, we randomized subjects within optimal (≥95%) and suboptimal (<95%) adherence strata to intervention vs. control arms.	METHODS
In months 4-9, intervention subjects received individualized reminders triggered by late dose taking (no device opening by 30 minutes past dose time) and counseling using device-generated data.	METHODS
Controls received no reminders or data-informed counseling.	METHODS
We compared postintervention proportions achieving optimal adherence, mean adherence, and clinical outcomes.	METHODS
Of 120 subjects enrolled, 116 (96.7%) completed the trial.	RESULTS
Preintervention optimal adherence was similar in intervention vs. control arms (63.5% vs. 58.9%, respectively; P = 0.60).	RESULTS
In the last intervention month, 87.3% vs. 51.8% achieved optimal adherence [risk ratio (RR): 1.7, 95% confidence interval (CI): 1.3 to 2.2] and mean adherence was 96.2% vs. 89.1% (P = 0.003).	RESULTS
Among preintervention suboptimal adherers, 78.3% vs. 33.3% (RR: 2.4, CI: 1.2 to 4.5) achieved optimal adherence and mean adherence was 93.3% vs. 84.7% (P = 0.039).	RESULTS
Proportions were 92.5% and 62.9% among optimal adherers, respectively (RR: 1.5, CI: 1.1 to 1.9) and mean adherence was 97.8% vs. 91.7% (P = 0.028).	RESULTS
Postintervention clinical outcomes were not significant.	RESULTS
Real-time reminders significantly improved ART adherence in this population.	CONCLUSIONS
This approach seems promising for managing HIV and other chronic diseases and warrants further investigation and adaptation in other settings.	CONCLUSIONS

Most gynecologists determine therapy based on current International Society of Gynecologic Pathologists (ISGP)/World Health Organization classification of endometrial hyperplasia, the reproducibility of which has been questioned.	BACKGROUND
The Gynecologic Oncology Group (GOG) initiated a protocol to assess the efficacy of hormonal therapy of atypical endometrial hyperplasia (AEH).	BACKGROUND
Primary goals of the first phase (Part A) were to prospectively determine reproducibility of referring institution's pathologist's diagnosis of AEH by a panel of 3 gynecologic pathologists and to determine reproducibility of diagnoses by panel members.	BACKGROUND
Three hundred six women were entered on this protocol with a referring institution's pathologist diagnosis of AEH based on biopsy or curettage.	METHODS
Available slides were assessed independently and interpreted by each of a panel of 3 gynecologic pathologists who used International Society of Gynecologic Pathologists (ISGP)/World Health Organization criteria.	METHODS
The majority diagnosis was based on diagnostic concordance by at least 2 of the 3 panelists.	METHODS
The referring institution's pathologist's diagnosis of AEH was supported by the majority of the panel in only 38% of cases.	RESULTS
Overall kappa value for the panel diagnosis of AEH was 0.28.	RESULTS
The majority diagnosis was adenocarcinoma in 29%, cycling endometrium in 7%, and nonatypical hyperplasia in 18% of cases.	RESULTS
Unanimous agreement for any diagnosis was reached among all 3 of the panel in 40% of cases.	RESULTS
For the panel, paired kappa values for any diagnosis ranged 0.34-0.43, with an overall kappa value of 0.40.	RESULTS
Reproducibility of referring institution's pathologists' diagnosis of AEH by a panel of gynecologic pathologists is poor.	CONCLUSIONS
Both underestimation and overestimation of the severity of the lesion are very common.	CONCLUSIONS
The level of reproducibility among subspecialist panel members for diagnosis of AEH in these specimens also is poor.	CONCLUSIONS
Better criteria and better sampling are needed to improve reproducibility of this diagnosis, particularly if it is to be used for clinical decisions.	CONCLUSIONS

To resolve uncertainty as to the risk of Sudden Infant Death Syndrome (SIDS) associated with sleeping in bed with your baby if neither parent smokes and the baby is breastfed.	OBJECTIVE
Bed sharing was defined as sleeping with a baby in the parents' bed; room sharing as baby sleeping in the parents' room.	METHODS
Frequency of bed sharing during last sleep was compared between babies who died of SIDS and living control infants.	METHODS
Five large SIDS case-control datasets were combined.	METHODS
Missing data were imputed.	METHODS
Random effects logistic regression controlled for confounding factors.	METHODS
Home sleeping arrangements of infants in 19 studies across the UK, Europe and Australasia.	METHODS
1472 SIDS cases, and 4679 controls.	METHODS
Each study effectively included all cases, by standard criteria.	METHODS
Controls were randomly selected normal infants of similar age, time and place.	METHODS
In the combined dataset, 22.2% of cases and 9.6% of controls were bed sharing, adjusted OR (AOR) for all ages 2.7; 95% CI (1.4 to 5.3).	RESULTS
Bed sharing risk decreased with increasing infant age.	RESULTS
When neither parent smoked, and the baby was less than 3 months, breastfed and had no other risk factors, the AOR for bed sharing versus room sharing was 5.1 (2.3 to 11.4) and estimated absolute risk for these room sharing infants was very low (0.08 (0.05 to 0.14)/1000 live-births).	RESULTS
This increased to 0.23 (0.11 to 0.43)/1000 when bed sharing.	RESULTS
Smoking and alcohol use greatly increased bed sharing risk.	RESULTS
Bed sharing for sleep when the parents do not smoke or take alcohol or drugs increases the risk of SIDS.	CONCLUSIONS
Risks associated with bed sharing are greatly increased when combined with parental smoking, maternal alcohol consumption and/or drug use.	CONCLUSIONS
A substantial reduction of SIDS rates could be achieved if parents avoided bed sharing.	CONCLUSIONS

To define the impact of chronic viremia and associated immune activation on B-cell exhaustion in HIV infection.	OBJECTIVE
Progressive HIV infection is marked by B-cell anergy and exhaustion coupled with dramatic hypergammaglobulinemia.	METHODS
Although both upregulation of CD95 and loss of CD21 have been used as markers of infection-associated B-cell dysfunction, little is known regarding the specific profiles of dysfunctional B cells and whether persistent viral replication and its associated immune activation play a central role in driving B-cell dysfunction.	METHODS
Multiparameter flow cytometry was used to define the profile of dysfunctional B cells.	METHODS
The changes in the expression of CD21 and CD95 were tracked on B-cell subpopulations in patients with differential control of viral replication.	METHODS
: Although the emergence of exhausted, CD21 tissue-like memory B cells followed similar patterns in both progressors and controllers, the frequency of CD21 activated memory B cells was lower in spontaneous controllers.	RESULTS
Our results suggest that the loss of CD21 and the upregulation of CD95 occur as separate events during the development of B-cell dysfunction.	CONCLUSIONS
The loss of CD21 is a marker of B-cell exhaustion induced in the absence of appreciable viral replication, whereas the upregulation of CD95 is tightly linked to persistent viral replication and its associated immune activation.	CONCLUSIONS
Thus, these dysfunctional profiles potentially represent two functionally distinct states within the B-cell compartment.	CONCLUSIONS

The bidirectional relationships between metabolic syndrome (MetS) and schizophrenia (SCZ) play a crucial role in clinical treatment of both diseases but such bidirectional causal effects have not been comprehensively elucidated.	BACKGROUND
To investigate the influence of MetS on incident SCZ and the opposite direction as well as their predictors for each direction with a population-based cohort sample.	OBJECTIVE
We enrolled 76,545 subjects who had participated in a community-based health screening program during 1999-2004.	METHODS
After excluding those with the existing MetS or SCZ at baseline, the two normal prospective cohorts corresponding to each independent variable of MetS or SCZ, respectively, were followed over time to ascertain incident outcome of SCZ and MetS. The crude and adjusted hazard ratios for the effect of the predictor on each incident outcome were estimated after controlling for the possible confounding factors.	METHODS
The overall incidence rate (per 10(5)person-years) of SCZ was 61.15.	RESULTS
The incidence rate in patients with MetS was lower than those without (44.24 versus 64.20), indicating the presence of MetS failed to find an increased risk of developing incident SCZ.	RESULTS
However, participants with abnormal waist circumference (WC) were two times (95% CI: 1.37 to 2.93) more likely to yield incident SCZ compared to those with normal WC.	RESULTS
In the opposite direction, the incidence of MetS was statistically higher in patients with SCZ than those without SCZ (11.25% vs 7.94%, respectively), suggesting SCZ conferred a higher risk for yielding incident MetS (adjusted hazard ratio=1.89, 95% CI: 1.36, 2.63).	RESULTS
After examining the bidirectional causal relationships between SCZ and MetS with the theoretically sound and large population-based prospective cohort study, central obesity, one of the individual components of MetS, was corroborated as an independent predictor for incident SCZ.	CONCLUSIONS
Patients diagnosed with SCZ were at greater risk of having incident cases of MetS. Such significant temporal bidirectional relationships between SCZ and central obesity suggest a reciprocal interaction exits between SCZ and central obesity.	CONCLUSIONS

To quantify the effects of quantity and frequency of alcohol consumption on risk of acute myocardial infarction and coronary death.	OBJECTIVE
Case-control study.	METHODS
Lower Hunter region of New South Wales, Australia, 1983-94.	METHODS
Men and women aged 35-69 years.	OBJECTIVE
Acute myocardial infarction or coronary death.	METHODS
Alcohol consumption patterns were compared between 11,511 cases of acute myocardial infarction or coronary death and 6077 controls randomly selected from the same study population.	RESULTS
After adjusting for the effects of age, smoking, and medical history, men and women who consumed one or two drinks of alcohol on five or six days a week had a reduction in risk of a major coronary event compared with men and women who were non-drinkers (odds ratios: men 0.31 (95% confidence interval 0.22 to 0.45); women 0.33 (0.18 to 0.59)).	RESULTS
A similar reduction in risk was found after excluding non-drinkers who were formerly moderate to heavy drinkers.	RESULTS
An acute protective effect of alcohol consumption was also found for regular drinkers who consumed one or two drinks in the 24 hours preceding the onset of symptoms (odds ratios: men 0.74 (0.51 to 1.09); women 0.43 (0.20 to 0.95)).	RESULTS
Frequency and quantity of alcohol consumption are important in assessing the risk of a major coronary event.	CONCLUSIONS
Risk is lowest among men who report one to four drinks daily on five or six days a week and among women who report one or two drinks daily on five or six days a week.	CONCLUSIONS

Although inhaled corticosteroids have an established role in the treatment of asthma, studies have tended to concentrate on non-smokers and little is known about the possible effect of cigarette smoking on the efficacy of treatment with inhaled steroids in asthma.	BACKGROUND
A study was undertaken to investigate the effect of active cigarette smoking on responses to treatment with inhaled corticosteroids in patients with mild asthma.	BACKGROUND
The effect of treatment with inhaled fluticasone propionate (1000 microg daily) or placebo for 3 weeks was studied in a double blind, prospective, randomised, placebo controlled study of 38 steroid naïve adult asthmatic patients (21 non-smokers).	METHODS
Efficacy was assessed using morning and evening peak expiratory flow (PEF) readings, spirometric parameters, bronchial hyperreactivity, and sputum eosinophil counts.	METHODS
Comparison was made between responses to treatment in non-smoking and smoking asthmatic patients.	METHODS
There was a significantly greater increase in mean morning PEF in non-smokers than in smokers following inhaled fluticasone (27 l/min v -5 l/min).	RESULTS
Non-smokers had a statistically significant increase in mean morning PEF (27 l/min), mean forced expiratory volume in 1 second (0.17 l), and geometric mean PC20 (2.6 doubling doses), and a significant decrease in the proportion of sputum eosinophils (-1.75%) after fluticasone compared with placebo.	RESULTS
No significant changes were observed in the smoking asthmatic patients for any of these parameters.	RESULTS
Active cigarette smoking impairs the efficacy of short term inhaled corticosteroid treatment in mild asthma.	CONCLUSIONS
This finding has important implications for the management of patients with mild asthma who smoke.	CONCLUSIONS

Minimal (< 10 mm thick) pleural effusion (PE) may represent an early phase of malignant PE, but its clinical relevance has rarely been studied.	OBJECTIVE
Therefore, we examined the proportion of minimal PE in patients with non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC) and its impact on survival.	OBJECTIVE
We also considered possible accumulation mechanisms in our data set.	OBJECTIVE
On the basis of PE status from chest computed tomography scans at diagnosis, 2,061 patients were classified into three groups: no PE, minimal PE, and malignant PE.	METHODS
Twenty-one variables associated with four factors-patient, stage migration, tumor, and treatment-were investigated for correlation with survival.	METHODS
Minimal PE presented in 272 patients (13.2%).	RESULTS
Of 2,061 patients, the proportion of each stage was the following: 5.2% stage I, 10.9% stage II, 13.2% stage IIIA, 23.8% stage IIIB, and 13.9% stage IV.	RESULTS
Minimal PE correlated significantly with shorter survival time than did no PE (median survival time, 7.7 v 17.7 months; log-rank P < .001), even after full adjustment with all variables (adjusted hazard ratio, 1.40; 95% CI, 1.21 to 1.62).	RESULTS
Prognostic impact of minimal PE was higher in early versus advanced stages (Pinteraction = .001).	RESULTS
In 237 patients (87.8%) with minimal PE, pleural invasion or attachment as a direct mechanism was observed, and it was an independent factor predicting worse survival (P = .03).	RESULTS
Minimal PE is a commonly encountered clinical concern in staging NSCLCs.	CONCLUSIONS
Its presence is an important prognostic factor of worse survival, especially in early-stage disease.	CONCLUSIONS

To examine the association between the use of right heart catheterization (RHC) during the first 24 hours of care in the intensive care unit (ICU) and subsequent survival, length of stay, intensity of care, and cost of care.	OBJECTIVE
Prospective cohort study.	METHODS
Five US teaching hospitals between 1989 and 1994.	METHODS
A total of 5735 critically ill adult patients receiving care in an ICU for 1 of 9 prespecified disease categories.	OBJECTIVE
Survival time, cost of care, intensity of care, and length of stay in the ICU and hospital, determined from the clinical record and from the National Death Index.	METHODS
A propensity score for RHC was constructed using multivariable logistic regression.	METHODS
Case-matching and multivariable regression modeling techniques were used to estimate the association of RHC with specific outcomes after adjusting for treatment selection using the propensity score.	METHODS
Sensitivity analysis was used to estimate the potential effect of an unidentified or missing covariate on the results.	METHODS
By case-matching analysis, patients with RHC had an increased 30-day mortality (odds ratio, 1.24; 95% confidence interval, 1.03-1.49).	RESULTS
The mean cost (25th, 50th, 75th percentiles) per hospital stay was $49 300 ($17 000, $30 500, $56 600) with RHC and $35 700 ($11 300, $20 600, $39 200) without RHC.	RESULTS
Mean length of stay in the ICU was 14.8 (5, 9, 17) days with RHC and 13.0 (4, 7, 14) days without RHC.	RESULTS
These findings were all confirmed by multivariable modeling techniques.	RESULTS
Subgroup analysis did not reveal any patient group or site for which RHC was associated with improved outcomes.	RESULTS
Patients with higher baseline probability of surviving 2 months had the highest relative risk of death following RHC.	RESULTS
Sensitivity analysis suggested that a missing covariate would have to increase the risk of death 6-fold and the risk of RHC 6-fold for a true beneficial effect of RHC to be misrepresented as harmful.	RESULTS
In this observational study of critically ill patients, after adjustment for treatment selection bias, RHC was associated with increased mortality and increased utilization of resources.	CONCLUSIONS
The cause of this apparent lack of benefit is unclear.	CONCLUSIONS
The results of this analysis should be confirmed in other observational studies.	CONCLUSIONS
These findings justify reconsideration of a randomized controlled trial of RHC and may guide patient selection for such a study.	CONCLUSIONS

Falciparum malaria or malaria tropica is one of the leading causes of childhood mortality worldwide.	BACKGROUND
Malaria-related deaths occur mainly in sub-Saharan Africa, where an estimated 365 million clinical cases of Plasmodium falciparum malaria occur each year.	BACKGROUND
In Europe, imported malaria cases occur due to returning travellers or immigration mostly from African countries.	BACKGROUND
Children are more at risk than adults.	BACKGROUND
The objective of this study was to identify high risk groups for imported childhood malaria in Europe in order to guide development of strategies for prevention, early recognition and management.	BACKGROUND
In the period May 2003-January 2005 we reviewed all cases of paediatric malaria in the Netherlands notified by the Dutch Paediatric Surveillance System (Nederland Signalerings Centrum Kindergeneeskunde, NSCK) and the literature on imported malaria in children in Europe published between 1996 and 2006.	METHODS
Malaria occurred mainly in children of long-term (n = 15, 47%) and new (n = 8, 25%) immigrants and was mostly acquired in sub-Saharan Africa.	RESULTS
The dominant species was P. falciparum.	RESULTS
Only one quarter of children had used adequate malaria chemoprophylaxis.	RESULTS
Complicated disease occurred in 10 (31%) of cases.	RESULTS
We also reviewed the literature and found 6082 reported cases of imported malaria among children in Europe; among these, four died and only one was reported to develop neurological sequelae.	RESULTS
Imported malaria in children remains an important problem and is unlikely to decrease unless the reasons for inadequate prophylaxis are addressed.	CONCLUSIONS

Whether immunosuppressive treatment adversely affects survival is unclear.	BACKGROUND
To assess whether immunosuppressive drugs increase mortality.	OBJECTIVE
Retrospective cohort study evaluating overall and cancer mortality in relation to immunosuppressive drug exposure among patients with ocular inflammatory diseases.	METHODS
Demographic, clinical, and treatment data derived from medical records, and mortality results from United States National Death Index linkage.	METHODS
The cohort's mortality risk was compared with US vital statistics using standardised mortality ratios.	METHODS
Overall and cancer mortality in relation to use or non-use of immunosuppressive drugs within the cohort was studied with survival analysis.	METHODS
Five tertiary ocular inflammation clinics.	METHODS
Patients 7957 US residents with non-infectious ocular inflammation, 2340 of whom received immunosuppressive drugs during follow up.	METHODS
Exposures Use of antimetabolites, T cell inhibitors, alkylating agents, and tumour necrosis factor inhibitors.	METHODS
Overall mortality, cancer mortality.	METHODS
Over 66 802 person years (17 316 after exposure to immunosuppressive drugs), 936 patients died (1.4/100 person years), 230 (24.6%) from cancer.	RESULTS
For patients unexposed to immunosuppressive treatment, risks of death overall (standardised mortality ratio 1.02, 95% confidence interval [CI] 0.94 to 1.11) and from cancer (1.10, 0.93 to 1.29) were similar to those of the US population.	RESULTS
Patients who used azathioprine, methotrexate, mycophenolate mofetil, ciclosporin, systemic corticosteroids, or dapsone had overall and cancer mortality similar to that of patients who never took immunosuppressive drugs.	RESULTS
In patients who used cyclophosphamide, overall mortality was not increased and cancer mortality was non-significantly increased.	RESULTS
Tumour necrosis factor inhibitors were associated with increased overall (adjusted hazard ratio [HR] 1.99, 95% CI 1.00 to 3.98) and cancer mortality (adjusted HR 3.83, 1.13 to 13.01).	RESULTS
Most commonly used immunosuppressive drugs do not seem to increase overall or cancer mortality.	CONCLUSIONS
Our results suggesting that tumour necrosis factor inhibitors might increase mortality are less robust than the other findings; additional evidence is needed.	CONCLUSIONS

To assay the efficiency for celiac disease (CD) screening of 2 immunochromatographic visual stick assays based on human recombinant tissue transglutaminase (tTG).	OBJECTIVE
One was the antitissue transglutaminase antibodies (AtTGA) stick for IgA/G antibodies to tTG detection, the other was the AtTGA/antigliadin antibodies (AGA) stick for IgA antibodies for tTG and/or gliadins.	OBJECTIVE
In a prospective multicenter study, 4 pediatric gastroenterology units from Spain and 2 from Latin America enrolled 72 control children with a normal small bowel mucosa and 113 untreated patients with CD with Marsh type 3 lesions.	METHODS
Evaluation of results by the gastroenterologists and by 2 independent observers at the coordination center showed a remarkably low interobserver variability.	RESULTS
For the AtTGA stick, sensitivity was 96.5% and specificity was 98.6%.	RESULTS
The AtTGA/AGA stick displayed a sensitivity of 94.5% and a specificity of 98.6% for AtTGA and a sensitivity of 63.1% and a specificity of 95.2% for AGA.	RESULTS
The highest efficiency and positive likelihood ratio was obtained for the AtTGA stick, higher than for IgA AtTGA by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay.	RESULTS
One additional advantage was that previous investigation of total serum IgA levels could be eluded.	RESULTS
The IgA AtTGA/AGA stick, with an efficiency of 95.1%, compared with 89.2% when the combined results of the 2 enzyme-linked immunosorbent assays were considered, turned out to be an excellent diagnostic tool for infants with no IgA deficiency.	RESULTS
These 2 assays are extremely efficient for CD screening, by combining a high diagnostic accuracy with the simplicity and rapidity of visual methods.	CONCLUSIONS

To assess the association between use of macrolide antibiotics in mothers and infants from pregnancy onset until 120 days after birth and infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS).	OBJECTIVE
Nationwide register based cohort study.	METHODS
Denmark, 1996-2011.	METHODS
999,378 liveborn singletons and linked individual level information on macrolide prescriptions (maternal use during pregnancy, n=30,091; maternal use after birth, n=21,557; use in infants, n=6591), surgery for IHPS, and potential confounders.	METHODS
Surgery for IHPS by three categories of macrolide use: in mothers during pregnancy, in mothers after birth, and in infants after birth.	METHODS
880 infants developed IHPS (0.9 cases per 1000 births).	RESULTS
Compared with infants with no use of macrolides, the adjusted rate ratio for IHPS in infants with use of macrolides during days 0 to 13 after birth was 29.8 (95% confidence interval 16.4 to 54.1) and during days 14 to 120 was 3.24 (1.20 to 8.74); the corresponding absolute risk differences were 24.4 (95% confidence interval 13.0 to 44.1) and 0.65 (0.06 to 2.21) cases per 1000 infants exposed to macrolides, respectively.	RESULTS
The rate ratio for maternal use of macrolides for days 0 to 13 after birth was 3.49 (1.92 to 6.34) and for days 14 to 120 was 0.70 (0.26 to 1.90); the corresponding absolute risk differences were 2.15 (0.82 to 4.64) and -0.11 (-0.26 to 0.31).	RESULTS
The rate ratios for maternal use of macrolides during pregnancy were 1.02 (0.65 to 1.59) for weeks 0 to 27 and 1.77 (0.95 to 3.31) for weeks 28 to birth; the corresponding absolute risk differences were 0.01 (-0.31 to 0.50) and 0.67 (-0.06 to 2.02).	RESULTS
Treatment of young infants with macrolide antibiotics was strongly associated with IHPS and should therefore only be administered if potential treatment benefits outweigh the risk.	CONCLUSIONS
Maternal use of macrolides during the first two weeks after birth was also associated with an increased risk of IHPS.	CONCLUSIONS
A possible association was also found with use during late pregnancy.	CONCLUSIONS

Chronic physical comorbidity is common in dementia.	OBJECTIVE
However, there is an absence of evidence to support good practice guidelines for attention to these problems.	OBJECTIVE
We aimed to study the extent of this comorbidity and its impact on cognitive function and disability in population-based studies in low and middle income countries, where chronic diseases and impairments are likely to be both common and undertreated.	OBJECTIVE
A multicentre cross-sectional survey of all over 65 year old residents (n = 15 022) in 11 catchment areas in China, India, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Venezuela, Mexico and Peru.	METHODS
We estimated the prevalence of pain, incontinence, hearing and visual impairments, mobility impairment and undernutrition according to the presence of dementia and its severity, and, among those with dementia, the independent contribution of these impairments to cognitive function and disability, adjusting for age, gender, education and dementia severity.	METHODS
Incontinence, hearing impairment, mobility impairment and undernutrition were consistently linearly associated with the presence of dementia and its severity across regions.	RESULTS
Among people with dementia, incontinence, hearing impairment and mobility impairment were independently associated with disability in all regions while the contributions of pain, visual impairment and undernutrition were inconsistent.	RESULTS
Only hearing impairment made a notable independent contribution to cognitive impairment.	RESULTS
There is an urgent need for clinical trials of the feasibility, efficacy and cost-effectiveness of regular physical health checks and remediation of identified pathologies, given the considerable comorbidity identified in our population based studies, and the strong evidence for independent impact upon functioning.	CONCLUSIONS

Recent studies show that COPD patients exhibit low-grade systemic inflammation, and that plasma fibrinogen and high neutrophil counts are related to faster declines in lung function.	BACKGROUND
We examined correlations between serum biomarkers and the decline of lung function in COPD patients.	BACKGROUND
Baseline levels of 9 serum biomarkers (TIMP-1, alpha1-antitrypsin, MMP-9, TNF-alpha, TGF-beta, IL-6, IL-8, neutrophil elastase and CRP), fibrinogen and white blood cell counts (WCC) were measured in 96 COPD patients.	METHODS
Lung function was measured at the time of blood sampling and every 3-6 months during the observation period (median 25.0 months).	METHODS
Twenty patients were rapid decliners of lung function and 53 patients were non-decliners.	RESULTS
Neutrophil counts, serum CRP and MMP-9 were significantly higher in the rapid decliners (p<0.05).	RESULTS
The annual change of % predicted FEV(1) was inversely correlated with MMP-9 (r=-0.288; p<0.01) and CRP (r=-0.354; p<0.005) (partial correlation coefficients adjusted for age, sex, cardiovascular disease, smoking history, and baseline % predicted FEV(1)).	RESULTS
The remaining biomarkers were not correlated with the annual change of % predicted FEV(1).	RESULTS
Serum CRP and MMP-9 levels were related to FEV(1) decline.	CONCLUSIONS
These markers are good candidates as predictors for rapid decline of FEV(1) in COPD patients.	CONCLUSIONS
Additional long-term and larger size studies of COPD patients could help determine the exact roles for these biomarkers.	CONCLUSIONS

Patients considered for arterial surgery, have been shown to have a high incidence of coexistent cardiac, vascular and other diseases, affecting operative risk and survival.	BACKGROUND
We developed a systematic workup strategy for detecting these coexistent diseases in our vascular surgical patients, mainly based on non-invasive diagnostic techniques.	BACKGROUND
We evaluated 200 consecutive patients, admitted to the department of vascular surgery in an academic teaching hospital, in order to establish the total incidence of relevant concomitant disorders, the extent to which this screening yielded previously unknown diagnostic information, and the impact on short-term (one year) survival.	METHODS
Coronary artery disease was present in 46% of the patients; 22% had active ischaemia, newly diagnosed in 5.5%.	RESULTS
Impaired cardiac function was found in 37%: severely impaired in 12%, newly diagnosed in 27%.	RESULTS
Carotid artery disease was present in 32%: critical stenoses were found in 9%; new diagnoses in 29.9%.	RESULTS
Aortic aneurysms were present in 7%, newly diagnosed in 5%.	RESULTS
Severe renal artery stenosis was present in 5%, newly diagnosed in 3.5%.	RESULTS
Sixteen % of the patients had chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, newly diagnosed in 3.5%, and 4.5% had unexpected disorders, which were all new diagnoses.	RESULTS
Overall, new diagnoses were reached in 64.5% of the population, affecting therapeutic strategy immediately in 21% of the patients.	RESULTS
The presence of coronary artery disease and of cardiac failure were clearly related to one year survival.	RESULTS
We conclude that a systematic screening strategy, mainly based on noninvasive techniques, can detect the presence of concomitant diseases in the vascular surgical patient.	CONCLUSIONS
Most important seem the newly diagnosed diseases altering surgical management in one out of every five patients; they also have important implications for patient prognosis.	CONCLUSIONS

To assess if family care givers of patients with lung cancer experience the patterns of social, psychological, and spiritual wellbeing and distress typical of the patient, from diagnosis to death.	OBJECTIVE
Secondary analysis of serial qualitative interviews carried out every three months for up to a year or to bereavement.	METHODS
South east Scotland.	METHODS
19 patients with lung cancer and their 19 family carers, totalling 88 interviews (42 with patients and 46 with carers).	METHODS
Carers followed clear patterns of social, psychological, and spiritual wellbeing and distress that mirrored the experiences of those for whom they were caring, with some carers also experiencing deterioration in physical health that impacted on their ability to care.	RESULTS
Psychological and spiritual distress were particularly dynamic and commonly experienced.	RESULTS
In addition to the "Why us?" response, witnessing suffering triggered personal reflections in carers on the meaning and purpose of life.	RESULTS
Certain key time points in the illness tended to be particularly problematic for both carers and patients: at diagnosis, at home after initial treatment, at recurrence, and during the terminal stage.	RESULTS
Family carers witness and share much of the illness experience of the dying patient.	CONCLUSIONS
The multidimensional experience of distress suffered by patients with lung cancer was reflected in the suffering of their carers in the social, psychological, and spiritual domains, with psychological and spiritual distress being most pronounced.	CONCLUSIONS
Carers may need to be supported throughout the period of illness not just in the terminal phase and during bereavement, as currently tends to be the case.	CONCLUSIONS

Patient experience is increasingly used to assess organizational performance, for example in public reporting or pay-for-performance schemes.	BACKGROUND
Conventional approaches using 95% confidence intervals are commonly used to determine required survey samples or to report performance but these may result in unreliable organizational comparisons.	BACKGROUND
We analyzed data from 2.2 million patients who responded to the English 2009 General Practice Patient Survey, which included 45 patient experience questions nested within 6 different care domains (access, continuity of care, communication, anticipatory care planning, out-of-hours care, and overall care satisfaction).	METHODS
For each question, unadjusted and case-mix adjusted (for age, sex, and ethnicity) organization-level reliability, and intraclass correlation coefficients were calculated.	METHODS
Mean responses per organization ranged from 23 to 256 for questions evaluating primary care practices, and from 1454 to 2758 for questions evaluating out-of-hours care organizations.	RESULTS
Adjusted and unadjusted reliability values were similar.	RESULTS
Twenty-six questions had excellent reliability (≥0.90).	RESULTS
Seven nurse communication questions had very good reliability (≥0.85), but 3 anticipatory care planning questions had lower reliability (<0.70).	RESULTS
Reliability was typically <0.70 for questions with <100 mean responses per practice, usually indicating questions which only a subset of patients were eligible to answer.	RESULTS
Nine questions had both excellent reliability and high intraclass correlation coefficients (≥0.10) indicating both reliable measurement and substantial performance variability.	RESULTS
High reliability is a necessary property of indicators used to compare health care organizations.	CONCLUSIONS
Using the English General Practice Patient Survey as a case study, we show how reliability and intraclass correlation coefficients can be used to select measures to support robust organizational comparisons, and to design surveys that will both provide high-quality measurement and optimize survey costs.	CONCLUSIONS

To determine the frequency of moderate and severe hypoglycemia and to identify clinical predictors associated with its occurrence in a large population-based sample of children and adolescents with IDDM.	OBJECTIVE
A total of 657 patients (age: 12.1 +/-	METHODS
4.4 years, mean +/-	METHODS
SD) were included in the study, yielding 1,449 patient-years of data.	METHODS
A prospective assessment of severe hypoglycemia (an event resulting in a seizure or coma) and moderate hypoglycemia (an event requiring assistance of another, excluding severe episodes) was made over a 3-year period.	METHODS
Patients and caregivers detailed episodes of significant hypoglycemia (moderate and severe events) and these were recorded at each 3-month clinic visit along with HbA1c.	METHODS
Data were analyzed using generalized estimating equation models fitted with the exchange correlation structure.	METHODS
The overall incidence of severe events was 4.8/100 patient-years and of moderate events was 13.1/100 patient-years.	RESULTS
Over 3 years, severe events occurred in 8.5% of children and moderate events occurred in 26.9%.	RESULTS
Significant hypoglycemia was rare in the first 12 months after diagnosis.	RESULTS
Rates of hypoglycemia were increased in children < 6 years of age versus > 6 years of age (40.9 vs. 16.6/100 patient-years, age < or = 6 years vs. age > 6 years, P < 0.001).	RESULTS
Rates of hypoglycemia doubled when HbA1c fell below 8%, and children with HbA1c < 7% had a threefold increase in both moderate and severe hypoglycemia (e.g., severe episodes 14.9 vs. 4.1/100 patient-years, HbA1c < or = 7% vs. HbA1c > 7%, P < 0.001).	RESULTS
Most severe events were seizures, and 75% of them occurred at night.	RESULTS
The majority of events were related to missed meals or increased activity.	RESULTS
However, in 38% no predisposing factor was evident.	RESULTS
Newly diagnosed children appear to be protected from severe hypoglycemia.	CONCLUSIONS
Rates increase with lower glycated hemoglobin, especially when mean HbA1c is < 8.0%.	CONCLUSIONS
Younger children, who may be more susceptible to the adverse effects of neuroglycopenia, are at a particular risk of significant hypoglycemia.	CONCLUSIONS

The association between the deficiency in mismatch repair (MMR) genes and prognosis in women with endometrial cancer is unclear.	BACKGROUND
Here we report a systematic review and meta-analysis exploring this association.	BACKGROUND
We searched literature databases (MEDLINE, EMBASE, and Cochrane) from 1980 until December 2011 to identify studies evaluating the association between MMR status and clinical outcome in endometrial cancer.	METHODS
The main outcome measures were overall survival (OS) and disease-free survival (DFS).	METHODS
Twenty-three studies met the inclusion criteria.	RESULTS
The median sample size of studies was 112, 74% were retrospective case-series and 70% performed microsatellite instability (MSI) analysis to evaluate the status of MMR.	RESULTS
Only 22% of studies used the panel of five microsatellite markers recommended by the National Cancer Institute.	RESULTS
Seven studies used immunohistochemistry to define MMR deficiency, but only two of them determined the expression of all four MMR proteins.	RESULTS
Overall, significant associations between MMR and outcome were observed in 32% of studies.	RESULTS
There was marked inter-study heterogeneity for estimates of OS and DFS.	RESULTS
Pooled analysis did not show any significant association between deficiency in MMR and worse OS (6 studies, hazard ratio [HR] 2.0, p=0.11) or DFS (4 studies, HR ratio 1.31, p=0.66).	RESULTS
There is no definitive evidence of a significant association between MMR status and detrimental survival in endometrial cancer.	CONCLUSIONS

To investigate the overall occurrence and relationship of genetic alterations in the phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K)/Akt pathway in thyroid tumors and explore the scope of this pathway as a therapeutic target for thyroid cancer.	OBJECTIVE
We examined collectively the major genetic alterations and their relationship in this pathway, including PIK3CA copy number gain and mutation, Ras mutation, and PTEN mutation, in a large series of primary thyroid tumors.	METHODS
Occurrence of any of these genetic alterations was found in 25 of 81 (31%) benign thyroid adenoma (BTA), 47 of 86 (55%) follicular thyroid cancer (FTC), 21 of 86 (24%) papillary thyroid cancer (PTC), and 29 of 50 (58%) anaplastic thyroid cancer (ATC), with FTC and ATC most frequently harboring these genetic alterations.	RESULTS
PIK3CA copy gain was associated with increased PIK3CA protein expression.	RESULTS
A mutual exclusivity among these genetic alterations was seen in BTA, FTC, and PTC, suggesting an independent role of each of them through the PI3K/Akt pathway in the tumorigenesis of the differentiated thyroid tumors.	RESULTS
However, coexistence of these genetic alterations was increasingly seen with progression from differentiated tumor to undifferentiated ATC.	RESULTS
Their coexistence with BRAF mutation was also frequent in PTC and ATC.	RESULTS
The data provide strong genetic implication that aberrant activation of PI3K/Akt pathway plays an extensive role in thyroid tumorigenesis, particularly in FTC and ATC, and promotes progression of BTA to FTC and to ATC as the genetic alterations of this pathway accumulate.	CONCLUSIONS
Progression of PTC to ATC may be facilitated by coexistence of PI3K/Akt pathway-related genetic alterations and BRAF mutation.	CONCLUSIONS
The PI3K/Akt pathway may thus be a major therapeutic target in thyroid cancers.	CONCLUSIONS

Control of blood pressure (BP) following renal transplantation may improve allograft and patient survival.	BACKGROUND
Our aims were (i) to describe the distribution of BP and the prevalence of systolic and/or diastolic hypertension in children over the first 5 years following renal transplantation and (ii) to evaluate clinical risk factors and centre-specific factors associated with hypertension in this population.	BACKGROUND
