Ninety-three patients were randomized into a comprehensive group, a ziwuliuzhu group and a prozac group, 31 cases in each group.	METHODS
In the ziwuliuzhu group, acupuncture was applied to the acupoints based on ziwuliuzhu, once a day, 5 times in a week.	METHODS
In the prozac group, fluoxertine hydrochloride (prozac) was prescribed for oral administration, once a day, 20 mg each time.	METHODS
In the comprehensive group, acupuncture based on ziwuliuzhu combined with the oral administration of prozac were adopted and the treatment frequency was the same as the ziwuliuzhu group and the prozac group.	METHODS
The 4-week treatment was taken as one session in the three groups and 6 sessions were required totally.	METHODS
The clinical efficacy and the Hamilton depression rating scale (HAMD) score and the adverse reaction were compared among the 3 groups.	METHODS
The total effective rate was 96.8% (30/31) in the comprehensive group, better than 83.9% (26/31) in the ziwuliuzhu group and 80.	RESULTS
6% (25/31) in the prozac group (both P<0.05).	RESULTS
In 4, 12 and 24 weeks of treatment, HAMD score was lower significantly than that before the treatment in the three groups (all P<0.05), and the score in the comprehensive group at each time point after treatment was lower than the other two groups (all P<0.05).	RESULTS
In 4 and 12 weeks of treatment, there were not different significantly between the ziwuliuzhu group and the prozac group (both P>0.05).	RESULTS
In 24 weeks of treatment, HAMD score in the ziwuliuzhu group was lower than that in the prozac group (P<0.05).	RESULTS
For the adverse reaction, there were 2 cases in the comprehensive group, 6 cases in the prozac group and 0 case in the ziwzuliuzhu group.	RESULTS
The comprehensive therapy of acupuncture at the acupoints based on ziwuliuzhu and oral administration of prozac is superior to either the simple oral administration of prozac or the ziwuliuzhu acu-puncture in terms of clinical efficacy and the improvements in depressive state.	CONCLUSIONS
Regarding the clinical efficacy, the impact of simple ziwuliuzhu acupuncture is not different significantly as compared with the simple oral administration of prozac, but it is better than the simple oral administration of prozac in terms of the long-term HAMD score and safety.	CONCLUSIONS

The Diabetes Prevention Program (DPP) is a 27-center randomized clinical trial designed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of interventions that may delay or prevent development of diabetes in people at increased risk for type 2 diabetes.	OBJECTIVE
Eligibility requirements were age > or = 25 years, BMI > or = 24 kg/m2 (> or = 22 kg/m2 for Asian-Americans), and impaired glucose tolerance plus a fasting plasma glucose of 5.3-6.9 mmol/l (or < or = 6.9 mmol for American Indians).	METHODS
Randomization of participants into the DPP over 2.7 years ended in June 1999.	METHODS
Baseline data for the three treatment groups--intensive lifestyle modification, standard care plus metformin, and standard care plus placebo--are presented for the 3,234 participants who have been randomized.	METHODS
Of all participants	RESULTS
, 55% were Caucasian, 20% were African-American, 16% were Hispanic, 5% were American Indian, and 4% were Asian-American.	RESULTS
Their average age at entry was 51 +/-	RESULTS
10.7 years (mean +/-	RESULTS
SD), and 67.7% were women.	RESULTS
Moreover, 16% were < 40 years of age, and 20% were > or = 60 years of age.	RESULTS
Of the women, 48% were postmenopausal.	RESULTS
Men and women had similar frequencies of history of hypercholesterolemia (37 and 33%, respectively) or hypertension (29 and 26%, respectively).	RESULTS
On the basis of fasting lipid determinations, 54% of men and 40% of women fit National Cholesterol Education Program criteria for abnormal lipid profiles.	RESULTS
More men than women were current or former cigarette smokers or had a history of coronary heart disease.	RESULTS
Furthermore, 66% of men and 71% of women had a first-degree relative with diabetes.	RESULTS
Overall, BMI averaged 34.0 +/-	RESULTS
6.7 kg/m2 at baseline with 57% of the men and 73% of women having a BMI > or = 30 kg/m2.	RESULTS
Average fasting plasma glucose (6.0 +/-	RESULTS
0.5 mmol/l) and HbA1c (5.9 +/-	RESULTS
0.5%) in men were comparable with values in women (5.9 +/- 0.4 mmol/l and 5.9 +/-	RESULTS
0.5%, respectively).	RESULTS
The DPP has successfully randomized a large cohort of participants with a wide distribution of age, obesity, and ethnic and racial backgrounds who are at high risk for developing type 2 diabetes.	CONCLUSIONS
The study will examine the effects of interventions on the development of diabetes.	CONCLUSIONS

& AIMS Helicobacter pylori is an important etiologic factor in the development of gastric cancer.	BACKGROUND
The aim of this study was to analyze the role of H. pylori infections in the induction of mutagenic events in gastric epithelial cells.	BACKGROUND
The effect of a high-salt diet as a genotoxic risk factor was also investigated.	BACKGROUND
Big Blue transgenic male mice (C57Bl/6) were inoculated with H. pylori (strain SS1) or Helicobacter felis (strain CS1) for 6 and 12 months.	METHODS
The frequency and spectrum of mutations at the stomach level were assessed.	METHODS
Inflammatory host response and inducible nitric oxide synthase (iNOS) expression by reverse-transcription polymerase chain reaction and immunohistochemistry analysis were also performed.	METHODS
After 6 months, the gastric mutant frequency was 4-fold and 1.7-fold higher in mice infected with H. pylori and H. felis, respectively, than in uninfected mice.	RESULTS
It was associated with a high frequency of transversions (AT --> CG and GC --> TA) known to result from oxidative damages.	RESULTS
The Helicobacter-infected mice exhibited severe gastritis and a high level of iNOS messenger RNA expression.	RESULTS
Hyperplasia developed 12 months after inoculation, and both the mutagenic effects and iNOS expression decreased in H. pylori- and H. felis-infected mice.	RESULTS
No synergistic effects of a high-salt diet and Helicobacter infection were observed regarding the frequency of gastric mutation.	RESULTS
A direct gastric mutagenic effect due to H. pylori infection in the Big Blue transgenic mouse model has been shown 6 months after inoculation.	CONCLUSIONS
This genotoxicity can be attributable to oxidative DNA damage involving the inflammatory host response.	CONCLUSIONS

The absolute risk of fractures in renal transplant patients is 3 times that of matched controls.	BACKGROUND
Most of the symptomatic fractures are peripheral, suggesting a greater compromise of cortical bone.	BACKGROUND
Peripheral quantitative computed tomography (pQCT) is a new imaging technique that allows separate noninvasive evaluations of cortical and trabecular bones.	BACKGROUND
We investigated cortical bone by pQCT in 12 renal transplant patients (seven men and five women) for comparison with 27 normal controls.	BACKGROUND
pQCT (XCT 960, Stratec, Pforheim, Germany) was performed upon the distal radius of the nondominant forearm (15% the length of the ulna, proximal from the radius end plate).	METHODS
We evaluated total and cortical bone mineral density (TBMD, cBMD), total (cross-sectional) and cortical area (TA, cA), cortical thickness (cThk), endosteal and periosteal circumferences, and the buckling ratio (r/cThK).	METHODS
Compared with normal controls transplant patients as a whole showed a significant increase in TA, in endosteal circumference (P < .001), and in the buckling ratio (P < .001) with a significant reduction in cThK (P < .001).	RESULTS
Female patients had a marked decrease in cA (51.4 vs 69.3 [pixel n]; P < .0001) and cThK (2.08 vs 2.78 mm; P < .0001).	RESULTS
Male patients also had a decrease in cThK (2.54 vs 3.30 mm; P = .0001) and an increase in endosteal perimeter (31.2 vs 26.4 mm; P < .0001).	RESULTS
Total time on dialysis prior to renal graft correlated negatively with cortical thickness (r = .62; P < .01).	RESULTS
Our results suggest that a marked thinning of cortical bone may explain the increased incidence of peripheral fractures among renal transplant patients.	CONCLUSIONS

The combination of ataxia and hypogonadism was first described more than a century ago, but its genetic basis has remained elusive.	BACKGROUND
We performed whole-exome sequencing in a patient with ataxia and hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, followed by targeted sequencing of candidate genes in similarly affected patients.	METHODS
Neurologic and reproductive endocrine phenotypes were characterized in detail.	METHODS
The effects of sequence variants and the presence of an epistatic interaction were tested in a zebrafish model.	METHODS
Digenic homozygous mutations in RNF216 and OTUD4, which encode a ubiquitin E3 ligase and a deubiquitinase, respectively, were found in three affected siblings in a consanguineous family.	RESULTS
Additional screening identified compound heterozygous truncating mutations in RNF216 in an unrelated patient and single heterozygous deleterious mutations in four other patients.	RESULTS
Knockdown of rnf216 or otud4 in zebrafish embryos induced defects in the eye, optic tectum, and cerebellum; combinatorial suppression of both genes exacerbated these phenotypes, which were rescued by nonmutant, but not mutant, human RNF216 or OTUD4 messenger RNA.	RESULTS
All patients had progressive ataxia and dementia.	RESULTS
Neuronal loss was observed in cerebellar pathways and the hippocampus; surviving hippocampal neurons contained ubiquitin-immunoreactive intranuclear inclusions.	RESULTS
Defects were detected at the hypothalamic and pituitary levels of the reproductive endocrine axis.	RESULTS
The syndrome of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, ataxia, and dementia can be caused by inactivating mutations in RNF216 or by the combination of mutations in RNF216 and OTUD4.	CONCLUSIONS
These findings link disordered ubiquitination to neurodegeneration and reproductive dysfunction and highlight the power of whole-exome sequencing in combination with functional studies to unveil genetic interactions that cause disease.	CONCLUSIONS
(Funded by the National Institutes of Health and others.).	CONCLUSIONS

Aspirin is widely used for relief of pain and for cardioprotective effects.	BACKGROUND
Its use is of concern to ophthalmologists when ocular surgery is being considered and also in the presence of age-related macular degeneration (AMD).	BACKGROUND
To examine the association of regular aspirin use with incidence of AMD.	OBJECTIVE
DESIGN, SETTING, AND PARTICIPANTS The Beaver Dam Eye Study, a longitudinal population-based study of age-related eye diseases conducted in Wisconsin.	OBJECTIVE
Examinations were performed every 5 years over a 20-year period (1988-1990 through 2008-2010).	OBJECTIVE
Study participants (N = 4926) were aged 43 to 86 years at the baseline examination.	OBJECTIVE
At subsequent examinations, participants were asked if they had regularly used aspirin at least twice a week for more than 3 months.	OBJECTIVE
Incidence of early AMD, late AMD, and 2 subtypes of late AMD (neovascular AMD and pure geographic atrophy), assessed in retinal photographs according to the Wisconsin Age-Related Maculopathy Grading System.	METHODS
The mean duration of follow-up was 14.8 years.	RESULTS
There were 512 incident cases of early AMD (of 6243 person-visits at risk) and 117 incident cases of late AMD (of 8621 person-visits at risk) over the course of the study.	RESULTS
Regular aspirin use 10 years prior to retinal examination was associated with late AMD (hazard ratio [HR], 1.63 [95% CI, 1.01-2.63]; P = .05), with estimated incidence of 1.76% (95% CI, 1.17%-2.64%) in regular users and 1.03% (95% CI, 0.70%-1.51%) in nonusers.	RESULTS
For subtypes of late AMD, regular aspirin use 10 years prior to retinal examination was significantly associated with neovascular AMD (HR, 2.20 [95% CI, 1.20-4.15]; P = .01) but not pure geographic atrophy (HR, 0.66 [95% CI, 0.25-1.95]; P = .45).	RESULTS
Aspirin use 5 years (HR, 0.86 [95% CI, 0.71-1.05]; P = .13) or 10 years (HR, 0.86 [95% CI, 0.65-1.13]; P = .28) prior to retinal examination was not associated with incident early AMD.	RESULTS
Among an adult cohort, aspirin use 5 years prior to observed incidence was not associated with incident early or late AMD.	CONCLUSIONS
However, regular aspirin use 10 years prior was associated with a small but statistically significant increase in the risk of incident late and neovascular AMD.	CONCLUSIONS

To describe a naturally occurring X-linked recessive mutation, no b-wave (nob), that compromises visual transmission between photoreceptors and second-order neurons in mice.	OBJECTIVE
Affected mice were identified by recording the light-evoked response of the retina, the electroretinogram (ERG).	METHODS
To evaluate visual transmission, cortical potentials were recorded with a scalp electrode.	METHODS
The inheritance pattern for nob was defined by breeding nob animals with normal mice.	METHODS
Retinal histologic analysis was performed by light microscopy.	METHODS
Although the photoreceptor-mediated ERG component (a-wave) was normal in nob mice, the major response component reflecting postreceptoral neuronal activity (b-wave) was missing.	RESULTS
Visually-driven cortical activity was also abnormal in nob animals.	RESULTS
At the light microscopic level, the nob retina appeared to have a normal cytoarchitecture.	RESULTS
These findings suggest that the nob defect interferes with the transmission of visual information through the retina and that these mice are a useful model for the study of outer retinal synaptic function.	CONCLUSIONS
In addition, this mutant mouse seems to provide an animal model for the complete form of congenital stationary night blindness, a human disorder in which patients have a profound loss of rod-mediated visual sensitivity.	CONCLUSIONS

Interleukin (IL)-17F, produced in IL-23R-expressing Th17 cells, is a novel member of the IL-17 cytokine family.	BACKGROUND
Given the association of IL23R with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), we characterized the role of IL-17F in IBD including its intestinal gene expression and the effect of the IL17F p.	BACKGROUND
His161Arg polymorphism on disease susceptibility and phenotype of Crohn's disease (CD) and ulcerative colitis (UC).	BACKGROUND
In addition, we analyzed the IL17F p.	BACKGROUND
His161Arg polymorphism for potential epistasis with IL23R and NOD2/CARD15 variants.	BACKGROUND
Intestinal IL-17F mRNA expression was measured by quantitative polymerase chain reaction (PCR).	METHODS
Genomic DNA from 1682 individuals (CD: n = 499; UC: n = 216; controls: n = 967) was analyzed for the presence of the IL17F p.	METHODS
His161Arg polymorphism, the 3 NOD2 variants, p.	METHODS
Arg702Trp, p.	METHODS
Gly908Arg, and p.	METHODS
Leu1007fsX1008, and 10 CD-associated IL23R variants.	METHODS
Intestinal IL-17F mRNA expression was 4.4-fold increased in inflamed colonic lesions compared to uninflamed biopsies in CD (P = 0.016) but not in UC.	RESULTS
However, the mean intestinal IL-17F mRNA expression was higher in UC than in CD (P < 0.0001).	RESULTS
The IL17F p.	RESULTS
His161Arg substitution was observed with similar frequencies in IBD patients and controls and was not associated with a certain disease phenotype, but weakly associated with a low body mass index (BMI; P = 0.009) and an earlier age of disease onset (P = 0.039) in UC.	RESULTS
There was no evidence for epistasis between the IL17F p.	RESULTS
His161Arg polymorphism and IBD-associated single nucleotide polymorphisms within the IL23R gene.	RESULTS
Intestinal IL17F gene expression is increased in active CD.	CONCLUSIONS
The IL17F p.	CONCLUSIONS
His161Arg polymorphism is not associated with IBD susceptibility and has no epistatic interaction with CD-associated IL23R variants.	CONCLUSIONS

The value of HER-2/neu status as a predictor of response to anthracycline-based chemotherapy is still a matter of debate.	OBJECTIVE
We evaluated the contribution of HER-2/neu gene amplification and other biologic markers in predicting response to different doses of neoadjuvant anthracycline-based chemotherapy.	OBJECTIVE
Clinical and pathologic records of 115 primary breast cancer patients were reviewed.	METHODS
Forty-eight and 67 patients received high (doxorubicin > or =20 mg/m2/wk; epirubicin > or =30 mg/m2/wk) and moderate-low anthracycline dose intensity regimens, respectively.	METHODS
Pathologic diagnosis, hormonal receptor status (HR), Ki67, and HER-2/neu status were assessed on tumor samples before neoadjuvant chemotherapy.	METHODS
HER-2/neu was determined by fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH).	METHODS
HER-2/neu amplification was observed in 29/115 (25%) tumors, 18 from moderate-low-dose and 11 from high-dose group.	RESULTS
In the univariate analysis, a high Ki67 index (> or =20%) and positive clinical axillary nodes were predictive of an objective tumor response (P = 0.033 and 0.001, respectively).	RESULTS
In the multivariate analysis, Ki67 was the only factor predictive of response (OR = 3.08, 95% CI = 1.1-8.5, P = 0.03).	RESULTS
HER-2/neu status was not a factor in predicting objective response to different anthracycline dose intensities.	RESULTS
The same finding was observed with regards to HR and Ki67.	RESULTS
In our series, no significant dose-response relationship was found according to HER-2/neu status.	CONCLUSIONS

The use of bisphosphonates for the prevention of skeletal related events in women with bone metastases from breast cancer is well established.	BACKGROUND
We undertook an evaluation of bisphosphonate use in clinical practice in three Canadian cancer centres.	BACKGROUND
In addition we assessed whether or not physicians at these centres are following their local treatment guidelines and funding policies.	BACKGROUND
Charts and electronic files of patients who had received either clodronate or pamidronate at any time between January 2000 and December 2001 at three Canadian cancer centres were retrospectively reviewed.	METHODS
There has been a marked improvement in the time between the diagnosis of bone metastases and the commencement of bisphosphonates from a median of 155 days in 1998 to 24 days in 2001.	RESULTS
However, despite a local funding policy requiring that oral clodronate be the first bisphosphonate used, this was the case in only 67% of patients.	RESULTS
In addition, despite one centre's guidelines recommending that bisphosphonates be stopped once the patient was progressing, 90% of their patients remained on bisphosphonates until they died.	RESULTS
A considerable amount of effort is spent on the creation of "evidence based" treatment guidelines.	CONCLUSIONS
Funding agencies develop policies based on these treatment guidelines, but often funding is more restrictive than the treatment guideline would suggest.	CONCLUSIONS
It is clear from this review that physicians still appear to manage a substantial proportion of patients outside of funding policies, but within evidence based recommendations.	CONCLUSIONS
Therefore, a need exists for either the creation of guidelines and policies that physicians will follow or the implementation of methods to ensure that restrictive policies are actually followed.	CONCLUSIONS

To demonstrate the relation of exercise capacity and BMI to mortality in a population of male veterans with type 2 diabetes.	OBJECTIVE
After excluding two underweight patients (BMI <18.5 kg/m2), the study population comprised 831 consecutive patients with type 2 diabetes (mean age 61 +/-	METHODS
9 years) referred for exercise testing for clinical reasons between 1995 and 2006.	METHODS
Exercise capacity was determined from a maximal exercise test and measured in metabolic equivalents (METs).	METHODS
Patients were classified both according to BMI category (18.5-24.9, 25.0-29.9, and > or =30 kg/m2) and by exercise capacity (<5.0 or > or =5.0 maximal METs).	METHODS
The association among exercise capacity, BMI, other clinical variables, and all-cause mortality was assessed by Cox proportional hazards.	METHODS
Study participants were followed for mortality up to 30 June 2006.	METHODS
During a mean follow-up of 4.8 +/-	RESULTS
3.0 years, 112 patients died, for an average annual mortality rate of 2.2%.	RESULTS
Each 1-MET increase in exercise capacity conferred a 10% survival benefit (hazard ratio 0.90 [95% CI 0.82-0.98]; P = 0.01), but BMI was not significantly associated with mortality.	RESULTS
After adjustment for age, ethnicity, examination year, BMI, presence of cardiovascular disease (CVD), and CVD risk factors, diabetic patients achieving <5 maximal METs were 70% more likely to die (1.70 [1.13-2.54]) than those achieving > or =5 maximal METs.	RESULTS
There was a strong inverse association between exercise capacity and mortality in this cohort of men with documented diabetes, and this relationship was independent of BMI.	CONCLUSIONS

To determine the frequency of neurobehavioral signs and symptoms reported in every published case of traumatic encephalopathy with a view toward the development of clinical diagnostic criteria with predictive validity.	OBJECTIVE
Cases of persistent or progressive neurological or neurobehavioral change following exposure to one or more head injuries have been reported since 1928.	BACKGROUND
This condition is often referred to as traumatic encephalopathy (TE).	BACKGROUND
To date, however, no diagnostic criteria have been advanced or accepted for the clinical diagnosis of TE.	BACKGROUND
Provisional research diagnostic criteria are required not only for meaningful diagnosis but also to facilitate research to determine the epidemiology, etiology, course, prognosis, imaging and biomarkers, neuropathological features and potentially effective treatments of TE.	BACKGROUND
All 436 published cases of TE in all languages were reviewed.	METHODS
All symptoms and signs reported in these cases were classified and enumerated.	METHODS
Ninety-seven cases met inclusion criteria based on sufficient documentation of the history and neurobehavioral examination.	RESULTS
Provisional research diagnostic criteria for clinically probable and clinically possible TE were developed based on the most frequently reported clinical features.	RESULTS
The provisional diagnostic criteria for TE presented here are the first published criteria for this condition based upon a systematic analysis of its clinical characteristics.	CONCLUSIONS
This is the first a step toward scientifically derived consensus criteria, which are essential to accelerate progress in the investigation of this important condition.	CONCLUSIONS

In patients with unstable coronary artery disease, there is a relation between the short-term risk of death and blood levels of troponin T (a marker of myocardial damage) and C-reactive protein and fibrinogen (markers of inflammation).	BACKGROUND
Using information obtained during an extension of the follow-up period in the Fragmin during Instability in Coronary Artery Disease trial, we evaluated the usefulness of troponin T, C-reactive protein, and fibrinogen levels and other indicators of risk as predictors of the long-term risk of death from cardiac causes.	BACKGROUND
Levels of C-reactive protein and fibrinogen at enrollment and the maximal level of troponin T during the first 24 hours after enrollment were analyzed in 917 patients included in a clinical trial of low-molecular-weight heparin in unstable coronary artery disease.	METHODS
The patients were followed for a mean of 37.0 months (range, 1.6 to 50.6).	METHODS
During follow-up, 1.2 percent of the 173 patients with maximal blood troponin T levels of less than 0.06 microg per liter died of cardiac causes, as compared with 8.7 percent of the 367 patients with levels of 0.06 to 0.59 microg per liter and 15.4 percent of the 377 patients with levels of at least 0.60 microg per liter (P=0.007 and P=0.001, respectively).	RESULTS
The rates of death from cardiac causes were 5.7 percent among the 314 patients with blood C-reactive protein levels of less than 2 mg per liter, 7.8 percent among the 294 with levels of 2 to 10 mg per liter, and 16.5 percent among the 309 with levels of more than 10 mg per liter (P=0.29 and P=0.001, respectively).	RESULTS
The rates of death from cardiac causes were 5.4 percent among the 314 patients with blood fibrinogen levels of less than 3.4 g per liter, 12.0 percent among the 300 with levels of 3.4 to 3.9 g per liter, and 12.9 percent among the 303 with levels of at least 4.0 g per liter (P=0.004 and P=0.69, respectively).	RESULTS
In a multivariate analysis, levels of troponin T and C-reactive protein were independent predictors of the risk of death from cardiac causes.	RESULTS
In unstable coronary artery disease, elevated levels of troponin T and C-reactive protein are strongly related to the long-term risk of death from cardiac causes.	CONCLUSIONS
These markers are independent risk factors, and their effects are additive with respect to each other and other clinical indicators of risk.	CONCLUSIONS

To conduct an economic analysis of the Hlabisa community-based directly observed therapy management strategy for tuberculosis and to project costs of three alternative strategies.	OBJECTIVE
Hlabisa health district, KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa.	METHODS
An economic analysis comparing the current tuberculosis management strategy in Hlabisa with three alternative strategies (the Hlabisa strategy prior to 1991 based on hospitalisation, the national strategy and sanatorium care) in terms of costs to both health service and patient and of cost-effectiveness.	METHODS
The current Hlabisa strategy was the most cost-effective (R3799 per patient cured), compared with R98307 for the strategy used prior to 1991, R9940 for the national strategy, and R11145 for sanatorium care.	RESULTS
Between 71% and 88% of treatment costs lie with the health service, and hospitalisation (R119 per day) is the most expensive item.	RESULTS
Prolonged hospitalisation is extremely expensive, but community care is cheaper (community clinic visit, R28; community health worker visit, R7).	RESULTS
The total cost of supervising a patient in the community under the current Hlabisa strategy was R503, equivalent to 4.2 days in hospital.	RESULTS
Drug costs (R157) are equivalent to just 1.3 days in hospital.	RESULTS
Cost to both health service and patient can be substantially reduced by using community-based directly observed therapy for tuberculosis, a strategy that is cheap and cost-effective in Hlabisa.	CONCLUSIONS
These findings have important national implications, supporting the goals of the new tuberculosis control programme.	CONCLUSIONS

The proinflammatory cytokine interleukin-18 (IL-18) putatively modulates food intake and energy metabolism, but the effects of IL-18 in high-fat diet fed animals are unknown.	OBJECTIVE
Whether IL-18 alters basal metabolic rate or metabolic processes of living is unknown.	OBJECTIVE
Here, we tested the hypothesis that IL-18 modulates weight gain, energy intake, whole-body energy expenditure, and utilization of lipid as a fuel substrate in high-fat diet fed mice.	OBJECTIVE
Food intake, whole-body metabolism, and motor activity of IL-18 knockout mice were compared to those of wildtype littermates; anorectic effects of intracerebroventricular IL-18 administration were compared between IL-18 receptor knockout, IL-18/IL-18R knockout and wildtype mice.	METHODS
Chow-reared IL-18 knockout mice were overweight at 6 months of age and then gained excess weight on both low-fat and high-fat diets, ate more high-fat diet, and showed reduced whole-body energy expenditure and increased respiratory exchange ratios.	RESULTS
Reductions in energy expenditure of IL-18 knockout mice were seen across fasting vs. feeding conditions, low- vs. high-fat diets, high vs. low levels of physical activity and times of day, suggesting actions on basal metabolic rate.	RESULTS
The circadian amplitude of energy expenditure, but not respiratory exchange ratio, food intake, or motor activity, also was blunted in IL-18 knockout mice.	RESULTS
Central IL-18 administration reduced high-fat diet intake in wildtype mice, but not in mice lacking the IL-18 receptor.	RESULTS
The loss-of-function results support the hypothesis that endogenous IL-18 suppresses appetite and promote energy expenditure and lipid fuel substrate utilization not only during sickness, but also in healthy adults consuming high-fat diets.	CONCLUSIONS

To describe the epidemiology of urban malaria, an emerging problem in sub-Saharan Africa.	OBJECTIVE
Cross-sectional surveys of communities in Accra and Kumasi, Ghana, determining risk factors for malaria infection and anaemia in children aged 6-60 months.	METHODS
Malaria prevalence rates ranged from 2% to 33% between urban communities.	RESULTS
47.1% of children were anaemic (Hb<11.0 g/dl).	RESULTS
Factors associated with malaria prevalence were low socio-economic status, age and anaemia.	RESULTS
The attributable risks of anaemia and severe anaemia (Hb<8.0 g/dl) caused by malaria were 5% and 23% respectively.	RESULTS
Malaria in urban areas displayed a heterogeneity and complexity that differed from the rural environment, which has important implications for malaria control.	CONCLUSIONS
Marked intra-city variation indicates the importance of targeting specific areas or districts.	CONCLUSIONS
The most vulnerable group, the urban poor, should be prioritized when designing control measures.	CONCLUSIONS
This would require careful assessment of the malaria risk pattern in any city to guide an integrated control program.	CONCLUSIONS

Delayed cerebral vasospasm causes permanent neurological deficits or death in at least 15% of patients following otherwise successful treatment for ruptured intracranial aneurysm.	BACKGROUND
Decreased bioavailability of nitric oxide has been associated with the development of cerebral vasospasm.	BACKGROUND
To determine whether infusions of nitrite will prevent delayed cerebral vasospasm.	OBJECTIVE
DESIGN, SETTING, AND SUBJECTS A total of 14 anesthetized cynomolgus monkeys had an autologous blood clot placed around the right middle cerebral artery.	OBJECTIVE
Cerebral arteriography was performed before clot placement and on days 7 and 14 to assess vasospasm.	OBJECTIVE
The study was conducted from August 2003 to February 2004.	OBJECTIVE
A 90-mg sodium nitrite intravenous solution infused over 24 hours plus a 45-mg sodium nitrite bolus daily (n = 3); a 180-mg sodium nitrite intravenous solution infused over 24 hours (n = 3); or a control saline solution infusion (n = 8).	METHODS
Each was infused continuously for 14 days.	METHODS
Nitrite, S-nitrosothiol, and methemoglobin levels in blood and cerebrospinal fluid and degree of arteriographic vasospasm.	METHODS
In control monkeys, mean (SD) cerebrospinal fluid nitrite levels decreased from 3.1 (1.5) micromol/L to 0.4 (0.1) micromol/L at day 7 and to 0.4 (0.4) micromol/L at day 14 (P = .03).	RESULTS
All 8 control monkeys developed significant vasospasm of the right middle cerebral artery, which was complicated by stroke and death in 1 animal.	RESULTS
Sodium nitrite infusions increased the nitrite and methemoglobin levels (<2.1% of total hemoglobin) in the blood and cerebrospinal fluid without evoking systemic hypotension.	RESULTS
Nitrite infusion prevented development of vasospasm (no animals developed significant vasospasm; mean [SD] reduction in right middle cerebral artery area on day 7 after subarachnoid hemorrhage of 8% [9%] in nitrite-treated monkeys vs 47% [5%] in saline-treated controls; P<.001).	RESULTS
There was a negative correlation between the concentration of nitrite in cerebrospinal fluid and the degree of cerebral vasospasm (P<.001).	RESULTS
Pharmacological effects of nitrite infusion were also associated with the formation of S-nitrosothiol in cerebrospinal fluid.	RESULTS
There was no clinical or pathological evidence of nitrite toxicity.	RESULTS
Subacute sodium nitrite infusions prevented delayed cerebral vasospasm in a primate model of subarachnoid hemorrhage.	CONCLUSIONS

Limited information exists regarding the role of left ventricular function in predicting exercise capacity and impact on age- and sex-related differences.	BACKGROUND
To determine the impact of measures of cardiac function assessed by echocardiography on exercise capacity and to determine if these associations are modified by sex or advancing age.	OBJECTIVE
Cross-sectional study of patients undergoing exercise echocardiography with routine measurements of left ventricular systolic and diastolic function by 2-dimensional and Doppler techniques.	METHODS
Analyses were conducted to determine the strongest correlates of exercise capacity and the age and sex interactions of these variables with exercise capacity.	METHODS
Large tertiary referral center in Rochester, Minnesota, in 2006.	METHODS
Patients undergoing exercise echocardiography using the Bruce protocol (N = 2867).	METHODS
Patients with echocardiographic evidence of exercise-induced ischemia, ejection fractions lower than 50%, or significant valvular heart disease were excluded.	METHODS
Exercise capacity in metabolic equivalents (METs).	METHODS
Diastolic dysfunction was strongly and inversely associated with exercise capacity.	RESULTS
Compared with normal function, after multivariate adjustment, those with moderate/severe resting diastolic dysfunction (-1.30 METs; 95% confidence interval [CI], -1.52 to -0.99; P < .001) and mild resting diastolic dysfunction (-0.70 METs; 95% CI, -0.88 to -0.46; P < .001) had substantially lower exercise capacity.	RESULTS
Variation of left ventricular systolic function within the normal range was not associated with exercise capacity.	RESULTS
Left ventricular filling pressures measured by resting E/e' of 15 or greater (-0.41 METs; 95% CI, -0.70 to -0.11; P = .007) or postexercise E/e' of 15 or greater (-0.41 METs; 95% CI, -0.71 to -0.11; P = .007) were similarly associated with a reduction in exercise capacity, each in separate multivariate analyses.	RESULTS
Individuals with impaired relaxation (mild dysfunction) or resting E/e' of 15 or greater had a progressive increase in the magnitude of reduction in exercise capacity with advancing age (P < .001 and P = .02, respectively).	RESULTS
Other independent correlates of exercise capacity were age (unstandardized beta coefficient, -0.85 METs; 95% CI, -0.92 to -0.77, per 10-year increment; P < .001), female sex (-1.98 METs; 95% CI, -2.15 to -1.84; P < .001), and body mass index greater than 30 (-1.24 METs; 95% CI, -1.41 to -1.10; P < .001).	RESULTS
In this large cross-sectional study of those referred for exercise echocardiography and not limited by ischemia, abnormalities of left ventricular diastolic function were independently associated with exercise capacity.	CONCLUSIONS

Peroxisome proliferator-activated receptors (PPAR) regulate lipid and glucose metabolism but their anticancer properties have been recently studied as well.	OBJECTIVE
We previously reported the antimetastatic activity of the PPARalpha ligand, fenofibrate, against melanoma tumors in vivo.	OBJECTIVE
Here we investigated possible molecular mechanisms of fenofibrate anti metastatic action.	OBJECTIVE
Monolayer cultures of mouse (B16F10) and human (SkMell88) melanoma cell lines, soft agar assay, and cell migration assay were used in this study.	METHODS
In addition, we analyzed PPARalpha expression and its transcriptional activity in response to fenotibrate by using Western blots and liciferase-based reporter system.	METHODS
Fenofibrate inhibited migration of B16F10 and SkMel188 cells in Transwell chambers and colony formation in soft agar.	RESULTS
These effects were reversed by PPAR inhibitor, GW9662.	RESULTS
Western blot analysis revealed time-dependent down-regulation of Akt and extracellular signal-regulated kinase l/2 phosphorylation in fenofibrate-treated cells.	RESULTS
A B16F10 cell line stably expressing constitutively active Akt mutant was resistant to fenofibrate.	RESULTS
In contrast, Akt gene silencing with siRNA mimicked the fenofibrate action and reduced the migratory ability of B16F1O cells.	RESULTS
In addition, fenofibrate strongly sensitized BI6FIO cells to the proapoptotic drug staurosporine, further supporting the possibility that fenofibrate-induced down-regulation of Akt function contributes to fenofibrate-mediated inhibition of metastatic potential in this experimental model.	RESULTS
Our results show that the PPAR-dependent antimetastatic activity of fenofibrate involves down-regulation of Akt phosphorylation and suggest that supplementation with this drug may improve the effectiveness of melanoma chemotherapy.	CONCLUSIONS

Corin has been suggested to be associated with hypertension by cell- and animal-based studies.	BACKGROUND
However, the association still lacks population-based evidence which critically promotes translation from basic research to clinical and preventive practice.	BACKGROUND
Here, we aimed to explore the association in a general population of China.	BACKGROUND
From January to May 2010, we conducted a cross-sectional study in 2,498 participants aged above 30 years, residing in Gusu district of Suzhou.	METHODS
Serum soluble corin and blood pressure were measured.	METHODS
Hypertensive participants had a higher level of serum corin than nonhypertensive participants (median (interquartile range): 1,836.83 (1,497.85-2,327.87) pg/ml vs. 1,579.14 (1,322.18-1,956.82) pg/ml, P < 0.001).	RESULTS
Higher serum corin was positively associated with prevalent hypertension (odds ratio (OR) = 2.01, P < 0.001).	RESULTS
In the multiple analysis, participants in the third (OR = 1.43, P = 0.007) and fourth (OR = 1.96, P < 0.001) quartiles had significantly increased odds of hypertension compared to those in the lowest quartile of serum corin.	RESULTS
ORs of hypertension positively and significantly increased with serum corin levels (P for trend <0.001).	RESULTS
Further subgroup analysis showed that ORs of hypertension associated with high corin (over the median level of serum corin: 1,689.20 pg/ml) were still significant in subgroups by age, body mass index, total cholesterol, low-density lipoprotein cholesterol, and fasting plasma glucose (all P < 0.05).	RESULTS
Our study showed that hypertensive participants had an increased serum corin level compared to those without hypertension.	CONCLUSIONS
This ﬁnding suggests that corin may play a role in the pathology of hypertension.	CONCLUSIONS

Two inflammatory disorders, type 1 diabetes and celiac disease, cosegregate in populations, suggesting a common genetic origin.	BACKGROUND
Since both diseases are associated with the HLA class II genes on chromosome 6p21, we tested whether non-HLA loci are shared.	BACKGROUND
We evaluated the association between type 1 diabetes and eight loci related to the risk of celiac disease by genotyping and statistical analyses of DNA samples from 8064 patients with type 1 diabetes, 9339 control subjects, and 2828 families providing 3064 parent-child trios (consisting of an affected child and both biologic parents).	METHODS
We also investigated 18 loci associated with type 1 diabetes in 2560 patients with celiac disease and 9339 control subjects.	METHODS
Three celiac disease loci--RGS1 on chromosome 1q31, IL18RAP on chromosome 2q12, and TAGAP on chromosome 6q25--were associated with type 1 diabetes (P<1.00x10(-4)).	RESULTS
The 32-bp insertion-deletion variant on chromosome 3p21 was newly identified as a type 1 diabetes locus (P=1.81x10(-8)) and was also associated with celiac disease, along with PTPN2 on chromosome 18p11 and CTLA4 on chromosome 2q33, bringing the total number of loci with evidence of a shared association to seven, including SH2B3 on chromosome 12q24.	RESULTS
The effects of the IL18RAP and TAGAP alleles confer protection in type 1 diabetes and susceptibility in celiac disease.	RESULTS
Loci with distinct effects in the two diseases included INS on chromosome 11p15, IL2RA on chromosome 10p15, and PTPN22 on chromosome 1p13 in type 1 diabetes and IL12A on 3q25 and LPP on 3q28 in celiac disease.	RESULTS
A genetic susceptibility to both type 1 diabetes and celiac disease shares common alleles.	CONCLUSIONS
These data suggest that common biologic mechanisms, such as autoimmunity-related tissue damage and intolerance to dietary antigens, may be etiologic features of both diseases.	CONCLUSIONS

To determine rates of suicide associated with pregnancy by the type of pregnancy.	OBJECTIVE
Register linkage study.	METHODS
Information on suicides in women of reproductive age was linked with the Finnish birth, abortion, and hospital discharge registers to find out how many women who committed suicide had had a completed pregnancy during her last year of life.	METHODS
Nationwide data from Finland.	METHODS
Women who committed suicide in 1987-94.	OBJECTIVE
There were 73 suicides associated with pregnancy, representing 5.4% of all suicides in women in this age group.	RESULTS
The mean annual suicide rate was 11.3 per 100,000.	RESULTS
The suicide rate associated with birth was significantly lower (5.9) and the rates associated with miscarriage (18.1) and induced abortion (34.7) were significantly higher than in the population.	RESULTS
The risk associated with birth was higher among teenagers and that associated with abortion was increased in all age groups.	RESULTS
Women who had committed a suicide tended to come from lower social classes and were more likely to be unmarried than other women who had had a completed pregnancy.	RESULTS
The increased risk of suicide after an induced abortion indicates either common risk factors for both or harmful effects of induced abortion on mental health.	CONCLUSIONS

To establish the mental health needs of homeless children and families before and after rehousing.	OBJECTIVE
Cross sectional, longitudinal study.	METHODS
City of Birmingham.	METHODS
58 rehoused families with 103 children aged 2-16 years and 21 comparison families of low socioeconomic status in stable housing, with 54 children.	OBJECTIVE
Children's mental health problems and level of communication; mothers' mental health problems and social support one year after rehousing.	METHODS
Mental health problems remained significantly higher in rehoused mothers and their children than in the comparison group (mothers 26% v 5%, P = 0.04; children 39% v 11%, P = 0.0003).	RESULTS
Homeless mothers continued to have significantly less social support at follow up.	RESULTS
Mothers with a history of abuse and poor social integration were more likely to have children with persistent mental health problems.	RESULTS
Homeless families have a high level of complex needs that cannot be met by conventional health services and arrangements.	CONCLUSIONS
Local strategies for rapid rehousing into permanent accommodation, effective social support and health care for parents and children, and protection from violence and intimidation should be developed and implemented.	CONCLUSIONS

Angiotensin receptor blockers (ARB) and angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors are known to reduce proteinuria.	BACKGROUND
Their combination might be more effective than either treatment alone, but long-term data for comparative changes in renal function are not available.	BACKGROUND
We investigated the renal effects of ramipril (an ACE inhibitor), telmisartan (an ARB), and their combination in patients aged 55 years or older with established atherosclerotic vascular disease or with diabetes with end-organ damage.	BACKGROUND
The trial ran from 2001 to 2007.	METHODS
After a 3-week run-in period, 25 620 participants were randomly assigned to ramipril 10 mg a day (n=8576), telmisartan 80 mg a day (n=8542), or to a combination of both drugs (n=8502; median follow-up was 56 months), and renal function and proteinuria were measured.	METHODS
The primary renal outcome was a composite of dialysis, doubling of serum creatinine, and death.	METHODS
Analysis was by intention to treat.	METHODS
This study is registered with ClinicalTrials.gov, number NCT00153101.	METHODS
784 patients permanently discontinued randomised therapy during the trial because of hypotensive symptoms (406 on combination therapy, 149 on ramipril, and 229 on telmisartan).	RESULTS
The number of events for the composite primary outcome was similar for telmisartan (n=1147 [13.4%]) and ramipril (1150 [13.5%]; hazard ratio [HR] 1.00, 95% CI 0.92-1.09), but was increased with combination therapy (1233 [14.5%]; HR 1.09, 1.01-1.18, p=0.037).	RESULTS
The secondary renal outcome, dialysis or doubling of serum creatinine, was similar with telmisartan (189 [2.21%]) and ramipril (174 [2.03%]; HR 1.09, 0.89-1.34) and more frequent with combination therapy (212 [2.49%]: HR 1.24, 1.01-1.51, p=0.038).	RESULTS
Estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) declined least with ramipril compared with telmisartan (-2.82 [SD 17.2] mL/min/1.73 m(2)vs -4.12 [17.4], p<0.0001) or combination therapy (-6.11 [17.9], p<0.0001).	RESULTS
The increase in urinary albumin excretion was less with telmisartan (p=0.004) or with combination therapy (p=0.001) than with ramipril.	RESULTS
In people at high vascular risk, telmisartan's effects on major renal outcomes are similar to ramipril.	CONCLUSIONS
Although combination therapy reduces proteinuria to a greater extent than monotherapy, overall it worsens major renal outcomes.	CONCLUSIONS

Increased expression of the tetraspanin TSPAN7 has been observed in a number of cancers; however, it is unclear how TSPAN7 plays a role in cancer progression.	BACKGROUND
We investigated the expression of TSPAN7 in the haematological malignancy multiple myleoma (MM) and assessed the consequences of TSPAN7 expression in the adhesion, migration and growth of MM plasma cells (PC) in vitro and in bone marrow (BM) homing and tumour growth in vivo.	METHODS
Finally, we characterised the association of TSPAN7 with cell surface partner molecules in vitro.	METHODS
TSPAN7 was found to be highly expressed at the RNA and protein level in CD138(+) MM PC from approximately 50% of MM patients.	RESULTS
TSPAN7 overexpression in the murine myeloma cell line 5TGM1 significantly reduced tumour burden in 5TGM1/KaLwRij mice 4 weeks after intravenous adminstration of 5TGM1 cells.	RESULTS
While TSPAN7 overexpression did not affect cell proliferation in vitro, TSPAN7 increased 5TGM1 cell adhesion to BM stromal cells and transendothelial migration.	RESULTS
In addition, TSPAN7 was found to associate with the molecular chaperone calnexin on the cell surface.	RESULTS
These results suggest that elevated TSPAN7 may be associated with better outcomes for up to 50% of MM patients.	CONCLUSIONS

Therapies to target prostate cancer bone metastases have only limited effects.	OBJECTIVE
New treatments are focused on the interaction between cancer cells, bone marrow cells and the bone matrix.	OBJECTIVE
Osteoclasts play an important role in the development of bone tumors caused by prostate cancer.	OBJECTIVE
Since Src kinase has been shown to be necessary for osteoclast function, we hypothesized that dasatinib, a Src family kinase inhibitor, would reduce osteoclast activity and prostate cancer (PC-3) cell-induced osteoclast formation.	OBJECTIVE
Dasatinib inhibited RANKL-induced osteoclast differentiation of bone marrow-derived monocytes with an EC(50) of 7.5 nM. PC-3 cells, a human prostate cancer cell line, were able to differentiate RAW 264.7 cells, a murine monocytic cell line, into osteoclasts, and dasatinib inhibited this differentiation.	RESULTS
In addition, conditioned medium from PC-3 cell cultures was able to differentiate RAW 264.7 cells into osteoclasts and this too, was inhibited by dasatinib.	RESULTS
Even the lowest concentration of dasatinib, 1.25 nmol, inhibited osteoclast differentiation by 29%.	RESULTS
Moreover, dasatinib inhibited osteoclast activity by 58% as measured by collagen 1 release.	RESULTS
We performed in vitro experiments utilizing the Src family kinase inhibitor dasatinib to target osteoclast activation as a means of inhibiting prostate cancer bone metastases.	METHODS
Dasatinib inhibits osteoclast differentiation of mouse primary bone marrow-derived monocytes and PC-3 cell-induced osteoclast differentiation.	CONCLUSIONS
Dasatinib also inhibits osteoclast degradation activity.	CONCLUSIONS
Inhibiting osteoclast differentiation and activity may be an effective targeted therapy in patients with prostate cancer bone metastases.	CONCLUSIONS

Melanocortin receptor 4 (MC4R) deficiency is characterized by increased linear growth greater than expected for the degree of obesity.	BACKGROUND
The objective of the investigation was to study the somatotroph axis in obese MC4R-deficient patients and equally obese controls.	OBJECTIVE
We obtained anthropometric measurements and insulin concentrations in 153 MC4R-deficient subjects and 1392 controls matched for age and severity of obesity.	METHODS
We measured fasting IGF-I, IGF-II, IGF binding protein (IGFBP)-1, IGFBP-3, and acid-labile subunit levels in a subset of 33 MC4R-deficient patients and 36 control subjects.	METHODS
We examined pulsatile GH secretion in six adult MC4R-deficient subjects and six obese controls.	METHODS
Height sd score was significantly greater in MC4R-deficient children under 5 yr of age compared with controls (mean ± SEM: 2.3 ± 0.06 vs. 1.8 ± 0.04, P < 0.001), an effect that persisted throughout childhood.	RESULTS
Final height (cm) was greater in MC4R-deficient men (mean ± SEM 173 ± 2.5 vs. 168 ± 2.1, P < 0.001) and women (mean 165 ± 2.1 vs. 158 ± 1.9, P < 0.001).	RESULTS
Fasting IGF-I, IGF-II, acid-labile subunit, and IGFBP-3 concentrations were similar in the two groups.	RESULTS
GH levels were markedly suppressed in obese controls, but pulsatile GH secretion was retained in MC4R deficiency.	RESULTS
The mean maximal GH secretion rate per burst (P < 0.05) and mass per burst (P < 0.05) were increased in MC4R deficiency, consistent with increased pulsatile and total GH secretion.	RESULTS
Fasting insulin levels were markedly elevated in MC4R-deficient children.	RESULTS
In MC4R deficiency, increased linear growth in childhood leads to increased adult final height, greater than predicted by obesity alone.	CONCLUSIONS
GH pulsatility is maintained in MC4R deficiency, a finding consistent with animal studies, suggesting a role for MC4R in controlling hypothalamic somatostatinergic tone.	CONCLUSIONS
Fasting insulin levels are significantly higher in children carrying MC4R mutations.	CONCLUSIONS
Both of these factors may contribute to the accelerated growth phenotype characteristic of MC4R deficiency.	CONCLUSIONS

To assess whether population screening for impaired vision among older people in the community leads to improvements in vision.	OBJECTIVE
Systematic review of randomised controlled trials of population screening in the community that included any assessment of vision or visual function with at least 6 months' follow up.	METHODS
Adults aged 65 or over.	OBJECTIVE
Proportions with visual impairment in intervention and control groups with any method of assessing visual impairment.	METHODS
There were no trials that primarily assessed visual screening.	RESULTS
Outcome data on vision were available for 3494 people in five trials of multiphasic assessment.	RESULTS
All the trials used self reported measures for vision impairment, both as screening tools and as outcome measures.	RESULTS
The inclusion of a visual screening component in the assessment did not result in improvements in self reported visual problems (pooled odds ratio 1.04:95% confidence interval 0.89 to 1.22).	RESULTS
A small reduction (11%) in the number of older people with self reported visual problems cannot be excluded.	RESULTS
Screening of asymptomatic older people in the community is not justified on present evidence.	CONCLUSIONS
Visual impairment in this age group can usually be reduced with treatment.	CONCLUSIONS
It is unclear why no benefit was seen.	CONCLUSIONS
Further work is needed to clarify what interventions are appropriate for older people with unreported impairment of vision.	CONCLUSIONS

Transthyretin amyloidosis is caused by the deposition of hepatocyte-derived transthyretin amyloid in peripheral nerves and the heart.	BACKGROUND
A therapeutic approach mediated by RNA interference (RNAi) could reduce the production of transthyretin.	BACKGROUND
We identified a potent antitransthyretin small interfering RNA, which was encapsulated in two distinct first- and second-generation formulations of lipid nanoparticles, generating ALN-TTR01 and ALN-TTR02, respectively.	METHODS
Each formulation was studied in a single-dose, placebo-controlled phase 1 trial to assess safety and effect on transthyretin levels.	METHODS
We first evaluated ALN-TTR01 (at doses of 0.01 to 1.0 mg per kilogram of body weight) in 32 patients with transthyretin amyloidosis and then evaluated ALN-TTR02 (at doses of 0.01 to 0.5 mg per kilogram) in 17 healthy volunteers.	METHODS
Rapid, dose-dependent, and durable lowering of transthyretin levels was observed in the two trials.	RESULTS
At a dose of 1.0 mg per kilogram, ALN-TTR01 suppressed transthyretin, with a mean reduction at day 7 of 38%, as compared with placebo (P=0.01); levels of mutant and nonmutant forms of transthyretin were lowered to a similar extent.	RESULTS
For ALN-TTR02, the mean reductions in transthyretin levels at doses of 0.15 to 0.3 mg per kilogram ranged from 82.3 to 86.8%, with reductions of 56.6 to 67.1% at 28 days (P<0.001 for all comparisons).	RESULTS
These reductions were shown to be RNAi-mediated.	RESULTS
Mild-to-moderate infusion-related reactions occurred in 20.8% and 7.7% of participants receiving ALN-TTR01 and ALN-TTR02, respectively.	RESULTS
ALN-TTR01 and ALN-TTR02 suppressed the production of both mutant and nonmutant forms of transthyretin, establishing proof of concept for RNAi therapy targeting messenger RNA transcribed from a disease-causing gene.	CONCLUSIONS
(Funded by Alnylam Pharmaceuticals; ClinicalTrials.gov numbers, NCT01148953 and NCT01559077.).	CONCLUSIONS

Chromosomal rearrangements of the gene encoding ROS1 proto-oncogene receptor tyrosine kinase (ROS1) define a distinct molecular subgroup of non-small-cell lung cancers (NSCLCs) that may be susceptible to therapeutic ROS1 kinase inhibition.	BACKGROUND
Crizotinib is a small-molecule tyrosine kinase inhibitor of anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK), ROS1, and another proto-oncogene receptor tyrosine kinase, MET.	BACKGROUND
We enrolled 50 patients with advanced NSCLC who tested positive for ROS1 rearrangement in an expansion cohort of the phase 1 study of crizotinib.	METHODS
Patients were treated with crizotinib at the standard oral dose of 250 mg twice daily and assessed for safety, pharmacokinetics, and response to therapy.	METHODS
ROS1 fusion partners were identified with the use of next-generation sequencing or reverse-transcriptase-polymerase-chain-reaction assays.	METHODS
The objective response rate was 72% (95% confidence interval [CI], 58 to 84), with 3 complete responses and 33 partial responses.	RESULTS
The median duration of response was 17.6 months (95% CI, 14.5 to not reached).	RESULTS
Median progression-free survival was 19.2 months (95% CI, 14.4 to not reached), with 25 patients (50%) still in follow-up for progression.	RESULTS
Among 30 tumors that were tested, we identified 7 ROS1 fusion partners: 5 known and 2 novel partner genes.	RESULTS
No correlation was observed between the type of ROS1 rearrangement and the clinical response to crizotinib.	RESULTS
The safety profile of crizotinib was similar to that seen in patients with ALK-rearranged NSCLC.	RESULTS
In this study, crizotinib showed marked antitumor activity in patients with advanced ROS1-rearranged NSCLC.	CONCLUSIONS
ROS1 rearrangement defines a second molecular subgroup of NSCLC for which crizotinib is highly active.	CONCLUSIONS
(Funded by Pfizer and others; ClinicalTrials.gov number, NCT00585195.).	CONCLUSIONS

In the studies of left ventricular dysfunction (SOLVD), enalapril reduced mortality in patients with symptomatic but not asymptomatic left ventricular systolic dysfunction during the trial.	BACKGROUND
We did a 12-year follow-up of SOLVD to establish if the mortality reduction with enalapril among patients with heart failure was sustained, and whether a subsequent reduction in mortality would emerge among those with asymptomatic ventricular dysfunction.	BACKGROUND
Of the 6797 patients previously enrolled in the SOLVD prevention and treatment trials, we ascertained the subsequent vital status of 5165 individuals who were alive when the trials had been completed.	METHODS
Follow-up was done through direct contacts in Belgium and linkages with national death registries and federal beneficiary or historic tax summary files in the USA and Canada.	METHODS
Follow-up was 99.8% (6784/6797) complete.	RESULTS
In the prevention trial, 50.9% (1074/2111) of the enalapril group had died compared with 56.4% (1195/2117) of the placebo group (generalised Wilcoxon p=0.001).	RESULTS
In the treatment trial, 79.8% (1025/1285) of the enalapril group had died compared with 80.8% (1038/1284) of the placebo group (generalised Wilcoxon p=0.01).	RESULTS
The reductions in cardiac deaths were significant and similar in both trials.	RESULTS
When data for the prevention and treatment trials were combined, the hazard ratio for death was 0.90 for the enalapril group compared with the placebo group (95% CI 0.84-0.95, generalised Wilcoxon p=0.0003).	RESULTS
Enalapril extended median survival by 9.4 months in the combined trials (95% CI 2.8-16.5, p=0.004).	RESULTS
Treatment with enalapril for 3-4 years led to a sustained improvement in survival beyond the original trial period in patients with left ventricular systolic dysfunction, with an important increase in life expectancy.	CONCLUSIONS

An increased volume of patients is associated with improved survival in numerous high-risk medical and surgical conditions.	BACKGROUND
The relationship between the number of patients admitted (hospital volume) and outcome among patients with critical illnesses is unknown.	BACKGROUND
We analyzed data from 20,241 nonsurgical patients receiving mechanical ventilation at 37 acute care hospitals in the Acute Physiology and Chronic Health Evaluation clinical information system from 2002 through 2003.	METHODS
Multivariate analyses were performed to adjust for the severity of illness and other differences in the case mix.	METHODS
An increase in hospital volume was associated with improved survival among patients receiving mechanical ventilation in the intensive care unit (ICU) and in the hospital.	RESULTS
Admission to a hospital in the highest quartile according to volume (i.e., >400 patients receiving mechanical ventilation per year) was associated with a 37 percent reduction in the adjusted odds of death in the ICU as compared with admission to hospitals in the lowest quartile (< or =150 patients receiving mechanical ventilation per year, P<0.001).	RESULTS
In-hospital mortality was similarly reduced (adjusted odds ratio, 0.66; 95 percent confidence interval, 0.52 to 0.83; P<0.001).	RESULTS
A typical patient in a hospital in a low-volume quartile would have an adjusted in-hospital mortality of 34.2 percent as compared with 25.5 percent in a hospital in a high-volume quartile.	RESULTS
Among survivors, there were no significant trends in the length of stay in the ICU or the hospital.	RESULTS
Mechanical ventilation of patients in a hospital with a high case volume is associated with reduced mortality.	CONCLUSIONS
Further research is needed to determine the mechanism of the relationship between volume and outcome among patients with a critical illness.	CONCLUSIONS

Ghrelin is an orexigenic hormone that can increase body weight.	BACKGROUND
Its circulating levels increase before meals and are suppressed after food ingestion.	BACKGROUND
Understanding the effects of specific types of ingested macronutrients on ghrelin regulation could facilitate the design of weight-reducing diets.	BACKGROUND
We sought to understand how ingestion of carbohydrates, proteins, or lipids affect acyl (bioactive) and total ghrelin levels among human subjects, hypothesizing that lipids might suppress ghrelin levels less effectively than do either carbohydrates or proteins.	OBJECTIVE
This was a randomized, within-subjects cross-over study.	METHODS
The study was conducted at a University Clinical Research Center.	METHODS
PARTICIPANTS	METHODS
There were 16 healthy human subjects included in the study.	METHODS
Isocaloric, isovolemic beverages composed primarily of carbohydrates, proteins, or lipids were provided.	METHODS
The magnitude of postprandial suppression of total and acyl ghrelin levels (measured with a novel acyl-selective, two-site ELISA) was determined.	METHODS
All beverages suppressed plasma acyl and total ghrelin levels.	RESULTS
A significant effect of macronutrient class on decremental area under the curve for both acyl and total ghrelin was observed; the rank order for magnitude of suppression was protein more than carbohydrate more than lipid.	RESULTS
Total ghrelin nadir levels were significantly lower after both carbohydrate and protein, compared with lipid beverages.	RESULTS
In the first 3 postprandial hours, the rank order for acyl and total ghrelin suppression was carbohydrate more than protein more than lipid.	RESULTS
In the subsequent 3 h, there was a marked rebound above preprandial values of acyl and total ghrelin after carbohydrate ingestion alone.	RESULTS
These findings suggest possible mechanisms contributing to the effects of high-protein/low-carbohydrate diets to promote weight loss, and high-fat diets to promote weight gain.	CONCLUSIONS

To determine if visual field (VF) loss resulting from glaucoma is associated with greater fear of falling.	OBJECTIVE
Prospective, observational study.	METHODS
Fear of falling was compared between 83 glaucoma subjects with bilateral VF loss and 60 control subjects with good visual acuity and without significant VF loss recruited from patients followed up for suspicion of glaucoma.	METHODS
Participants completed the University of Illinois at Chicago Fear of Falling Questionnaire.	METHODS
The extent of fear of falling was assessed using Rasch analysis.	METHODS
Subject ability to perform tasks without fear of falling was expressed in logits, with lower scores implying less ability and greater fear of falling.	METHODS
Glaucoma subjects had greater VF loss than control subjects (median better-eye mean deviation [MD] of -8.0 decibels [dB] vs. +0.2 dB; P<0.001), but did not differ with regard to age, race, gender, employment status, the presence of other adults in the home, body mass index (BMI), grip strength, cognitive ability, mood, or comorbid illness (P ≥ 0.1 for all).	RESULTS
In multivariate models, glaucoma subjects reported greater fear of falling as compared with controls (β = -1.20 logits; 95% confidence interval [CI], -1.87 to -0.53; P = 0.001), and fear of falling increased with greater VF loss severity (β = -0.52 logits per 5-dB decrement in the better eye VF MD; 95% CI, -0.72 to -0.33; P<0.001).	RESULTS
Other variables predicting greater fear of falling included female gender (β = -0.55 logits; 95% CI, -1.03 to -0.06; P = 0.03), higher BMI (β = -0.07 logits per 1-unit increase in BMI; 95% CI, -0.13 to -0.01; P = 0.02), living with another adult (β = -1.16 logits; 95% CI, -0.34 to -1.99 logits; P = 0.006), and greater comorbid illness (β = -0.53 logits/1 additional illness; 95% CI, -0.74 to -0.32; P<0.001).	RESULTS
Bilateral VF loss resulting from glaucoma is associated with greater fear of falling, with an impact that exceeds numerous other risk factors.	CONCLUSIONS
Given the physical and psychological repercussions associated with fear of falling, significant quality-of-life improvements may be achievable in patients with VF loss by screening for, and developing interventions to minimize, fear of falling.	CONCLUSIONS

Preoperative C-reactive protein (CRP) levels more than 10 mg/l have been shown to be associated with increased morbidity and mortality after cardiac surgery.	BACKGROUND
We examine the value of preoperative CRP levels less than 10 mg/l for predicting long-term, all-cause mortality and hospital length of stay in surgical patients undergoing primary, nonemergent coronary artery bypass graft-only surgery.	BACKGROUND
We examined the association between preoperative CRP levels stratified into four categories (< 1, 1-3, 3-10, and > 10 mg/l), and 7-yr all-cause mortality and hospital length of stay in 914 prospectively enrolled primary, nonemergent coronary artery bypass graft-only surgical patients using a proportional hazards regression model.	METHODS
Eighty-seven patients (9.5%) died during a mean follow-up period of 4.8 +/-	RESULTS
1.5 yr.	RESULTS
After proportional hazards adjustment, the 3-10 and > 10 mg/l preoperative CRP groups were associated with long-term, all-cause mortality (hazards ratios [95% CI]: 2.50 [1.22-5.16], P = 0.01 and 2.66 [1.21-5.80], P = 0.02, respectively) and extended hospital length of stay (1.32 [1.07-1.63], P < 0.001 and 1.27 [1.02-1.62], P = 0.001, respectively).	RESULTS
We demonstrate that preoperative CRP levels as low as 3 mg/l are associated with increased long-term mortality and extended hospital length of stay in relatively lower-acuity patients undergoing primary, nonemergent coronary artery bypass graft-only surgery.	CONCLUSIONS
These important findings may allow for more objective risk stratification of patients who present for uncomplicated surgical coronary revascularization.	CONCLUSIONS

To identify changes in the occurrence of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease that might be related to the epidemic of bovine spongiform encephalopathy.	OBJECTIVE
Epidemiological surveillance of the United Kingdom population for Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease based on (a) referral of suspected cases by neurologists, neuropathologists, and neurophysiologists and (b) death certificates.	METHODS
England and Wales during 1970-84, and whole of the United Kingdom during 1985-96.	METHODS
All 662 patients identified as sporadic cases of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease.	OBJECTIVE
Age distribution of patients, age specific time trends of disease, occupational exposure to cattle, potential exposure to causative agent of bovine spongiform encephalopathy.	METHODS
During 1970-96 there was an increase in the number of sporadic cases of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease recorded yearly in England and Wales.	RESULTS
The greatest increase was among people aged over 70.	RESULTS
There was a statistically significant excess of cases among dairy farm workers and their spouses and among people at increased risk of contact with live cattle infected with bovine spongiform encephalopathy.	RESULTS
During 1994-6 there were six deaths from sporadic Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease in the United Kingdom in patients aged under 30.	RESULTS
The increase in the incidence of sporadic Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease and the high incidence in dairy farmers in the United Kingdom may be unrelated to bovine spongiform encephalopathy.	CONCLUSIONS
The most striking change in the pattern of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease in the United Kingdom after the epidemic of bovine spongiform encephalopathy is provided by the incidence in a group of exceptionally young patients with a consistent and unusual neuropathological profile.	CONCLUSIONS
The outcome of mouse transmission studies and the future incidence of the disease in the United Kingdom and elsewhere, will be important in judging whether the agent causing bovine spongiform encephalopathy has infected humans.	CONCLUSIONS

The association between antecedent head injury and AD is inconsistent.	BACKGROUND
To examine the association between early adult head injury, as documented by military hospital records, and dementia in late life; and to evaluate the interaction between head injury and APOE epsilon4 as risk factors for dementia.	OBJECTIVE
The study had a population-based prospective historical cohort design.	METHODS
It included men who were World War II Navy and Marine veterans, and were hospitalized during their military service with a diagnosis of either a nonpenetrating head injury or another unrelated condition.	METHODS
In 1996 to 1997, military medical records were abstracted to document the occurrence and details of closed head injury.	METHODS
The entire sample was then evaluated for dementia and AD using a multistage procedure.	METHODS
There were 548 veterans with head injury and 1228 without head injury who completed all assigned stages of the study.	METHODS
The authors estimated risk of dementia, specifically AD, using proportional hazards models.	METHODS
Both moderate head injury (hazard ratio [HR] = 2.32; CI = 1.04 to 5.17) and severe head injury (HR = 4.51; CI = 1.77 to 11.47) were associated with increased risk of AD.	RESULTS
Results were similar for dementia in general.	RESULTS
The results for mild head injury were inconclusive.	RESULTS
When the authors stratified by the number of APOE epsilon4 alleles, they observed a nonsignificant trend toward a stronger association between AD and head injury in men with more epsilon4 alleles.	RESULTS
Moderate and severe head injuries in young men may be associated with increased risk of AD and other dementias in late life.	CONCLUSIONS
However, the authors cannot exclude the possibility that other unmeasured factors may be influencing this association.	CONCLUSIONS

Ketamine, as an anesthetic agent, has an anti-inflammatory effect.	BACKGROUND
In the present study, we investigated whether ketamine inhibits release of high mobility group box 1 (HMGB1), a late-phase cytokine of sepsis, in lipopolysaccharide (LPS)-stimulated macrophages through heme oxygenase-1 (HO-1) induction.	BACKGROUND
Macrophages were preincubated with various concentrations of ketamine and then treated with LPS (1 μg/mL).	METHODS
The cell culture supernatants were collected to measure inflammatory mediators (HMGB1, nitric oxide, tumor necrosis factor-α, and interleukin 1β) by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay.	METHODS
Moreover, HO-1 protein expression, the phosphorylation and degradation of IκB-α, and the nuclear translocation of nuclear factor E2-related factor 2 and nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) p65 were tested by Western blot analysis.	METHODS
In addition, to further identify the role of HO-1 in this process, tin protoporphyrin (SnPP), an HO-1 inhibitor, was used.	METHODS
Ketamine treatment dose-dependently attenuated the increased levels of proinflammatory mediators (HMGB1, nitric oxide, tumor necrosis factor α, and interleukin 1β) and increased the HO-1 protein expression in LPS-activated macrophages.	RESULTS
Furthermore, ketamine suppressed the phosphorylation and degradation of IκB-α as well as the LPS-stimulated nuclear translocation of NF-κB p65 in macrophages.	RESULTS
In addition, the present study also demonstrated that ketamine induced HO-1 expression through the nuclear translocation of nuclear factor E2-related factor 2 in macrophages.	RESULTS
The effects of ketamine on LPS-induced proinflammatory cytokines production were partially reversed by the HO inhibitor tin protoporphyrin (SnPP).	RESULTS
Ketamine inhibits the release of HMGB1 in LPS-stimulated macrophages, and this effect is at least partly mediated by the activation of the Nrf2/HO-1 pathway and NF-κB suppression.	CONCLUSIONS

Androgens play a critical role in the growth of both androgen dependent and castration-resistant prostate cancer (CRPC).	BACKGROUND
Only a few micro-RNAs (miRNAs) have been suggested to be androgen regulated.	BACKGROUND
We aim to identify androgen regulated miRNAs.	BACKGROUND
We utilized LNCaP derived model, we have established, and which overexpresses the androgen receptor (AR), the VCaP cell line, and 13 intact-castrated prostate cancer (PC) xenograft pairs, as well as clinical specimens of untreated (PC) and CRPC.	METHODS
The expression of miRNAs was analyzed by microarrays and quantitative RT-PCR (Q-RT-PCR).	METHODS
Transfection of pre-miR-141 and anti-miR-141 was also used.	METHODS
Seventeen miRNAs were > 1.5-fold up- or downregulated upon dihydrotestosterone (DHT) treatment in the cell lines, and 42 after castration in the AR-positive xenografts.	RESULTS
Only four miRNAs (miR-10a, miR-141, miR-150*, and miR-1225-5p) showed similar androgen regulation in both cell lines and xenografts.	RESULTS
Of those, miR-141 was found to be expressed more in PC and CRPC compared to benign prostate hyperplasia.	RESULTS
Additionally, the overexpression of miR-141 enhanced growth of parental LNCaP cells while inhibition of miR-141 by anti-miR-141 suppressed the growth of the LNCaP subline overexpressing AR.	RESULTS
Only a few miRNAs were found to be androgen-regulated in both cell lines and xenografts models.	CONCLUSIONS
Of those, the expression of miR-141 was upregulated in cancer.	CONCLUSIONS
The ectopic overexpression of miR-141 increased growth of LNCaP cell suggesting it may contribute to the progression of PC.	CONCLUSIONS

This longitudinal study conducted path analyses to examine the relationships between treatment processes and outcomes among patients in community-based drug treatment programs.	OBJECTIVE
A total of 1,939 patients from 36 outpatient drug-free and residential treatment programs in 13 California counties were assessed at intake, discharge, three months after admission, and nine months after admission.	METHODS
Path analyses were conducted to relate the quantity and quality of services that were received in the first three months of treatment to treatment retention and outcomes at the nine-month follow-up.	METHODS
Patients were determined to have a favorable outcome if for at least 30 days before the follow-up assessment they did not use drugs, were not involved in criminal activity, and lived in the community.	METHODS
The path analyses controlled for patients' baseline characteristics.	METHODS
Greater service intensity and satisfaction were positively related to either treatment completion or longer treatment retention, which in turn was related to favorable treatment outcomes.	RESULTS
Patients with greater problem severity received more services and were more likely to be satisfied with treatment.	RESULTS
These patterns were similar for patients regardless of whether they were treated in outpatient drug-free programs or residential programs.	RESULTS
The positive association between process measures-that is, greater levels of service intensity, satisfaction, and either treatment completion or retention-and treatment outcome strongly suggests that improvements in these key elements of the treatment process will improve treatment outcomes.	CONCLUSIONS

Since 1990, overall breast cancer mortality rates in the United States decreased 24%.	OBJECTIVE
This decline has been attributed to mammography screening and adjuvant systemic therapy.	OBJECTIVE
However, the efficacy of these modalities may depend on estrogen receptor (ER) expression and age.	OBJECTIVE
We therefore examined breast cancer mortality trends in the United States according to ER status and age.	OBJECTIVE
Using the Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results (SEER) program (1990-2003), we calculated trends in incidence-based mortality (IBM), annual hazard rates for breast cancer deaths after diagnosis, and relative hazard rates for women with ER-positive and ER-negative tumors.	METHODS
Relative hazard rates were assessed with Cox proportional hazards models, adjusted for stage and grade, and stratified by age at diagnosis.	METHODS
During the study period, IBM and annual hazard rates for breast cancer deaths decreased among women with ER-positive and ER-negative tumors, although declines were greater for those with ER-positive tumors.	RESULTS
Among women younger than 70 years, relative hazard rates declined 38% for those with ER-positive tumors versus 19% for those with ER-negative tumors.	RESULTS
Among women 70 years or older, relative hazard rates declined 14% for those with ER-positive tumors versus no significant decline for those with ER-negative tumors.	RESULTS
In the United States, breast cancer mortality rates have declined among women with ER-positive and ER-negative tumors, with greater declines among younger women and those with ER-positive tumors.	CONCLUSIONS
Although mortality in all groups remains unacceptably high, additional emphasis should be placed on improving outcomes of breast cancer patients older than 70 years and those of all ages with ER-negative tumors.	CONCLUSIONS

Imiquimod is an immune response modifier that acts through toll-like receptor 7 to induce cytokine production and a subsequent innate and adaptive cell-mediated immune response.	BACKGROUND
Clinical studies have demonstrated clinical and histological clearance of superficial basal cell carcinoma (sBCC) after treatment with imiquimod 5% cream.	BACKGROUND
To evaluate the safety and clinical efficacy of imiquimod (Aldaratrade mark; 3M Pharmaceuticals, St Paul, MN, U.S.A.) 5% cream for the treatment of sBCC in a multicentre, randomized, parallel, vehicle-controlled, double-blind, phase III clinical study conducted at 26 centres in Europe.	OBJECTIVE
Subjects who had at least one histologically confirmed sBCC tumour were randomized to apply imiquimod or vehicle cream to the target tumour once daily, seven times per week (7 x/week) for 6 weeks.	METHODS
The target tumour location was identified with an indelible ink mark before treatment initiation.	METHODS
The treated tumour site was clinically assessed for treatment response at 12 weeks post-treatment and was then excised for histological evaluation.	METHODS
Efficacy assessments included the composite response rates (proportion of subjects with clinical and histological clearance) and response rates solely based on histology (proportion of subjects with histological clearance).	METHODS
Safety assessments, which included adverse events and scoring of local skin reactions (LSRs), were carried out throughout the study.	METHODS
In total, 166 subjects were enrolled in this study.	RESULTS
For the intent-to-treat dataset, there was a statistically significant difference between imiquimod and vehicle groups for both composite clearance rates (clinical and histological assessments) and histological clearance rates.	RESULTS
Composite clearance was demonstrated in 77% and 6% of subjects treated with imiquimod and vehicle cream, respectively.	RESULTS
Histological clearance was demonstrated in 80% and 6% of subjects treated with imiquimod and vehicle cream, respectively.	RESULTS
The most frequently reported safety findings were investigator-assessed LSRs and spontaneous reports by subjects of application site reactions, which occurred more frequently in the imiquimod group than in the vehicle group.	RESULTS
Imiquimod 5% cream administered 7 x/week for 6 weeks is a safe and effective treatment for sBCC when compared with vehicle cream.	CONCLUSIONS

To establish high cell density cultivation process of recombinant Helicobacter pylori multi-epitope vaccine engineering bacteria BIB.	OBJECTIVE
Based on the results of shake flask fermentation, the process was magnified into volume of a 50 L fermenter to optimize and verify the factors affecting the yield of the target protein, such as the fermentation medium, working seed inoculation amount, inducer concentration, induction starting time, induction duration, inducer adding mode and feeding strategy.	METHODS
After activated in modified TB medium at 37°C for 8 h, the BIB working seed was inoculated at 5% (v/v) and was induced for expression for another 11 h by the final concentration of 5 mmol/L lactose.	RESULTS
